“Oh, I didn’t realize you two were involved in that way.” Janet frowned, “We may need some additional disclosure forms. Are you the father?” Janet asked, oblivious to what she had just revealed. 

 

“Absolutely NOT!” Agatha shouted just as Freddy, in utter shock, gasped “Father!?” 

 

Agatha rounded on him as he looked on in horror at her rage, “If you must know, I’m fucking pregnant you asshole! I was meeting with her to discuss my maternity leave. Not that it’s any of your fucking business!” She bellowed “I didn’t mention anything about your relationship with the intern but since you’re so fucking insistent I’m sure she’d love to hear all about it!” She snapped before turning to Sharon. “Come on, we’re going to be late for Herb’s meeting.” She stormed off down the hallway towards Herb’s office with Sharon closely in tow leaving Freddy and Janet alone in the aftermath. 

 

After a brief moment of silence Janet piped up, as her head tilted to the side inquisitively. “What exactly did she mean by relationship with the intern?” 

 

————————————————-

 

Agatha stormed into Herb’s office just as he was finishing a call. 

 

“Thanks Garrett, I’ll catch up with you when I get back, I have to run to my next meeting.” He said as he immediately hung up the phone. “Agatha, Sharon, good to see you. Is everything alright?” He asked, seeing her dismay. 

 

“Everything’s fine!” Agatha grunted as she settled into her chair. “I’ve asked Sharon to sit in today, she’s going to be joining us for planning meetings this year. We’ll discuss the justification when we talk after this.” She explained as calmly as she could manage. 

 

“Oh, alright, glad to have you!” Herb nodded in Sharon’s direction though his attention didn’t entirely leave Agatha. “Did you happen to see Freddy on your way over?”

 

“Yes, unfortunately.” She replied just as Freddy burst through the doors. 

 

“Sorry I’m late, Herb.” He gasped, nearly out of breath.

 

“Surprised you made it at all.” Agatha grumbled under her breath as he settled into the seat next to her. “I thought you might have been held up with Janet.” 

 

“Oh don’t worry, I have a meeting with her first thing Monday. No thanks to you.” He snapped

 

“No thanks to me?! You’re the one who couldn’t mind your own damn business!” She bit back

 

“You implied you were filing a complaint against me, as far as I knew it was my business!” He exclaimed, growing more irritated. 

 

“I didn’t imply shit, you assumed.” she responded, matching his energy.

 

“Alright, alright! Let’s get it together!” Herb demanded. “We have enough to get through today without you at each other's throats. Whatever is going on between you two you’ll have to sort through it later. And be sure that you do, we’re going to need all hands on deck if we’re going to pull off what I have in mind.” 

 

As they reluctantly settled, Herb laid out his plan for the upcoming festival. Along with the regular calendar of concerts and events he wanted to extend the festivities to outside the building. In collaboration with local artists, restaurants, and breweries, they would host a night market each weekend, Thursday through Saturday. 

 

“You do understand this is going to require an entire team to execute. We have nowhere near the amount of resources or people to manage something like this currently.” Agatha voiced sharply as her body hummed with tension at the thought of it all. 

 

“Which is why, thanks in large part to your efforts earlier this year, we are planning to hire a team of seasonal workers and contractors to help us manage.” Herb explained

 

“Fantastic.” She muttered as a pit formed in her stomach thinking of the insurmountable task ahead. Why did she have to be so good at her job?

 

“Well I for one think this is absolutely brilliant! It’s exactly the kind of thing I can sink my marketing teeth into. Lots to showcase, if we can pull it off.” Freddy goaded, flashing a sideways glance at Agatha. 

 

“Well good, there’s a lot to do!” Herb admitted. “I was pleasantly surprised to get the necessary permits and permissions from the city today, which is why I hurried to gather us before my trip. We are finally clear to move forward with our plans. I have a few companies I’ve been looking at working with. I’d like you two to review and select what’s needed while I’m out. I have a list of vendors to consider as well, Agatha I’d like you to review that. Freddy, I have the names of the artists we are looking to partner with if you’d get started on some promotional materials, keeping in mind the elemental theme we agreed upon.” Herb said as he handed each of them a folder. “I’d like to hit the ground running when I return so I’m counting on both of you.” 

 

“No worries on my end! Agatha, you seem surprisingly quiet. Are you not excited about Herb’s plan?” Freddy asked tauntingly. 

 

“Thrilled.” She growled, glaring at him. 

 

“Excellent! I know this is going to be an undertaking, it’s something we’ve talked about wanting to do for a few years, so now that we have the opportunity we can’t afford to take any half-measures, understand? Do either of you have any questions before we wrap this up?” 

 

“No, I’m good.” Freddy commented, “Agatha?” 

 

“Not at the moment, as long as you’re still good to chat after this?” She asked in a hushed tone. 

 

“Yeah, of course! I have a few minutes. Freddy, I’ll catch you when I’m back. Sharon, good to see you, nice to have you for this project, it’s going to be a doozy but I think it’ll be a big hit!” Herb cheered. 

 

“Oh definitely, sounds like a hoot! Aha-ha!” Sharon replied before turning to Agatha, “Is there anything else you need dear? Would you like me to stay until after your chat with Herb?” Sharon asked discreetly.

 

“No, that’s alright, you head home. I’ll see you at 10 tomorrow.”  

 

“Alright honey!” She gave Agatha a caring smile and rested a hand on her shoulder as she leaned in, whispering “Good luck!” before following Freddy out the door.




Agatha bit her lip anxiously as Herb made his way to lean against his desk. “So, there’s something you wanted to talk about? Is everything alright? You and Freddy both seemed pretty upset when you got here.” 

 

She let out a nervous laugh, recalling their confrontation, “Yeah, Freddy doesn’t seem to know when to keep his mouth shut or mind his own business.”

 

“Though, I’m not surprised, it’s disappointing to hear. Is there anything I can do to help? You know we’ll be working closely together over the next few months, I want to make sure any issues are dealt with head on and resolved quickly.” Herb stated plainly.

 

“You know I can’t stand that man.” Agatha grimaced.

 

“I do. I also know how effective this team can be when you two are able to cooperate with each other.” Herb admitted.

 

Agatha glared at him, unamused. “It’s fine, I’ve already handled it.” She reliped as she started to pick at her fingers anxiously.

 

“Good, that’s what I like to hear. Is that what you were planning to talk with me about or is there something else?” Herb asked as he moved around to sit behind his desk.

 

“No…I um…there is something else we need to discuss.” She admitted as her body tingled with nervous energy and her stomach launched into her throat.

 

“Talk to me, what’s going on?” Herb asked calmly.

 

“Well…” She laughed apprehensively “I have had some news recently, very recently.” She glanced down as a flutter hummed beneath her skin, as if aware of what she was about to reveal. 

 

“Oh, is it something serious?” he asked, eyebrows stitched with concern. 

 

“You could say that.” She nodded while fidgeting in her seat, trying to find the right way to say it. “It may…well, it will likely impact my participation in Mayfest to some extent this year.” Herb’s face fell as he grew more distressed. “It looks like I’ll be about 8 months pregnant by the beginning of May.”

 

Herb’s mouth gaped comically as his eyebrows raised further up his head, in shock, than she’d ever seen. “You’re pregnant?” He finally breathed, to which she nodded tentatively. Herb let out a surprised burst of laughter as a grin beamed across his face. “Seriously?” He asked, still stunned.

 

“Dead serious, unfortunately.” she cringed.

 

“I…wow…that’s…HA!...I wasn’t expecting that!” He admitted, still with a grin on his face.

 

Agatha let out a chuckle at that. “You and me both!” 

 

“Wow! I mean, congratulations! That’s fantastic news!” Herb gushed, clearly excited for her. “You…uh…yeah I can see that making things a little more difficult this year. Huh.”

 

She swallowed anxiously as she rushed to dissuade any concerns. “I, of course, am committed to doing all that I can, it’s just…I don’t know where I’m going to be at that point, with everything. Sharon is aware of the situation which is why I had her come today. She’s already agreed to help me manage my end, so between the two of us we should be able to handle what is required. I’m technically not due until June so I’m hoping not to be out until then. Though I do have a few appointments coming up. I’m already working to get everything organized in anticipation of my absence.” she rambled

 

Herb raised his hand, quieting her explanations, before he commented calmly, “I have no doubts in your ability to accomplish what I’ve asked. I have kids, three of them. I am well aware of the position this puts you in. I am more than willing to accommodate whatever it is that you need to be successful in this. If that’s more time, more people, flexible work hours, we’ll make it happen. Thanks to you we can afford to!”

 

She breathed a laugh of astonishment. She had expected Herb to be understanding, she had not expected him to bend over backwards to accommodate her. “Thank you Herb, I appreciate that.” was all she could manage to say as the relief of this support began to shift something inside her. 

 

“Make no mistake, I know who actually gets things done around here. Freddy and I have the vision and the passion but you make it happen. You find the resources and people. You construct the plan of action and keep everyone in line, and always manage to go above and beyond what’s expected. We’re lucky to have you.” Herb praised.

 

Agatha sucked her upper lip between her teeth as she felt herself collapse from within at the recognition. Receiving compliments had always been difficult for her, as it was not something she experienced often, and an urgent rush of fear sparked within her. She gritted her teeth together in an awkward smile and abruptly stood, needing to escape. “Alrighty then! Well, this has been fun. I hope you have a nice trip. I guess I’ll see you in three weeks!”  She hurriedly gathered her things and started to head out. 

 

“Agatha.” Herb called as she neared the door. “Congratulations. Take care of yourself, ok?” She nodded to him as she closed the door behind her. 

 

She sped down the hallway, back to her office, and collapsed on the small couch. Only then did she let herself breathe a sigh of relief. It had gone well, remarkably well. The people she had told, save for Freddy, were supportive and genuinely happy for her. Work had fallen into place, yet where she craved relief from the security this provided, her heart only found the aching sorrow and guilt she had buried since that morning. A few tears quickly developed into a waterfall as she finally let herself feel the emotions she had been holding in. The disappointment and guilt she had for herself, the gratitude she had for Jen, and Sharon and Herb, the fury she had for Freddy, and the crushing grief and anger and aching longing she still had for Rio. All rushing in at once, consuming every fiber of her being. Her form shuddered as she worked through each wave of emotion.

After a while the sobs began to subside, leaving a hiccuping echo of grief, and she could feel her body finally settle around her. As she lay still in the silence of her office a gentle flutter danced beneath her skin. The child she had always wanted, had hoped for, had begged for, had grieved over, reminding her once again of his miraculous presence. She looked down and carefully placed a hand above the spot she had felt the motion. She rested there for a moment before the flutter echoed beneath her palm. She let out a heavy sigh as a small smile cracked the corners of her lips. In the empty aftermath of her sorrow this little flicker of light shone through the darkness. The spark of hope she had come so close to giving up on. She let her head fall back onto the couch savoring this peace, cradling the strumming life inside her. 

Chapter End Notes

Next chapter is a Rio chapter and will feature Lilia so stay tuned!

Thank you for all your comments and kudos on the last chapter. It was my favorite to write so far.

Chapter 19: Twenty Six

Chapter Summary

Rio in the aftermath of telling Agatha she's pregnant.

Chapter Notes

Believe it or not I am still working on this! I may have to be up at an ungodly hour but I couldn't go another day without posting a chapter so here you go.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio took a hard swallow as she opened the door to the restaurant, after all she was there to see Agatha. As she stepped through the threshold the vastness of the hall nearly swallowed her whole. She did her best to wade through the seemingly endless crowd of people filling the dusky space. Her gaze searched, table after table, person after person until she spotted her. Agatha, seated against the back wall, clad in a flowing navy blue dress, glowing ethereally as if a halo of light surrounded her. Her piercing blue eyes calling to Rio across the rows of people between them. 

Rio lurched forward, heading directly toward her, though each step felt like moving through quicksand. As she drew closer Agatha’s crystal blue eyes grew ever more fierce, highlighted in a red tearyness, as if the wounds Rio had made were still fresh and raw. With each step closer she drew a new tear from Agatha’s eyes. Then, right when she was within striking distance of the table, Agatha rose, a storm of fury and grief, and moved to push past Rio, bumping into her along the way. 

Rio spun around just in time to spot her moving quickly through the crowd. She rushed to follow, back through the sea of people, barely catching sight of Agatha as she sped to the door. Just as she was about to escape, Rio managed to reach out, catching her wrist. Agatha looked back sharply, gaze full of fear, and anger, and sorrow. Rio cried out, “ Agatha, please wait!” Though the sound was muffled by the crowd. 

Agatha stared back at her, eyebrows stitched in confusion and pain but said nothing in response. Instead, she broke away from Rio’s grasp and rushed out the door and down the street. Rio felt a swell of pain and anguish and desperation as she pushed through the last of the crowd and out the door after Agatha.

In the empty silent darkness of the world outside she saw Agatha rush across the street at the end of the block. Rio bolted, hurrying to catch up to her but it was as if Agatha was twice as fast. Rio stopped at the stairs that met her on the other side of the street as she saw Agatha slip through the front doors of what appeared to be Music Hall. 

Rio hurried up the steps after her and through the massive doors where she was met with a swarm of people milling about in evening wear. Some dancing, some chatting, some eating and drinking merrily as classical music lilted in the air around them. She eased into the multitude, once again searching for a glimpse of Agatha. As Rio reached the center of the entryway she caught sight of her in the threshold of the back hallway, face stitched in pain as she gripped the corner of the wall, her other arm wrapped protectively around her stomach. Rio surged forward as a new rush of fear pricked at her heart. As she worked to get through the partying horde she watched Agatha stumble down the hallway in distress. Despite her urgency, as she reached the corridor, Agatha was nowhere in sight. She stood for a moment staring down the dark passage before her, lit only by a single bulb of light at the far end. An eerie stillness settled in the space before her as the hallway seemed to stretch further and further away. The noise of the event behind her blurred into nothingness as she strained to listen for any sound of the woman she was searching for. 

In the void a scream rang out, sharp, earth shattering. Rio sprinted down the hallway as wails continued to echo around her. Her legs moved as fast as they could but it still seemed like ages before she reached the end where she had to choose, left or right. She stood still, listening to the screams that had taken shape, calling out her name in desperation.

“ Rio! Rio, please! Please, help!”  

As she turned to the right towards the sound, a glow seemed to radiate from one of the doors down the dark hallway. She hurried forward to stand before the door, the cries growing ever more frantic as her hand shakily reached up to turn the knob. The handle clicked and she pushed the creaking door open to near silence.

There sprawled on the floor of an empty room was Agatha, sitting on her side with her knees curled around her, one hand splayed out on the floor in front of her, supporting her weight, the other wrapped around her swollen stomach. Her head had fallen forward as her body shook with sobs and labored breaths, her long hair draped down around her like a veil. Her dress was splayed out beneath her and appeared to be growing in size as Rio stepped forward into the room. 

“Agatha?” she called out, barely more than a whisper. Agatha didn’t say a word but all sounds she had been making immediately ceased. Rio continued to inch forward until her foot made contact with the hem of her dress. The sound it had made was wet and squelching. She glanced down to find instead of the dress, she was standing in an expanding pool of blood. In a rush of fear her gaze snapped back to lock with Agatha’s, her eyes now dark and sunken in, her skin pallid and waxy, making her blue irises ever more penetrating. With the last of the strength that she had, Agatha, through streaming bloody tears, begged, “ Rio, help me! ” before her body crumbled beneath her. 

 

Rio felt herself lurch forward as she screamed out “AGATHA!” her heart pounding in her chest. She looked into the darkness around her as sweat poured in cold droplets down her back. She shifted her legs under the covers to sit more comfortably as she dropped her head into her hands. She sat for a moment as she caught her breath, she couldn’t survive this much longer. It had been almost three weeks since the debacle in the Chili's parking lot and since then she had been plagued nightly by these worsening terrors.




In the beginning her dreams were brief, just flashes in the few hours that she could find rest. It being her week off she couldn’t help but anxiously wait for any news about Agatha that she doubted would ever come. She had no idea where they stood. She had technically broken up with her, though it was because she was trying to beat Rio to the punch, she doubted if anything that had followed changed that fact. It left her with a crippling sense of guilt and fear that caused her to seclude herself in her apartment, lying awake into the early hours of the morning torturing herself for the great mistakes she had made and the pain she had caused. Her days were plagued with the awareness of what she had lost. It was suffocating and sharp, as if a piece of her soul had been ripped away. She spoke to no one except for the food delivery person, even blowing off messages from Nat and Yelena asking her if she was doing alright or needed anything. Instead she taunted herself with memories of their time together, thoughts of the child she likely would never meet, and the life they would never share. 

 

The following week she had no choice but to gather herself enough to head back to work. Whenever she entered the hospital the smell of antiseptic and medical equipment helped ease her into a robotic numbness, going about her job devoid of emotion. Something she had honed in residency that made her the excellent surgeon she was, now her lifeline in the purgatory that had become her every day. Despite this rigid shell, fears continued to roam the corners of her mind, wondering how Agatha was, if she and the baby were alright. She hadn’t heard from Jen and didn’t dare reach out to Agatha in fear of causing more distress than she already had. At night she would return to her empty apartment, the quiet loneliness gnawing at her as she craved to reach out to her, but she knew she was in no place to sort through the mess between them. Repressing herself, though, had had terrible consequences as the dreams began to grow more intense and caused her to wake in the wee hours of the morning. 

 

She had hoped that once her week at work was over and she had time to settle and refocus that the dreams would ease, but no such luck. If anything the dreams grew more vivid and more intense with each passing night and her waking hours were a battle to distract herself from the ever consuming thoughts of Agatha. She couldn’t remember ever being this distressed in any of her previous break ups. Even when she had broken off her engagement the pain had started to subside after the first week. With Agatha, even weeks later, she was still experiencing deep waves of grief that would seem to hit her out of nowhere and nearly crumble her to the point of hopelessness. 




Now, it was Friday, she only had a few more days before she had to return to work again and she was reeling from the most horrific nightmare yet. As she sat there in the darkness her limbs tingled with the residual fear and panic of seeing Agatha’s limp, bloody form before her. As cold sweat streamed down her body she reached over to her nightstand and grabbed her phone to check the time. 

 

4:44

 

Later than she had been sleeping until but still horrendously early. With her heart still racing in her chest she knew, even if she tried, there was no way she would be able to fall back asleep. An ominous dread was settling in her body and would not let her rest further. She had been stuck with this worsening curse that was threatening to thrust her further into depression and now after nights of restless sleep she was starting to unravel at the seams. Why was her mind doing this? Why was she there every time she closed her eyes? Was it not enough to deal with the real pain of losing her?  She decided she needed to shake this panic loose from her body so she rolled out of bed, threw on a sweatshirt and sweatpants, and headed out for a run. 

 

It was almost too cold for how few layers she had on, but the bite of the winter air filling her lungs burned in a way that felt like it was scratching an itch she hadn’t been able to reach. The emotional pain she had been dragging around night after night, day after day was finally matched by the sharp burning in her chest with each labored breath. The tingling fear was quickly replaced by a stinging numbness in her extremities. She ran listlessly for miles until she could barely feel her feet hitting the pavement beneath her and frozen tears pricked her eyes. Eventually she began to slow, finally taking in the world around her, and was disappointed to find herself in the middle of the park she and Agatha would take walks in. In the stunned absurdity of it all she found a laugh bubbling out of her mouth. Of course, even in her mindless distraction she had managed to drive herself to the center of many cherished memories. It seemed no matter what she did she was destined to be haunted by Agatha’s presence. 

She padded over to a patch of frosty grass and let herself collapse onto the earth, her lungs aching for oxygen. As her body stilled her shuddered breath broke into pieces as delirious tears began to flow like a river down the sides of her face. Would she ever be free of this sorrow? She brought her hands down to press into her eyes as she let out a frustrated scream. She was at her wits end. She pounded her fists into the ground beside her as she forced herself to breathe in deeply. She had to figure out how to make it stop before it broke her completely.  

 

In the past, when her world had felt like it was crumbling, she would escape to Lilia’s for guidance and respite but she hadn’t spoken to the woman since that very night. After the hospital, after she had dragged Ralph through the store gathering everything she could think Agatha might need in a last stitch effort to mend what seemed almost too broken to repair, she had sat in her car in Agatha’s driveway as the reality of what had happened fully hit her. Despondent in her grief and anger she had gone over out of reflex and unloaded all her pain onto Lilia who just sat and listened and held her when the weight of it all became too much to bear. Since then she had done her best to avoid her, ignoring the occasional call or text. She couldn’t help but feel resentment towards the woman for being the catalyst for her turmoil and was struggling to find a way to forgive her, though now her heart ached for her comfort. Once this wave of pain had settled she wiped away the last of the tears and hauled herself up from the ground. She took a centering breath, doing her best to release the last of her anxieties, and began the long journey back to her apartment, contemplating how to get out of this slump. 

 

The sun was just starting to rise as she returned and she immediately headed inside and ran herself a scalding hot shower letting the steam seep into the aching pit inside her, soothing her frostbitten lungs. Once the water had drowned out the last of her worries she stepped out, wrapping herself in a plush towel and moved to look at herself in the mirror. After weeks of this anguish the image she was met with was a gaunt ghost of her former self. Eyes rimmed in dark circles, skin sallow and sickly, her collar bone protruding starkly from her chest. She had fallen further into despair than she had realized. She looked around, taking in the state of the bathroom. Towels strewn about, trash can full to the point of spilling over, clothes piled on nearly every surface but the sink. How had she let it get this bad? 

She wandered out into her bedroom which was in a similar state, books thrown about, take out boxes on the floor, more dirty laundry in heaps about the room, several glasses and mugs hovering on the nightstand and shelves. She dug about, eventually finding jeans and a sweater clean enough to throw on, before pushing through to the kitchen and living room to take stock. 

The coffee pot was half full though she hadn’t made any since her last day at work nearly five days ago, dishes were piled in the sink and about the counters, the fridge was empty save for 2 day old fries, a cup of coleslaw, and a series of condiments, take out bags were scattered about the living room, the couch was piled with a nest of blankets and pillows, and tissues clustered in the corners. Perhaps if she cleansed her space it could help relieve the clutter in her mind.  

She moved to pull the curtains open, letting the light of early morning break through the darkness she had secluded herself to. She grabbed her phone, hooking it up to her bluetooth speaker, and turned on a punk playlist as she began to reset the space. She moved about encouraging herself to dance and sing along to the music as she cleaned. A common remedy for the blues that she had picked up from Lilia. The act, though simple, did wonders to lift much of the sorrow that had settled in her body. With each space she resurrected a weight fell from her shoulders. 

As she wrapped up the main living space she checked the clock, nearly 2:00, and she hadn’t had a bite to eat. Her stomach protested as she considered ordering in again so she decided now was as good of a time as any to finally go to the grocery. She climbed through the mess that was her room to search for her keys and wallet, finding them somehow hiding in her underwear drawer. She glanced around again at the state of her room, really smelling the musk she had created, and decided to start a load of laundry on her way out. She gathered up the nearest pile of clothes and threw them in her rolling hamper and headed out the door to the elevator. As she pulled the basket in behind her she noticed a ribbon of fabric trailing behind her. She quickly gathered it up as the doors began to close. 

As she rode down she studied the fabric in her hand, silky, a dark purply blue with flashes of foliage. Her eyebrows scrunched as she searched her mind for the item this belonged to. She knew she recognized it but couldn’t quite place it. She brought the hand up to bite at her nails as she pondered and that’s when she smelled it, the faintest hint of lilac and honeysuckle. Agatha. She unraveled the item, letting the length drape off the sides of her hands as realization hit. The belt to Agatha’s robe? How had that managed to snake its way into her things? She must have had it since Boston! Naturally, not an item inconvenient enough to lose that you might reach out to your ex to get it back, but it was still her’s. As the elevator arrived in the basement she stuffed the item in her pocket, for whatever reason she couldn’t bring herself to wash it. She rushed down the hall, hurriedly threw her clothes in an open washer and headed back out, not wanting to ruminate on the discovery. 





As she pulled into the grocery store parking lot, the bright winter sun beaming down, she was starkly aware of how isolated she had been keeping herself. Seeing the few other people milling about, doing their weekly shopping, just another Friday, it felt as if she was about to step out onto another planet. She eased the car door open and forced herself out and into the store. 

 

The fluorescent lights flickered and hummed as canned oldies music crackled through the store speakers. The few people shopping and working were scattered about the store, each in their own little bubble. It was an eerie feeling, being around people somehow made her more aware of the loneliness that plagued her. She bit her lip in focus as she cycled through the produce, grabbing all of the staple items she could recall since she hadn’t bothered to write a list. 

She meandered down aisles, hobbling together the ideas of meals, when her attention was caught by the song ringing out from the speaker above her. Silky strings flowed like a river as Etta James' velvety voice crooned out At Last . She was immediately transported back to their karaoke night when she had sung that very song to Agatha. She had felt it in her bones as the words poured from her lips. Agatha had been the piece of her heart she hadn’t known was missing and now, without her, she was left with this gnawing emptiness. Her heart fluttered with longing and she could feel her throat catch as she swallowed back the tears that were pressing at her eyes. Though she could feel another wave of grief approaching she only had a few more items to get, she needed to hold it together and not come apart in this store. 

She quickly gathered the last of the things she could remember and headed to check out. She rolled up to the shortest line, finding a place behind a woman carrying a small infant. The child could only have been a few months old, and was transfixed by Rio as they gazed over their mother’s shoulder. With one hand in their mouth they gave her a toothless smile and began to kick their feet about happily. She chuckled softly at the attention and gave the child a small wave to which they replied with a series of squeals and coos gaining their mother’s attention. The woman looked at the child then back at Rio who had started making silly faces in response. She hurried to quiet her expressions and muttered a small apology. 

The woman smiled back, unbothered, commenting, “Oh honey, you’re fine! Thanks for keeping him entertained. Normally by now he’d be screaming his head off but he seems to be taken by you.”

“He’s pretty charming himself.” Rio offered with a half smile. The woman nuzzled her face into his plump baby cheek to which the child erupted in giggles as she started to unload her cart. 

 

Rio felt her eyes growing misty as she observed the pair. She wanted this, her heart ached for it, a child, a family, love - in all its challenges and triumphs. And in that, more than anything, she wanted Agatha. She wanted to see her, needed to see her, to hold her in her arms once again and remind her how much she truly loves her. She could feel the wounds she had stitched together that morning once again pulling at the seams. She unloaded her own cart as her mind traced over a life she desperately wanted but feared she had already lost. 

As she headed back to the car the weight of her longing grew heavier, nearly crushing her with grief. She hurried to put her groceries in her trunk before the wave of sorrow brought her to a halt. She had barely made it to the driver's seat before her vision was completely clouded by the waterfall of tears that had burst forth. She wanted more than anything to be able to move forward, past this unrelenting despondency, but it engulfed her mercilessly. 

She ached to reach out to Agatha but she knew that wasn’t wise in this disheveled state. Her next best instinct was to call someone, anyone, if for no other reason than to release some of the pain she was carrying. Her fingers navigated their way to calling Yelena, the first in her list of favorites. The phone rang out through the speakers a few times before clicking over to voicemail. She ended the call and immediately reached out to Nat, hoping she would be quick to answer. After the seventh ring she abandoned the call, dropping the phone in her lap as she collapsed forward onto the steering wheel. She sat there sobbing and alone as the grief overtook her, until she felt the buzzing of her phone in her lap. She sat up slowly and grabbed the phone to find Lilia was calling her. Her screen glowed with the photo of Lilia squeezing her as tightly as possible and planting a kiss on her cheek which drew her to answer. Despite her anger at the woman, despite the mess she had helped put her in, now more than ever she needed her.

 

“Lilia…” she croaked out as she wiped away the last of the tears. 

 

“Oh! Sweetheart! I wasn’t sure if you’d pick up. I’ve been thinking about you! Is everything alright?” Lilia’s voice cooed as she sensed the dismay on the other end of the phone.

 

Rio bit her lip, trying to stave back another wave of tears.“It’s…I’m…I don’t…”

 

“What is it, doll? What’s going on? Talk to me!” Lilia’s directness at last shook loose the truth of her fears.

 

“I…I can’t do it.” She choked out

 

“Can’t do what?”

 

“I can’t let go of her. She’s all I can think about. I feel lost without her. How am I supposed to keep living like this?” The tears rushed forward once again as the words spilled out of her mouth.

 

“Oh honey! Where are you?” Lilia asked as concern flooded her voice.

 

“I uh, I’m in my car at the grocery.” She managed to convey through streaming tears. 

 

“Did you just get there?” She asked, calm but direct.

 

“No, I just finished up and barely made it out to the car before…” she trailed off as her breath began to stutter. 

 

“Are you ok to drive?”

 

“Yeah, I just…I need to calm down.” she breathed shakily

 

“Yes, good, take some deep breaths. Are you heading home?”

 

“Uh huh.” She grunted through a shaky breath as the tears began to ease. 

 

“Alright…you ok if I meet you there?” Lilia asked cautiously

 

Rio bit her lip, weighing the anger she still harbored against the unrelenting agony, “Yes.” she finally relented.

 

“Ok, I’m on my way. Take your time, make sure you’re calm enough to drive and I’ll see you soon.” Rio could hear keys already moving in the background of the call.

 

“Yeah, see you in a bit.” She murmured then hung up the phone. She laid her head against the headrest as she refocused herself. She had been doing so well and in an instant it had all come crashing down once again. Once she felt the steadiness return to her hands she turned on her car and headed home. 






As she pulled into her apartment lot she caught sight of Lilia’s van taking up nearly two spaces at the end. She turned off her car and let out a heavy sigh before forcing herself out of the vehicle. Part of her was glad Lilia had come yet she still wrestled with a deep resentment for what she had done. Had it not been for her interference she likely wouldn’t have had to endure any of this, though now she would never know. Now the depth of her sorrow outweighed her stubbornness to keep everyone at a distance. She needed comfort and if that came in Lilia’s form then so be it. She moved to the trunk, and began grabbing what she could as Lilia made her way over to her. Lilia rubbed a soothing hand on her back, saying nothing as she helped her grab the last of her bags and followed Rio inside. 

 

Rio settled the bags on the counter and began to silently unpack everything. Lilia cautiously watched her as she did the same, waiting for Rio to start the conversation, not pushing, just allowing her to speak in her own time. She hummed a nameless, almost haunting tune, being sure to give Rio the space she needed to settle. As she was putting away the last items in the pantry she walked in on Rio wiping away a few stray tears. 

“Oh, Honey!” She exclaimed as she dropped the box of cereal she was holding and rushed to pull Rio into a hug. Rio stilted at first but quickly relaxed into the caring embrace, the pressure and warmth soothing her most tender parts. After a few moments Lilia released her and gathered Rio’s face in her hands. 

“Let’s make some tea and chat, yes? Tell me everything that’s been going on.” Rio nodded meekly at the invitation. “Go on, have a seat, I’ll get it set up. Just point me to where you keep your tea.” Lilia offered.

 

“I might be out, but if I have any it’s in the cabinet by the stove.” Rio grumbled as she headed out to sit at the kitchen island. 

 

“Might be out?! How could you be out of tea? Didn’t I teach you better than that!” Lilia chided teasingly as she searched the cabinets. Rio glared at her silently, she was not in the mood to entertain sarcasm. “Ah, well no matter, you know I always keep some in my bag.” Lilia shuffled over to her purse and pulled out three tins of loose leaf tea. “Green, black, or Oolong?” she offered. Rio quickly looked at the selection and placed her index finger on the green tea, sliding it over to Lilia. “Excellent choice, doll!” she praised as she tucked the other two away. “So where do you want to start? You want to tell me what got you so upset at the store?”

 

“Oh, I don’t know, could it be that my life feels meaningless now that I’ve lost the love of my life, no thanks to you.” Rio bit as she stared down at the counter.

 

“Dear, I am truly sorry for that. I know it doesn’t change anything but I sincerely apologize for my actions. They were completely inappropriate.”

 

“You think?” Rio chuckled sardonically

 

“It was a horribly misguided attempt to protect you, both of you, one that I deeply regret.” Lilia offered in earnest.

 

“Protect us? How in the hell was that supposed to protect us?” Rio snapped growing enraged

 

“Well by telling you I was hoping to avoid all of this but I should know better that some things are just unavoidable. Perhaps it’s part of the journey that you have some time apart to realize how much you actually need each other.” she explained cryptically.

 

“What the fuck are you talking about?” Rio spat as her patience began to wear thin.

 

“Dear, I could see this brewing under the surface since you brought her over for lunch! The connection you two have, the pregnancy, the impending strife and… other difficulties. You both seemed oblivious.” She explained matter of factly.

 

“We were.” Rio grunted through gritted teeth.

 

“Exactly, which is why I brought it to light. Things like this cannot live under the surface.” She warned, wagging her finger.

 

“But did you have to be the one to say something? You couldn’t just let it play out, let us discover in our own time, you had to get involved!?” Rio scolded

 

“It seemed like a time sensitive issue.” She reasoned.

 

“But it wasn’t your issue to resolve! That’s what you’re not getting! This was between us! What you did, was fucking psychotic and it ruined everything!” Rio shouted, unable to restrain herself further.

 

“I’ll admit I may have crossed a line with the pregnancy test, but would you have believed me otherwise?” Lilia asked

 

“I don’t know! Is that really what’s important here? Me believing you? Because now I don’t fucking trust you! Look at the position you put me in! Why didn’t you just go to her in the first place. Instead you burdened me with the responsibility of telling her!” Rio raged.

 

“You would have preferred I went up to your girlfriend and asked her about her pregnancy?” Lilia questioned, dumbfounded.

 

“No I would have preferred you not get involved at all!” Rio shouted with a sense of finality.

 

Lilia stood silently letting the weight of that truth settle. “You’re right.” She finally breathed, “I shouldn’t have gotten involved. It’s caused you more pain than I could have imagined and that was the last thing I ever wanted for you.” The kettle on the stove had started to scream and Lilia moved to finish making their tea. “If I could go back and change it I would, but I can’t, the next best thing I can do is be here for you, anytime you need me.” She said, placing the mug of tea in front of Rio. “Do you want to tell me what else has been going on, like what got you so upset at the store and in the pantry?”

 

Rio bit the inside of her cheek as she contemplated the contents of her mug. Lilia was right, she couldn’t change any of what happened, neither of them could. All she could do now is work through the aftermath of what was left. She let out a sigh as she resolved to explain. “It’s been weeks and I just can’t stop thinking about her. Nearly everything I do, everywhere I go, I’m reminded of her. I’ve never experienced anything like it. Even when I sleep I have these dreams, nightmares really, and I feel like I’m going crazy. I don’t know how much more I can take!” Rio’s voice faltered a bit as her nerves began to prickle with the dread she had woken up with.

 

Lilia’s face was stitched in concern. “Oh, sweetheart” she moved to gather Rio in a hug.  “Maybe your heart is trying to tell you something? Tell me about the dreams.” 

 

“They’re awful! I’m usually chasing her and she’s just out of reach. Half the time when I catch up with her she explodes with rage and tries to kill me.” She sat up straighter anxiously, looking Lilia in the eyes, “The other half of the time…somethings wrong, she’s in pain but I can’t help her. The one last night was…gruesome. I thought I’d lost her completely.” Rio felt a shiver run down her spine as the image of Agatha’s lifeless body flashed in her mind. 

 

Lilia bit her lip as a sense of foreboding pricked within her. “Have you two had a chance to talk?” She asked, brushing a piece of hair behind Rio’s ear.

 

“No.” Rio muttered as she looked down despondent into her mug.

 

“Have you tried to reach out to her?” Lilia asked cautiously

 

“Something tells me that wouldn’t be welcomed.” Rio grumbled as she took a sip of her tea.

 

“You don’t know that!” Lilia offered reassuringly.

 

“She broke up with me! She pushed me away, refused to see me! I reached out to her friend after a week and heard nothing. I’m just trying to take the hint.”

 

“I’m sure I’m the last person you want advice from right now…” Lilia started

 

“You’d be right.” Rio bit back

 

“But reaching out, letting her know you’re thinking about her and how you’re feeling might be what’s needed to resolve some of this distress you’re feeling.”

 

“I know, I just don’t want to cause any more damage than I already have.” Rio groaned

 

“What damage? Showing her you still care? Worst thing that can happen is you don’t hear back, but at least you know you’ve laid all your cards on the table. Best case scenario you get to talk with her and have some sort of resolution one way or another.” 

 

Rio mulled over Lilia’s advice as she swirled her tea. “I can’t say it hasn’t crossed my mind. It’s just every time I think about it I’m reminded of just how terribly it all went that night and I don’t know if I can survive another disaster like that. I mean look at me now I’m barely holding on by a thread, I look like I’m half dead.” 

 

“You look like you’re exhausted, like you’ve been carrying this alone for too long.” Lilia offered gently

 

“Maybe I have, but it’s my burden to carry.” Rio reasoned

 

“Ah!” Lilia sighed knowingly. “Could that be what’s holding you back? You feel like you deserve this pain as punishment?”

 

Rio blinked back stunned at the insight. “Don’t I?”

 

“No, sweetheart.” Lilia cooed as she took Rio’s face into her warm hands. “You’ve punished yourself enough for this mistake. It’s time to let go so you can move forward.”

 

“How can I? It was a disaster, I ruined everything.” Rio cried frustratedly

 

“A disaster it may have been but you have to find a way to forgive yourself for what happened.” Lilia’s words hung in the air between them, breaking something loose within her.

 

Rio pressed her eyes closed as tears leaked from the corners and she turned her head away from Lilia’s grasp. “I don’t know how to do that.”

 

“Start with a deep breath.” She held onto Rio’s shoulders as they breathed together. “You can’t change what has already happened…” she said blankly as she stared into Rio’s eyes. “but you are still able to shape what lies ahead. Your heart already knows what it wants, you just have to find the courage within yourself to go after it, even if it’s messy and painful.”  

 

Rio bit her lip before taking a sip of her tea. “Perhaps you’re right.” she muttered reluctantly.

 

“I’m sorry, dear, what was that?” Lilia asked

 

“Perhaps you’re right!” She shouted back at her. “I’ll… give it some thought.”

 

“That’s all I ask.” She leaned in, pressing a kiss to Rio’s forehead then holding her face between her hands. “I hate to see you this way dear, and I deeply regret all that I did to put you here. I just want to see you happy again, and Agatha, she makes you happy. If there’s anything else I can do to help…” 

 

“NO!” Rio shouted, a little louder than she meant to. “You’ve…you’ve already done so much and actually I still have to tackle a shit load of laundry.” She admitted, hinting to Lilia that she had tired of their grief session. “But I promise I’ll let you know how I’m doing and what’s going on.”

 

“I appreciate that! Please take care of yourself and have some ice-cream before bed, it should help a bit with the night terrors.” She wrapped her arms around Rio, squeezing her tightly in a hug. “I love you so much dear! Call me on Sunday, we’ll have lunch!” she said as she gathered her things.

 

Rio grumbled, “Love you too” as she waved Lilia out the door. 





As soon as Lilia was out the door Rio headed to her bedroom and gathered up another pile of laundry in a bag to take down and wash. She mulled over their conversation as she switched over the load. Maybe she was the one holding herself back. It’s not like Agatha would be the one to reach out, she had enough going on. If this is something she wanted, as desperately as she knew she did, she would have to swallow her pride and make the first move, even if it ended in the rejection she had been so desperately trying to avoid. 

She washed and sorted and folded load after load of laundry as she began to plan out reaching out to Agatha. Should she text her? That felt too informal, and especially after how long it had been, rather insincere. She thought about calling her or sending a voice message but worried she would stumble over her words or say the wrong thing in the moment. Just showing up was out of the question, she knew catching her off guard in person would only end in disaster and she didn’t think she would be able to handle the pressure. The safest option would be to send her a letter. Old fashioned as it was, it would give her the opportunity to plan out exactly what she wanted to say and give Agatha space and time to react, which could only work in her favor. 

Having folded the last of the laundry she reached for her phone to check the time. 7:30, and she had two missed calls from Yelena. She tapped the notification returning the call. The phone rang twice before Yelena’s voice burst through the phone.

 

“ Holy shit! She lives! Vidal, where are you? ”

 

“I’m at my apartment, where are you?” she chuckled back at the unexpected question.

 

“ Is it that one in the school? ”

 

“Yes…? Why?” Rio asked, growing suspicious as she could hear another voice mumbling in the background.

 

“ Is that on Sycamore or Main? ”

 

“Yelena, where are you? Who are you with?” She asked as an amused smirk pulled at her lips.

 

“ I’m driving around with Nat.” she snorted as Nat shouted expletives in the background. “We’re having trouble finding your apartment. ”

 

“What do you mean? Don’t tell me you two drove all the way out here!” She exclaimed in disbelief.

 

“ Dude! We haven’t heard from you in weeks! You dropped that pregnant girlfriend bombshell when you visited and then fucking ghosted us! Honestly this is an overdue wellness check. ”

 

Rio chuckled in astonishment. “I’ll text you the address. Park anywhere in the faculty parking lot at the front, I’ll meet you out there.”

 

“ Hell yeah! See you soon! ” Yelena cheered as she hung up the call. 

 

Rio stared at her phone for a moment processing what was happening. Her friends drove four fucking hours to visit her. Until hearing Yelena’s voice on the phone she hadn’t realized how badly she needed their intervention. She hurriedly texted her the address and rushed to put away the last of her laundry before heading down to meet them. As she opened the front doors she could see their headlights pulling into the lot. Yelena leaned out the passenger side window waving to Rio as she called out, “We were like only two streets away but somebody kept taking the wrong turn!” She looked down into the car at Nat as the vehicle rolled to a stop in one of the parking spaces. Immediately she sat back down to throw the car door open and rushed to tackle Rio in a hug.

 

“How are you guys here right now?” Rio managed to cough out once Yelena released her. 

 

“It was Yelena’s idea. She said if we didn’t hear from you by this morning we were heading out. We’ve both been worried about you, with everything going on. How are you holding up?” Nat asked, as she locked the car behind her. 

 

“I’ve been better.” she grunted

 

“No shit! I don’t think I’ve seen you look this miserable since residency!” Yelena laughed

 

“I don’t think I’ve been this miserable since residency!” she chuckled back

 

“That bad huh?” Nat asked

 

“You have no idea!” Rio groaned as she rubbed her temples at the thought.

 

“Then you’ll just have to tell us all about it! Have you eaten anything?” Yelena asked excitedly

 

“No, hadn’t even thought about it yet.” she admitted.

 

“Sweet, we almost stopped like an hour out but we decided to wait and see if you’d like to join us. Figured you could probably use a night out.” Yelena explained.

 

“Honestly, that sounds amazing.” She breathed, as a glimmer of relief bloomed in her chest. “Let me go grab a jacket and my bag and we’ll head out. I know a great wing place!” she shouted as she headed for the doors.

 

“Ugh! Wings sound amazing right now!” She heard Yelena groan as she hurried back into her apartment. She quickly threw on a pair of sneakers, grabbed her bag, and hunted around for her leather jacket. With everything clean and put away she figured it would be where she always kept it, carefully hung in her closet, but it was nowhere to be found. After a few minutes she gave up the search and settled on her oversized black corduroy jacket and headed down to her friends. 

 

“Finally! Let’s go! If I don’t have wings and fries in my face in the next 30 minutes I might pass away!” Yelena roared as she settled into the back seat. 

 

“You ok to drive since you probably know where we’re going?” Nat asked

 

“Yeah that’s fine, it’s not far anyway.” Nat tossed her the keys and she quickly settled into the driver's seat. As they pulled away from the curb Nat turned on an obscure playlist and Yelena babbled about their journey to her. It felt like home, safety, and for the first time in weeks she could feel herself starting to relax. 



Within the hour they were seated and digging into a feast of wings and appetizers as Rio regaled them on the calamity that had ensued. How Agatha had shown up when she was talking with her friends and broken things off. How she had chased her and blurted out that Agatha was pregnant in a desperate attempt to save their relationship by finally telling her the truth, the whole of it. Agatha’s initial disbelief and the work her friends did to help convince her which eventually sent her into a panicking spiral that had her running across the parking lot until she stopped to spew the contents of her stomach on the Chili’s sign. How she had pushed her back in disgust before they all headed to the hospital and confirmed what Rio had known for weeks at that point. How Ralph, her very gay best friend, was technically the father. 

 

As she painted the picture for them she found herself more than once laughing at the absurdity of the situation. She sat back, amused when their jaws dropped in astonishment or their eyes flashed in shock at each new piece of information she revealed. They let her work her way through the entire series of events, barely touching their food as they were too engrossed in her story. Once Rio finished, Nat and Yelena stared at her blankly working to wrap their heads around all she had explained. 

 

“You two are awfully quiet.” Rio smirked as she stole one of Nat’s fries. 

 

“I…I just…I guess…where are you at with all of this?” Yelena asked earnestly.

 

 “I wish I could say I was over it, that it was just another fling like all the others and I’m moving on but…I’ve never felt this way about someone before. We’ve had some space and it’s only made me want her more. Everything reminds me of her, it’s like she’s haunting me or something. I’ve been hesitant about reaching out, I don’t really know where we stand and I don’t want to cause any more damage than I already have but, I think I’m at a point now where I have to at least see if there’s any chance for us to fix this, for my own peace of mind if nothing else.”

 

“Wow, I never thought Rio Vidal would ever be this pussy whipped.” Nat chuckled teasingly

 

“Shut the fuck up!” Rio groaned as she threw a crumpled napkin in her direction.

 

“Seriously though, the fact that you’re still this infatuated with the woman after everything ? It’s either destiny or delusion! Regardless, we're here for you, any way we can be.” 

 

“Thanks.” She mumbled through a half smile “Just the fact that you guys came means everything. You have no idea how badly I needed this, just needed a break from it, from myself! This is the first time I haven’t felt depressed as shit since this happened.” 

 

“Well, then I guess I’m glad we made the trip!” Yelena gleamed as she stood from the table. “I’m gonna run to the restroom, I’ll be back.” 

 

They sat in silence for a moment as Nat finished her food before Rio asked, “Am I crazy? For wanting to do this?”

 

“Most definitely but, if it’s what you want,” She shrugged, “You’ve gotta go for it.”

 

“You think so?” she asked as she bit her lip.

 

“You’re going to regret it more if you don’t.” Nat warned as she ate the last of her wings.

 

Rio fidgeted with her fingers as she wrestled with the doubt that had been plaguing her. “What if…what if she doesn’t want to talk?”

 

Nat breathed a sigh of understanding, “She may not! Though, I’d be surprised if she didn’t also have some unresolved feelings about how things ended up. All you can do is tell her how you feel and give her the space and opportunity to talk if or when she feels comfortable doing so.”

 

Rio sat back in awe of the simple practicality of Nat’s advice. “Damn, why do I feel therapized by that?”

 

Nat chuckled, “My therapist said the same thing about reconnecting with my half-sister.”

 

“Oh yeah, how’s that going?” Rio asked excitedly

 

“Really well actually! She’s coming to stay with me next month, I’m going to show her the city and I’m going to visit her in the fall at her ranch.”

 

“Oh that’s amazing! I’m so happy for you both!” Rio beamed

 

“Thanks! It’s been a long time coming but I’m glad we’re finally making the effort to see each other.” 

 

“Alright, so I’ve been thinking…” Yelena said as she returned to the table.

 

“Uh-oh, that’s never a good sign.” Nat groaned

 

“I’ve been thinking…we should go out tonight.” She smiled with a wicked gleam in her eye

 

“We are out.” Rio replied flatly

 

“No, I mean out out. You need to blow off some steam and take a break from thinking about this clusterfuck you’ve found yourself in.” She said, pointing to Rio. “You just survived a week in hell with Dr. Dickhead and I know you need a drink.” She pointed at Nat “And I want to go to this drag show.” She pulled up a picture of a flyer that had been hanging in the bathroom stall. 

 

“Tonight?!” Rio asked trepidatiously 

 

“Yes tonight! It starts at ten, I looked it up, if we leave now we’d get there about when it starts.”

 

“I don’t know, what are you thinking Nat?” Rio asked, not entirely convinced.

 

“Completely up to you, I’m fine either way.”

 

“Come on! We’re only here for the weekend! When is the last time we’ve gotten to do something like this together?” Yelena pleaded

 

“Fine, just let me pay the bill.” Rio relented

 

“I already took care of it!” Yelena cheered gleefully “Come on, I want to make sure we get there before it’s standing room only!” 

 

Rio and Nat chuckled as they followed Yelena out of the restaurant and all piled into the car. Yelena insisted she drive since she already had the address up on her phone so Nat reluctantly squeezed into the back seat as Rio settled into shotgun. Having sifted through the mayhem of her life the conversation quickly settled into their usual banter. Yelena divulged the work gossip as she filled Rio in on what had happened since she left and Nat interspersed her commentary as she saw fit. Rio hummed along, half listening as she watched the world go by out the passenger window. She let herself revel in the comfort of it, the familiar cadences soothing the raw edges of her grief. That was until they pulled up to their destination. 

 

As Yelena parked and she and Nat exited the vehicle, Rio sat eyes wide with dread, it was Alice’s bar. The bar where Agatha had run into her with the door. Where she had sat across the runway mesmerized by her presence. Where she had struggled to work up the courage to ask her to dance, and somehow she had agreed, and though it was brief it had been the best night of her life. Of course, of the several gay bars in this city, it had to be this one. 

 

“Are you coming?” Yelena called to her through the window. 

 

She took a deep breath. It’s not like Agatha would be there, she didn’t really go out before and now it was even less likely. Though that didn’t mean she couldn’t end up running into one of her friends, it was Alice’s bar after all. The idea of seeing one of them was simultaneously terrifying and thrilling. She opened the door and slowly joined her friends, deciding to keep this nugget of information to herself, at least for now, not wanting to get ahead of herself. 

 

“You good?” Nat asked as they joined the end of the short line

 

“Yeah, fine, just a little tired.” Rio claimed

 

“OOO we should get some espresso martinis when we get in there.” 

 

“Though that sounds delicious I think I’m going to struggle through it. If I drink coffee now I’m never going to get to sleep! Besides, one of us should plan to drive home.” Rio reasoned

 

“You sure? I don’t want you to miss out on the fun!” Yelena asked

 

“Yeah, I’ll have a good time regardless.” She replied, partially as encouragement to herself. 

 

As they approached the door she could feel a nervous pit swell in her throat. This was the moment of truth. Part of her hoped at least one of them was there. Maybe she would have a chance to ask them how Agatha was. Another part was gripped with fear at possibly being spotted and not welcomed. She didn’t want to cause any more drama. Her mind did its best to quiet these voices, reasoning it was more likely that none of them were there and she could just enjoy a night with her friends. Though as she finally stepped through the doors and her eyes scanned the crowd her heart dropped and a cold chill ran down her spine. Fate couldn’t help but be cruel. There sat at a table against the far wall, clad in a dark flowing dress, her long hair cascading down her shoulders as the neon glow of the stage lights illuminated her in an ethereal radiance, was Agatha.

Chapter End Notes

To all of you still following along at this point - thank you from the bottom of my heart. I'm gonna do my best to get the next bit out a bit sooner. We'll see how that goes!

Chapter 20: Kismet

Chapter Summary

Fate has drawn them together once again, will it mend their relationship?

Chapter Notes

I'm just glad this didn't take me 3 weeks to publish. Enjoy

See the end of the chapter for more notes

In the weeks that followed Agatha struggled to adjust to the demands of her new life. Work was practically drowning her. Not only did she have the tasks Herb had assigned to her, reviewing the companies he had selected to help manage operations and interviewing and organizing vendors for each of the four weekends, she had managed to absorb Freddy’s responsibilities as well, at least for the time being. After his meeting with HR that following monday he was put on administrative leave as they investigated his questionable conduct. This meant that every minute of her day was now booked solid. From the time she arrived until Sharon would force her to leave, she was in meetings, on calls, or holding interviews. It was beyond more than what she had bargained for and after three weeks she was looking forward to Herb's imminent return.

 

When she wasn’t working she was doing her best to come to terms with a body that still felt foreign as it continued to make room for the child growing quickly inside of her. It was as if it had been withholding this secret, waiting to reveal all once he had been discovered. In just these few weeks her son truly began to make his presence known, kicking, nudging, and squirming, expanding her from within to the point that more than once she dissolved into a teary rage trying to find clothes that still fit. The shock of it all had pressed into wounds she hadn’t realized were still tender. After all this time it brought up fears and worries that she had kept buried deep, hidden even from herself. What if she couldn’t do it? What if her body couldn’t do it and failed her again? If something were to happen to her, what would happen to the baby? She found that, despite the abundance of support around her, she still felt overwhelmingly alone and vulnerable. 

With Sharon’s help she somehow made time for follow up visits with Dr. Allen who reaffirmed that all was well and relatively healthy for both of them. Jen, despite her demanding schedule, made herself readily available for all of Agatha’s concerns and questions whenever they arose. Ralph, true to his word, took over much of the housework. Many mornings he would wake up and make breakfast for them then spend his days organizing, cleaning, and removing most of his things from her house. He made time to take her shopping for a new wardrobe that actually fit. He even managed to rope Alice into helping him paint the room the particular shade of sage green that she had mentioned the night she came home from the hospital. It was all a relief and a much needed buoy in the storm surge that was her life, yet there was still an unrelenting ache that she couldn’t seem to shake. 

 

Despite the pain she had caused her, Rio was an ever present thought hovering at the back of her mind. In the beginning these thoughts brought a rush of panic and anger to the surface. She felt betrayed, lied to, humiliated in front of everyone! She had opened her heart enough to let herself love again and had let herself believe that Rio truly loved her. That the bond they had quickly created was deep and unwavering, but after this… How could she trust her? 

Over time, as the fear and anger began to release her from their grip, a sense of conflicting guilt crept in overtaking their place. This child, though a life shattering shock, was everything she had ever wanted. She barely knew him and already he had completely stolen her heart. She was grateful for every step that had brought him to her and yet she was devastated that he had come along when he did. It had cost her everything. The joy and love and safety she had found in Rio vanished. Yet now, as she faced the second half of her surprise pregnancy along with an overly demanding work life, she needed Rio’s comfort and stability more than ever. 

As the weeks wore on and she heard nothing from Rio, she felt a bitter disappointment begin to take root. For all she had professed in her soliloquy about the love she had for her, this silence felt like a dagger to her heart. She had prepared herself for this eventuality, after all why would Rio want to stick around? Yet as it sunk in that they may indeed be over, it stung sharper than she had expected. Had it all been a lie? Had she moved on, not wanting to deal with the mess that had become her life? Could she really blame her if she had? After all, when it came down to it, she was the one who ultimately put them in this position. 

She dissected things over and over with Ralph, the qualms and grief she still held, yet each time he suggested she be the one to reach out and talk things over with Rio she dismissed him claiming she didn’t have the time to deal with it on top of everything else. Perhaps after everything settles , she would tell him then hurriedly change the subject, not wanting to commit to when that might be. She held on to so many questions that were still left unanswered but for now she let the idea simmer in the back of her mind like a pot hovering on the stove, unsure of when it would boil over. 

 

As the third week drew to a close she resigned herself to the fact that, though it had seemed like fate at the start, she and Rio were likely too broken to repair. She had to move on, focus on her impending single motherhood, and push through these hectic months until he arrived. Herb would be back the following Monday and she had managed, with Sharon’s help, to accomplish nearly all the tasks he had set forth, including Freddy’s responsibilities. She would be able to hand back a good portion of the work and settle into a steadier routine. 

 

Though, just as Herb was set to return, she was also going to lose Ralph to his next cruise contract. She had come to depend on him, to an extent, filling in the gaps she was losing to her overly demanding work life. But as the week turned it would all be gone. She would be back to her regular schedule, coming home to a silent house. The impending void brought renewed fears of doubt and uncertainty. How could she possibly survive this alone? She wasn’t yet sure but for now could only take it one day at a time.

 

—-------------------------------------------------------------

 

As Friday rolled around she felt a mixture of relief and anxiety. She had survived the trial of managing everything Herb had set yet she was another day closer to solitude. The day went by in a blur. She had a few final meetings in the morning, a quick lunch as she caught up on emails and meeting requests, and rounded out the day organizing contracts and documents to present to Herb on Monday. She was in the home stretch, packing up her things when her phone rang with an unexpected call from her lawyer. Her heart skipped a beat as she answered. 

 

“Valentina! I’m surprised to hear from you, you usually just email me.” She greeted, doing her best to sound nonchalant.

 

“Agatha! Hey, yeah, I thought this might be better to talk over the phone.” Valentina was a sharp and direct woman. This was a boon when it came to handling legal matters but tended to make difficult conversations sting in their bluntness. At her tone Agatha prepared for the worst.

 

“Everything alright?” She asked as her nerves pricked in anticipation.

 

“It’s your mother. She’s appealed the temporary restraining order and it was granted to her so it’s no longer in effect.” She stated casually as if reading an item off of a list, though the words landed like blows.

 

Agatha’s stomach dropped. Evanora couldn’t possibly consider visiting her after everything that happened in Boston. “Oh.” she breathed through the lump in her throat.

 

“And I wish I could say that was the worst of it but she’s suing you for ownership of the house.” Another direct hit, one that nearly knocked Agatha off her feet. 

 

“What?! Can she do that?” She gasped in shock.

 

“She can try. She’s claiming to have found an amended will leaving her the estate.”

 

“That doesn’t make any sense! She was the one who reached out to me about the will in the first place!” Agatha cried in frustration

 

“I’m inclined to believe this holds no water, authenticity remains to be seen, but regardless this will likely end up before a judge at some point.” Valentina wasn’t holding any punches.

 

“Fuck.” Agatha breathed exasperatedly as her hand braced her forehead.

 

“This also means you won’t be able to sell the house until this issue is resolved.” At this point Valentina had her on the ropes. 

 

“You’re kidding me?!” She screeched into the phone.

 

“Believe me, I wish I was. Look, they're going to try and drag this out, I’m opting to handle it sooner rather than later but I need your input and availability.” Finally a breath in the onslaught of devastating news.

 

“I mean… yes! I don’t want to be sitting on this house forever, let alone deal with her longer than I have to. When do you think we can get before a judge?”

 

“I’m hoping to work something out for early to mid April. Would that work for you?”

 

“If we can get this dismissed I’ll make it work.” Agatha agreed.

 

“That’s kind of what I figured. I’ll go ahead and submit the paperwork and get back to you when I have a date.”

 

“Sounds like a plan. Thanks Val!” Agatha groaned as she hung up the phone. This was the last thing she wanted to have to deal with. 



—---------------------------------------------------

 

As she stumbled through her front door, furious about the call from her lawyer and exhausted at having survived the last week, she threw her things to the side and flung herself down onto the couch with a grunt.

 

“Tough day at the office mama?” Ralph called from the kitchen as he rifled through the pantry. 

 

“The day was tolerable up until the end.” she sighed

 

“Uh-oh, what happened? Did they let Freddy back in the office?”

 

“Gods no! I’m pretty sure they’re just waiting for Herb to get back to officially fire him.” She huffed in amusement. “No, I got a call from my lawyer.”

 

“Ugh, that’s never a good thing. What did she have to say?” 

 

“That my mother is suing me for the house.” She groaned

 

“She what?!” Ralph shouted as he slammed the pantry door closed.

 

“Yeah and I have to go to court if I want to get it dismissed.” she added, frustratedly

 

“Fuck, when is that happening?”

 

“Don’t know yet, Val said early to mid April.” 

 

“Shit! Does this mean you’d have to see your mother?” He asked tentatively

 

“More than likely yes, particularly since she also got the restraining order dismissed.” she added

 

“Damn you cannot catch a break with that woman!” He sighed as he sat in the armchair across from her. He looked her over for a moment before asking, “Do you think she knows?”

 

“Knows about what?” Agatha asked, confused.

 

“What do you mean knows about what ? The pregnancy obviously! She always seems to keep tabs on you one way or another!” He reasoned

“Oh fuck!” She groaned as she pressed her hands into her face.

 

“Did you seriously not think about that?” He chuckled

 

“No! It wasn’t top of mind when she told me I was being sued! Hell, I don’t know! I’m sure she’s just doing this to get back at me for what happened in Boston.” 

 

“What do you think she’s going to do when she finds out?” He asked, looking nervous.

 

“Who fucking knows! It’s not something I have the time or energy to worry about now. I just want to take a bath, eat an ungodly amount of pizza and go to bed.” she sighed

 

“So… are you not going to Jen’s birthday thing tonight then?” He asked judgingly.

 

“What? No, isn’t that tomorrow?” She asked as her eyebrows twitched in confusion.

 

“No mama, it’s tonight! Friday! It’s also my last show before my contract, remember?”

 

She let out a pitiful whine. “Really? You two couldn’t have planned this for tomorrow and given me a day to rest at least?” 

 

“Sorry girl! You know how Jen is, this has been planned for months, before we knew about your little spawn. I’m sure she’d forgive you if you decided to stay home, all things considered.” He shrugged

 

“Are you joking?! She didn’t talk to me for a week after I didn’t wish her a happy nurse’s day and that’s not even a real day. If I missed her birthday she’d probably tell them I don’t want an epidural out of spite.” she scoffed.

 

“Well they won’t be here until 7 to go to dinner so you have some time.” 

 

She looked at her phone, it was just after six. “Hardly! Don’t bother me until they get here.” She groused as she rolled into the couch, settling in for a nap. 

 

“Fine by me! I’ve gotta go get ready anyway.” He rose and headed down the hallway to the bathroom.

 

As she curled in on herself scratchy hopped up to settle into the nest of space between her and the back of the couch. Satisfied with his position he nuzzled close and began to purr contentedly. She quickly began to slip into the twilight of near slumber but before she could tip over the edge she felt an insistent nudge just below her ribs. He’d been rather calm all day, but now as she was trying to rest her son had decided to stir. She pressed a hand to the spot, hoping to soothe him into rest, instead he pressed further outwards before shifting higher. Scratchy turned his head now looking at her stomach where he could sense a disturbance to his rest and purred heavily as he sniffed about. Seemingly in response her son rolled again within her. She let out a defeated groan before shooing Scratchy off the couch. She rested her hand on the crest of her stomach and rubbed slow circles with her thumb. 

 

“Come on kid, just give me 10 minutes, then you can party all you want.” she begged. There were a few more nudges until he finally settled again and she drifted off to sleep. 





Before she knew it she was being shaken awake by Ralph, now dressed as Lady Bohner in a sequined jumpsuit and a choppy, long blond wig. 

 

“Jen?” She croaked groggily as she blinked herself awake. 

 

“She wishes!” Ralph laughed

 

“Are they here?” She asked as she looked around seeing no one else. 

 

“No, we had a change of plans. She and Alice went ahead to dinner, I told them we’d meet up at the bar.” he explained.

 

“Oh. What time is it?” She asked as she searched around for her phone.

 

“Like 9:15? You were dead asleep, I tried to wake you earlier but you wouldn’t budge. We’ll leave in about 15 minutes. Come, have some pizza first.” He said with a smirk.

 

“You ordered pizza?” She asked, her voice breaking in relief as she peeled herself away from the couch. 

 

“Oh absolutely! You mentioned pizza earlier and I couldn’t stop thinking about it. I got it from that one place you like that does the little squares. You two have your own veggie so eat as much as you want.” He offered as he slid the box towards her. 

 

She opened the lid and nearly cried at the sight, it was exactly what she had been craving. She picked up a slice, took a bite, and melted onto the stool at the island as a tear streaked down her cheek. After the day she had this pizza was stitching her back together piece by piece. “What the hell am I going to do when you’re gone?” She asked through a mouthful of sauce and dough. 

 

“Either make Jen’s life a living hell or,” He smirked at her with a glint in his eye, “if you get desperate enough, finally reach out to Rio.” He laughed, taunting her.

 

She glared at him in annoyance. “Are we really going to have this conversation again?” 

 

“Agatha, come on! You like to pretend that you’re over it but I know you still think about her. Why not at least shoot her a text or something. See where she’s at?”

 

“I don’t understand why I should be the one to reach out!” she exclaimed, bracing a hand to her chest. “I’m not the one who was keeping secrets from her! If she was so sorry and felt so bad about what happened then perhaps I should have gotten an apology by now, but no!” She snapped before taking a bite. “Besides, I’m sure she’s moved on at this point anyway and I see no reason to open that door.” she mumbled with her mouth full.

 

“Well, technically, you were keeping a secret, it was just secret from the both of you.” He corrected. “I guarantee you that girl has been beating herself up about this since that night. You should have seen her on the ride home, she was distraught! Also, you were the one who broke up with her, aggressively I might add! For all she knows you’d kill her the next time you saw her. So, if anything, she’s probably just as scared as you are to hash this out.” he groaned frustratedly

 

“I’m not scared!” she growled at him.

 

“Could have fooled me!” He chuckled 

 

“Why are you defending her anyway? Aren’t you supposed to be my friend?” She snapped at him

 

“I am your friend which is why I’m telling you you’re being a stubborn bitch about this!” He sassed. “After all you put her through you could at least give her the opportunity to explain herself. I’m not saying you two have to get back together, but I’d hate to see you lose out on someone I know makes you happy.” He insisted

 

“You’ve been hanging out with Alice too much.” She grumbled as she finished her pizza. “Come on, we better go before you’re late.” 

 

“Fine, we can drop it for now, just please think about it, for mine and Jen’s sanity if nothing else.” 

 

“I’ll consider thinking about reaching out to her, see if she’d be willing to talk. No promises!” She said, grabbing her keys.

 

“Oh do the bare minimum, why don’t you!” He groaned as he followed her out the door.

 

—————————————————



Rio stood frozen in the entryway as her friends worked their way through the crowd searching for a seat. They hadn’t seen Agatha and knew nothing about the hurricane of panic building inside Rio. Seeing her now, enveloped in a halo of light, her navy dress flowing gracefully around her, Rio thought she was caught back in the nightmare she had woken up to that morning.
