She could feel her heart begin to flutter, not in fear, not in worry, but in gleeful anticipation at seeing her son.

 

Lost in Rio’s gaze and caring touch, she’d hardly noticed Dr. Allen had started until Rio’s eyes darted past her. Illuminated by the glowing light of the screen she could see Rio’s face shift from adoration to awe at the sight before her. 

 

“There he is!” it was spoken like she had discovered a holy relic, with reverence and wonder as she lifted her head to get a better view. 

 

Agatha broke her gaze and turned to see the miracle that was her son. His little profile was on full display giving view to the tiniest button nose above what was unmistakably Agatha’s puckered lips. His precious hand hovered by his chin as it opened and closed, almost as if he was waving at them. Then, at last, the strong whooshing sound of his heartbeat rang out into the room. 

 

“Look at him! He’s perfect!” Rio breathed shakily, unable to contain her veneration.

She was biting at her lip in a weakening attempt to hold herself together and as she glanced back down at Agatha her composure broke as an incredulous chuckle burst forth. Rio leaned forward and pressed a kiss to Agatha’s cheek, which was now drenched in her own tears, before pulling away to grab them both tissues. 

 

“I will say, everything seems to be progressing nicely. He’s measuring to be right where we want him as we enter into the third trimester. Strong heartbeat, lots of movement and overall seems happy and content. Let me just grab a few shots here while he’s cooperating for us…” Dr. Allen clicked about for a few more moments before turning off the device and cleaning the goo from Agatha’s stomach as Rio helped her to sit up. “So, little one is in the clear, now tell me about how you’re doing. I know you mentioned you were having trouble sleeping, anything else you’re experiencing?”

 

“Oh, really I’m just sore and tired all the time. I have had some occasional, I guess you could call it cramping?”

 

“Hmmm…ok, are you experiencing any bleeding or spotting with it?”

 

“No, nothing like that. It’s just uncomfortable for a bit then goes away pretty quickly.” 

 

“It’s likely Braxton Hicks, you’ll probably feel them more frequently as you settle into the third trimester and we get closer to the due date. Though if anything changes or you do experience any bleeding, don’t be afraid to reach out.” She gave Agatha a reassuring smile before glancing over her chart as she continued her questioning, “How are you managing stress these days? I know when we first met there was a lot going on and this had come as a bit of a shock. Last time you mentioned work has become a little more demanding but it would be somewhat temporary. Have things settled at all?”

 

Agatha breathed a laugh, “Not exactly, though the shock has worn off a bit.” She flashed a nervous glance to Rio who was standing holding her hand and leaning against the table beside her. “For the most part things in my personal life are beginning to come together a bit more.” She felt Rio squeeze her hand and she responded in kind. “Work, on the other hand, is another story. I had hoped things would calm down earlier this week but due to some recent changes that hasn’t been the case. If anything it’s gotten more complicated.”

 

“Good! I’m glad to hear some things have settled. I’m sorry to hear work hasn’t eased up yet. Other than work and difficulty sleeping, is there anything else you would say contributes to stress in your life currently?”

 

“No, not that I can th…oh, well I wouldn’t say I’m stressed about it, more moderately annoyed, but technically, I guess my mother is suing me.”

 

“What?!” Rio shouted, her eyes bulging in shocked fury as she glared at Agatha.

 

“Did I forget to mention that?” She asked as an amused smirk crept across her face

 

“Uh, yeah! I feel like I would have remembered that!” Rio laughed, dispersing the anger that sparked inside her at the mention of Evanora. “We can talk about it later.” she snickered as they turned their attention back to Dr. Allen. 

 

“Wow, yeah, that’s definitely not going to help anything!” Dr. Allen let out a sympathetic laugh. “With everything that you’re managing it’s important that, as things progress, you continue to rest and relax as much as possible. Make sure you’re eating enough, drinking enough water, and not over exerting yourself. Overall you’re in good shape, the only thing I’m currently concerned about is that your blood pressure is still higher than I’d like it to be. We’re going to continue to monitor it closely for now, though if it hasn’t decreased by your next visit we may look at prescribing something.”

 

“Is this something we should be monitoring at home?” Rio jumped in, growing worried at the concern.

 

Dr. Allen cracked a smile, “Great minds! I was just about to suggest checking a few times throughout the day. It will also help us see if you are experiencing any spikes.”

 

“How concerned should I be about this?” Agatha asked, seeing the growing worry from the two professionals in the room.

 

“Right now it's just something to be aware of, in the sense that you should do what you can to eliminate as much stress as possible. That, to me, seems to be the likely contributing factor as you appear pretty healthy otherwise and baby is doing great.” She gave Agatha an encouraging smile. “Do you have any other questions for me?” 

 

“No I don’t think so.” She took another glance back at Rio whose caring smile had grown to hold a twinge of concern. “Do you?” 

 

Rio gleamed at the question “No, I’m good.” 

 

“Alright, I’ll have the photos up at the front for you when you make your next appointment. You’re all set here, y’all enjoy the rest of your day.” Dr. Allen left with a wave and a kind smile. 

 

Rio helped Agatha down from the table and grabbed her purse as Agatha straightened herself and led them out to the front desk. Rio followed in a haze, the last few minutes had been life changing. Though she had seen several ultrasounds throughout her career, it was a completely different experience being on this side of the table. The amazement she held at seeing the child that had turned her world upside down was indescribable, and yet fear bloomed at the back of her mind. She couldn’t let anything happen to Agatha and she would do everything in her power to ensure it. 

 

—------------------------------------------------

“Thank you for inviting me, Cariño.” she smiled, leaning over the center console, taking in Agatha’s lips for a kiss. “This has been the second best day of my life.” she leaned in for another kiss. 

 

“Second best?” Agatha asked, grinning through pressed lips

 

“The best was when I met you, of course!” 

 

Agatha laughed, breaking the kiss. “You really can’t help it can you?”

 

“Can’t help what?” Rio asked innocently

 

“Being this obscenely charming!” Agatha exclaimed

 

Rio gasped in mock astonishment “You think I’m charming? And I thought this day couldn’t get any better!”

“He’s going to look just like you.” Rio chuckled as they got to the image of him waving

 

“How do you know?” Agatha asked, eyebrow raised

 “You can’t tell that!” She laughed, eyebrow arching further in skepticism

 

“There! Right there! I swear, it’s the same exact face!” Rio insisted as she giggled.

As she thought of the life she wished for her son she couldn’t imagine depriving him of someone who already loved him more than her own mother ever did. It pulled at something deep within her, a phantom of guilt and fear at how close she had been to throwing this all away. It washed over her in a wave of cold panic causing her to reach her hand across the console, cupping Rio’s cheek as she pulled her lips into hers as her fingers wound through her hair.

The smell of lilac and honeysuckle invaded her airways, deepening her hunger, causing her to press her tongue into Agatha’s mouth, chasing the heavenly taste she had craved for so long. It’s also been a hell of a day.” She leaned back in her seat brushing the wetness from her eyes. “Come on, I should probably get back to work anyway.”

“What?” 

 

“Given what Dr. Allen said, maybe it’s a good idea for you to take the afternoon off.”

 

“HA!” Agatha burst out a laugh “You’re joking!”

 

“Agatha, you just said it yourself, it’s already been a rough day. You’ve been working like crazy for weeks, on your own. I think you’ve earned it.” 

 

“I can’t just take the afternoon off, I have to save vacation days for when the baby comes. Besides, I’m supposed to meet with finance to figure out a plan for this marketing thing!” 

 

“First, it’s barely half a day, they probably wouldn’t even count it against you. You and I both know Herb wouldn’t question it. Second, does the finance thing really need to happen today ? Maybe Sharon could push it to tomorrow? Knowing you I bet you’d still have it resolved before noon.” Agatha narrowed her eyes at her in consideration but said nothing. Rio picked up the sonogram of the baby waving and held it up next to her face, “He says Please mommy! Please blow off work this afternoon and hang out with Rio instead !” 

 

Agatha raised her eyebrows in amusement, “Are you seriously using my son to guilt me into skipping work?”

 

“Only if it’s working.” She glanced at the photo then back at Agatha. “Is it working?” She laughed nervously. 

 

Agatha smirked as she pulled out her phone. “I’ll call Sharon, if she can find a time tomorrow morning for me to meet with them then I’ll take the afternoon off.” 

 

“Excellent! Let me talk to her!” Rio demanded as Agatha called Sharon. 

 

“What?” Agatha asked as the phone rang. 

 

“Here, put it on speaker!” She held out her hand as Agatha handed over the phone and Rio adjusted just in time for Sharon to answer. 

 

“ Hello dear! How did it go?” 

 

“Everything was fine!” Agatha replied 

 

“Everything was not fine Sharon!” Rio shouted towards the phone. 

 

“ Is that Rio? Hi honey!”

 

“Hi, yes it’s Rio! Agatha’s not coming back to work today, doctor's orders, she needs to reschedule her money meeting for tomorrow morning.” 

 

“ Oh, ok! I hope it’s not too serious! You know, that might work out better actually. I was only able to grab 30 minutes right at 2:30 today and I wasn’t sure if that was going to be enough time.” 

 

“See! Tomorrow’s better!” Rio taunted as Agatha rolled her eyes. “She’ll be fine, just needs to rest a bit. Thanks Sharon! You’re the best!”

 

“Yes, thank you Sharon. I’ll see you tomorrow.” Agatha said as she hung up the phone. “So, now what?” 

 

“Now, we chill.”

 

“And what does chilling involve?” 

 

“Anything you want! We could head back to your place, hang out with Scratchy and relax on the couch. Or we can head to my place. See what they have playing in the theatre, maybe go for a swim? Though, at some point, we should stop at a store and try and get a blood pressure monitor.” 

 

“A swim?” Agatha chuckled. 

 

“Yeah why not? It’d probably feel good if you're sore. Besides, no one ever uses the pool, especially on a Thursday afternoon. I’m sure we’d have the place to ourselves.” 

 

“Now that you mention it, that does sound nice, though, I don’t know if I have anything to wear that still fits at this point.” 

 

“How about this, we run to your house, you can grab what you need, I’m sure we can find something that’ll work, then we can stop at the store on the way to my place?” 

 

“Yeah, that sounds like a plan.” 

 

“Hell yeah! This is going to be great!” Rio cheered as she turned the car on. “Much better than stressing out over work stuff! Bleh!”

 

“You’re a terrible influence!” Agatha chuckled

 

“Yes, but I’m your terrible influence.” Rio smirked as she pulled out of the lot and headed to Agatha’s house. 

 

—————————————————

“I look like a beach ball!” She called out to Rio who was already swimming around gleefully. “I can’t believe you talked me into this!”

 

“You’re the cutest beach ball I’ve ever seen!” Rio lilted as she swam to meet her at the shallow end of the pool. “Come on, the water feels great!” Rio stood at the edge of the stairs and reached a hand out for Agatha to join her.

She eased onto the first step and was surprised to find it was warmer than she expected, almost tepid like a bath, immediately soothing the swollen aching in her feet. Her eyes fluttered closed sighing at the relief. As she lowered herself further she felt the tension she had accumulated throughout the day begin to lessen, melting into the water around her. “Let go, I’ve got you.” She murmured as her arms tucked under her shoulders.

“Feeling better, my love?” Rio hummed as Agatha’s head sank further onto her shoulder. 

 

“Mmhmmm” Agatha sighed as she felt her spine begin to decompress. “This feels amazing! I feel like I can breathe again.”

Her eyes, now heavy in relaxed bliss, slowly blinked Rio back into focus.

“Just barely.” Agatha yawned “I don’t remember the last time I felt this relaxed. This is exactly what I needed.” 

 

Rio smiled, “I had a feeling this might do the trick.” She let her gaze fall down to the bump pressed between them as her hands rose to rest on either side. “And how about you pequeño bichito? Are you relaxed? Happy?”

Agatha stepped forward, resuming her position between Rio’s legs and placed her hand back at the spot. “You tell me” she chuckled as the waves of laughter faded.

 

As soon as Rio’s hand made contact she could feel the strumming of life she had awakened beneath Agatha’s skin. “Ha!” An astonished laugh burst forth from Rio’s throat as her eyes jumped up take in Agatha’s surprised amusement. “Well,” she shrugged “Maybe now he’ll let you sleep through the night!” 

 

“One can only hope!” Agatha sighed as she moved to lean against the wall next to Rio. 

 

As soon as she was settled Rio turned her head abruptly with a mischievous glint in her eye. “Hey, you want to see a cool trick?” 

 

Agatha chuckled as her eyebrows stitched in amusement. “A cool trick?” Rio nodded excitedly “Sure, as long as I don’t have to move.” 

 

“Not at all! You’re perfect right where you are!” Rio replied, planting a kiss on Agatha’s cheek as she pushed herself away from the wall, easing through the water, grinning like a crocodile. She swam to the other side of the pool and pushed herself out onto the ground. Dripping as she walked she headed towards the set of diving boards at the far end. 

 

“Please don’t hurt yourself! I’m in no condition to try and save you!” Agatha called across the room. 

 

“I promise I’ll be safe!” Rio shouted back as she ascended one of the ladders. She walked halfway down the board, gave Agatha a wave, then zeroed in her focus to the task at hand. With the grace of a champion athlete she stepped out, sprang once, twice then leapt off the board clearing two and a half rotations before her hands hit the water in a near perfect dive. 

 

Agatha sat, mouth hung ajar, gobsmacked at what she had just witnessed. As the water bubbled just below where Rio had disappeared her eyes searched for her to resurface. A moment passed, then another, then finally Rio’s head breached the water just a few feet away from where she was standing. “What the hell was that?” Agatha shrieked in outraged amazement. 

 

“Just a 2.5. Cool trick right?” Rio beamed as she came to float in front of Agatha. 

 

“Where did that come from?” Agatha half shouted, still in shock

 

“I was on the diving team through undergrad. I wasn’t very good but I had a good time.” Rio shrugged as she waded back and forth in the water. “What can I say? I’m full of surprises!”

“Was there any note or message with it?”

 

“No, dear, just the bag.” 

 

“Huh” she huffed as she turned to head back into her office. Just as she crossed the threshold she heard her phone ringing in her bag. She dropped the toy back on her desk and grabbed her phone. It was her lawyer, Valentina. She took a breath then answered the call.

 

“Good morning, Val. Do you have an update for me?”

 

“Yes! Good morning. We’ve finally been assigned a court date. I was able to get us on the docket the first Wednesday in April. That’s in a couple of weeks, will that work for you?”

 

“Yes, I’ll make it work. What time?”

“8:30. I’m not sure how long it will take but I’d plan to take off the whole day just in case.”

 

Agatha sighed in annoyance. “If it will put an end to this whole thing I’ll do what I need to. Did you have any more insight on the will?’

 

“I finally got a hold of a copy of their document yesterday. It took your mother’s lawyer way longer than it should have to send it over. I haven’t had a chance to dig into it yet but on first look the document seems authentic.” 

 

Agatha’s heart dropped at that discovery. “What would that mean?”

 

“Nothing for the time being. There are a few red flags I’m having my assistant dig into. We’ll plan to meet up soon to go over everything. I’m happy to schedule something for after your work hours.”

 

“Thank you, I appreciate that.”

 

“Of course. Until then try not to dwell on things. I’ll reach out soon about scheduling a time. For now, enjoy your weekend, I’ll see you sometime next week.”

 

“See you.” She hung up the phone and flung it onto her desk. 

 

In her bliss with Rio she had pushed off the idea of dealing with her mother but now, with the date set it was inevitable. She would have to face her once again and the thought sent a cold chill of dread down her spine. She closed her eyes, rubbing her temples to relieve the stress that had built during the conversation. As she did so she felt her son shift dramatically within her, as if finally waking up for the day at the anxiety that was now thrumming through her. 


“Morning little bug.” She hummed as she brought a hand down to the swell. “Don’t worry, you’ll never have to deal with that woman if I can help it.” She let out a sigh as her hand continued to rub soothing circles along the surface, and then her eye caught sight of the toy and a fear pricked up her spine. No, surely she wouldn’t! How could she possibly know? Her heart skipped a beat as she picked up the toy and the bag once again. No name, no note anywhere in sight. Then, quickly, as if the items had caught fire in her hands, she threw them in the trash. Whatever game Evanora thought she was playing Agatha was not going to be a part of it.

Chapter End Notes

Not sure when I'll be able to post the next chapter but it will be some drama with Evanora so definitely something to look forward to! I'm gonna tell you right now Rio is not having any of her bullshit.

Chapter 23: Thirty One

Chapter Summary

Agatha and Rio prepare for dealing with Evanora

Chapter Notes

As always, thank you for your patience! My partner had major surgery so I haven't had as much time to write. Glad to finally have something to post.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“So, she’s stalking you?” Jen grumbled as she sipped wine on Agatha’s couch while she and Rio prepared dinner in the kitchen. 

 

“Well, I don’t think it’s her specifically. More likely someone from her congregation. There’s this women’s group that she leads and the seven of them hang on her every word. I swear they’d kill for her if she asked them to.” Agatha explained

 

“It’s a fucking cult.” Rio noted. 

 

“Yeah, I guess you could call it that.” Agatha shrugged as she chopped vegetables.

 

“I mean, why else would these people be keeping tabs on you?” Rio reasoned

 

“Morbid curiosity, entertainment, sheer nosiness? I don’t know, I don’t really care, I just want it to stop! I want her out of my life once and for all but I don’t know what to do. The restraining order clearly didn’t work!” Agatha groaned, exasperatedly throwing the chopped vegetables onto a baking tray.

 

“What all has she sent you?” Alice asked.

 

“It started with this stupid toy rabbit that showed up at my office last Friday. I immediately threw it in the trash. Then she followed up with a childrens bible on Monday, I told the courier to return to sender but the fucking thing showed up at my house later that day. That also went straight in the trash. Then this morning as I’m trying to leave for work I almost trip over that fucking box.” she gestured to a gift box tossed by the side of the door. “I didn’t have time to deal with it so I just threw it there. I swear if another garbage item shows up at my house tomorrow I’m going to fucking lose it!” Agatha groaned frustratedly

 

“Soooo fucking weird!” Jen chuckled as she moved to grab the box, eyeing it curiously. “Are you going to open it?” 

 

“Why would I?” Agatha snorted

 

“Aren’t you curious?” Jen asked, turning the box over in her hands.

 

“Not in the slightest! I really should just throw it out.” Agatha reasoned

 

“If that’s the case you won’t mind if I open it.” Jen inquired

 

“Knock yourself out! It’s going in the trash either way.” Agatha waived dismissively as she handed the tray to Rio. 

 

Jen peeled back the silver wrapping paper revealing a department store clothing box. As she lifted the lid she discovered a tiny, lacy white gown. “What the fuck is this?” she asked as she held the garment up between her fingers. “Why did she send you a baby dress?” Jen’s voice dripped with disgust.

 

“Ugh…it’s a christening gown.” Agatha scoffed as she looked over at what Jen was holding.

 

“The fuck?” Jen grumbled, scrunching her face in confusion.

 

“It’s a church thing.” Agatha clarified

 

“Have you reached out to the post office about blocking what she tries to send you?” Alice asked

 

“Well Sharon knows not to accept any other packages at the office. But I don’t know that the ones that are showing up here are even going through the mail.” Agatha shrugged

 

“Woah, wait, you think she’s dropping them here herself?” Jen asked in astonishment.

 

“No, again I’m pretty sure it’s just one of her minions. Like I said, that box showed up before I even left for work.”

 

“I don’t quite understand her thought process here.” Alice said, brows etched in contemplation. “She’s suing you and sending you gifts.”

 

“Well, technically they’re not for me.” Agatha explained

 

Rio slammed the oven door shut causing everyone to jump. “I fucking hate this! It’s psychotic and manipulative!” Rio shouted, slamming a tray back on the stove. “All this weird passive aggressive evangelical bullshit! There’s no way she’s ever going anywhere near this child, not if I can help it!” Rio growled

 

“When do you have to see her?” Alice asked

 

“A week from tomorrow. I am not looking forward to it.” Agatha groaned

 

“No shit!” Jen chuckled

 

“We’re supposed to meet with my lawyer tomorrow to prep. I’ll be interested to hear what she has to say.”

 

“You’re telling her about the gifts right?” Jen insisted

 

“Oh, absolutely! I don’t know that it will make a difference but I’m hoping it might help prove stalking and maybe we can refile the restraining order. I picked up some security cameras so if anything else does show up we’ll at least have some sort of documentation of what’s been happening.” Rio explained. “I know I’ve said this before but I really wish we had filed charges when she attacked Agatha in Boston. I feel like that would have been the nail in her coffin, she wouldn’t have been able to appeal the original restraining order, and we wouldn’t be dealing with this now. This is the last thing she needs!” Rio grumbled, gesturing to Agatha as she put another tray in the oven. 

 

“I’ll be fine! I’ve been dealing with her pulling stunts like this my entire life. They’re definitely getting old but at this point there isn’t much else I can do other than face it. I just feel bad that you’ve been dragged into this.” She sighed as she leaned her head onto Rio’s shoulder.

 

“No, no, no. I’m more than happy to be the person to tell her to go fuck herself on your behalf.” Rio replied, wrapping her arm around Agatha’s shoulders.

 

“Oof, I am right there with you! I’ve been there for some of the other crap she’s pulled and it’s way past time for her to learn her lesson! As a principle, I don’t condone elder abuse but that woman needs to get her fucking shit rocked.” Jen scoffed. 

 

“Oh don’t worry, I’m more than prepared to handle her!” Rio insisted

 

“ Rio… ” Agatha warned, rising to glare scoldingly at Rio.

 

“Yes, I know dear! I won’t do anything that’ll get me fired, or thrown in jail.” Rio confirmed before walking over and pouring Alice a glass of wine. “Unless she starts throwing hands again then all bets are off.” She mumbled to Alice and Jen. 

 

“She’s not going to get violent in a courtroom.” Agatha called from the kitchen. 

 

“I don’t know, she didn’t seem to have a problem slapping you in front of like 12 strangers.” Rio barked.

 

“I’m convinced that was a fluke. We were in our house, on familiar territory and she wasn’t expecting me to stand up to her so when I called her a bitch I think her reflexes just kicked in.” Agatha reasoned

 

“I mean you weren’t wrong. She’s a grade A bitch if I’ve ever seen one.” Jen snorted 

 

“Alright, dinner’s almost ready, can we please stop talking about my mother? I don’t want to think about her any more than I already have to.” Agatha groaned

 

“Of course, cariño.” Rio cooed as she placed a kiss on Agatha’s cheek. 

 

“How’s the new living situation been working out?” Agatha asked Jen and Alice.

 

“I’ve been pretty happy with it.” Alice smiled coyly, “How about you?” she asked, gazing lovingly at Jen who was already beaming.

 

“Oh my gosh! I can’t begin to tell you the difference it’s made! There’s so much space, I have access to a full kitchen with a dishwasher, it’s like ten minutes closer to the hospital, and on top of that I get to see Alice everyday now! Honestly, better than I could have imagined! What about you two?” She asked as she took a sip of wine.

 

“What about us?” Agatha snorted. 

 

“Come on, have you two spent a day apart since you got back together?” Jen chuckled

 

“Fair enough.” Rio shrugged. “I mean, why would we want to spend another day apart?” 

 

“Gross!” Jen groaned “How have you been feeling? Everything go alright at your last check in with Vicky?” she asked, shifting the conversation as quickly as she could.

 

“Fine, all things considered. She said he seems healthy and happy, growing appropriately so that makes me feel better.” 

 

“ But… ” Rio pressed

 

“But, she did say my blood pressure was slightly high so we’ve been monitoring that more frequently.” 

 

“Oh, and how’s that been going?” Jen inquired

 

“Still higher than it should be, which makes sense given everything she’s dealing with, so definitely a concern. I think the next visit is after the court date next week. She said if it hasn’t gone down by then she’ll prescribe something.” Rio explained. 

 

 “Yeah, that’s definitely something you want to stay on top of. We don’t need any complications.” Jen insisted, raising her eyebrows in concern. 

 

“She said it’s probably stress related so that doesn’t help. There are quite a few factors contributing to that at the moment.” Agatha added, eyes widened in emphasis. 

 

“Which is why I’ve been telling you to take it easy. In fact, go sit down while I finish up.” Agatha rolled her eyes as she padded over to collapse in the armchair across from Jen and Alice on the couch.

 

“Oh, that reminds me! I brought you something!” Jen jumped up to grab her bag. “After you called me last week I figured this might give you some peace of mind without having to call and divulge more details that I do not want to know.” Jen dug around in her bag for a moment until she pulled out a small handheld machine which she handed to Agatha. “It’s a fetal heart rate monitor so you can check in on him between visits.” 

 

“Jen! You did not have to do this!” She gasped in awe. 

 

“Please! It was only like $50, and if it keeps me out of your sex life it was worth every penny.” Jen scoffed. 

 

“Alright, dinner’s ready, come and get it!” Rio called from the kitchen. “You, park it! I’ll bring you a plate.” She insisted, pointing to Agatha who slumped back down in the armchair. 

 

“Now I know Agatha had nothing to do with this food, it looks and smells amazing!” Jen complimented, practically drooling at the selection.

 

“Hey!” Agatha bit in protest

 

“It’s alright, my love, you can’t be good at everything!” 

 

“HEY!” She shouted, shocked at Rio’s honesty

 

“Oh you let her cook for you?” Jen snickered as she plated her food.

 

“We both agreed it was a mistake and ended up ordering pizza.” 

 

“Smart move! Hey, I’ve been meaning to ask, when are we doing your baby shower?” Jen pried as she returned to the couch.

 

“We’re not!” Agatha snapped

 

“Oh come on, don’t you still need like…a ton of shit?” Jen asked, shaking her head in astonishment. 

 

“I have no problem collecting things myself. I don’t need some pastel hellscape party populated by people I consider acquaintances at best oohing and awing over how big I’ve gotten or guesstimating when I’m going to squeeze him out. Even if they are bringing free shit I’d still have to sit there and pretend to fawn over whatever crap they decided to buy.” Agatha grumbled as she took the plate of food from Rio.

 

“It doesn’t have to be like that if you don’t want it to be, and I think it would be more helpful than you realize to not have to worry about finding half the stuff you still need.” Jen retorted

 

“She has a point, cariño.” Rio said as she handed Agatha her plate earning her a glare. “One less thing to stress about, like the doctor suggested.” 

 

“Right, but if the party itself stresses me out then it’s a moot point.” Agatha challenged

 

“Why would it stress you out? I thought you loved being the center of attention!” Jen snickered

 

“Not like this, it’s very…performative.” 

 

“But isn’t that what you do best?” Jen chuckled to which Agatha scowled.

 

“Only when it comes to money. Me? My personal life? No thank you!” Agatha explained through a mouthful of food. 

 

“What if I were to throw you the party, my love? I plan the whole thing, you just have to show up and look cute, easy right? You won’t have to talk with anyone if you don’t want to.” Rio suggested trying to sound as harmless as possible.

 

“You’re all so insistent about this.” Agatha sighed facetiously 

 

“Yeah because it’s a good idea!” Jen snapped annoyedly 

 

“I don’t even know when we would have this, I have so much going on with this court date and preparing for Mayfest.” Agatha countered, hoping there was still a chance to talk them out of it. 

 

“Oh, right, how’s that going?” Alice inquired.

 

“It’s been driving me insane, but thankfully we’re finally over the marketing hurdle. We found a company that will be able to work aggressively within our budget, given we really only have a month to promote it. We’ve been cycling social media ads for the time being with the few items Freddy did create but, given the scale this year, we really need to make sure there’s a good turnout. Now we just have to hire a management company by the end of the week so we can submit updated festival plans to the city for road closures and shit by the first of the month. It’s a nightmare, but if we pull this off it’ll change everything.” 

 

“The high blood pressure is making sense now.” Jen nodded as she cleared her plate. “Again I think this is just more of a reason to have a shower. When are you going to have time to get all this shit before the baby comes?” Jen continued prodding. 

 

“Online ordering is a marvel, Jen. I’ll have to show you!” Agatha brushed off sarcastically. 

 

Jen flashed Agatha an unamused look, “Ok then, when are you going to have time to order all this shit?” 

 

“You’re really not going to drop this are you?” Agatha groaned as she dropped her fork to her plate with a clank. 

 

“If it comes to it I’ll make it a surprise party and you’re not going to know when it happens.” Jen threatened

 

“Don’t you dare!” Agatha gasped

 

“Or you can decide on a date and let the three of us plan something.” Jen offered.

 

“FINE! No stupid games, I’m talking to no one , and I’m not opening one damn present!” Agatha spat, resigning herself at last. 

 

“Ok, Agatha, we’ll figure something out! Maybe close to the end of April, before the festival but after the court date.” Rio suggested.

 

“Whatever, I am not acknowledging my part in this until the day of.” Agatha insisted

 

“Fair enough, cariño.” Rio chuckled nervously as she glanced back at Jen and Alice. 

 

“Can you hold this for me?” she held out her plate to Rio “I have to go to the bathroom again, he’s dancing on my bladder.” She pressed a hand to her side as she slid to the edge of the chair. 

 

“Of course, do you need help up?” Rio asked as she grabbed the plate and stood to help.

 

“No, no I’ve got it! I’m not useless yet.” She waved Rio off as she heaved herself from the chair and waddled down the hallway. 

As soon as she disappeared through the door Rio leaned over to whisper to Jen and Alice. “So I’m thinking maybe we do something small, a lunch or dinner or something. Keep it short. I really don’t want to overwhelm her. I mean, she seems less keen on the idea than I thought she would be.” She explained worriedly 

 

“Yeah, Agatha is not a party person, especially if it’s for her. I didn’t know when her birthday was the first five years I knew her because she never celebrated it and refused to tell me.”

 

“I was also thinking, considering her stance on presents, maybe we can try and collect things ahead of time and I can set up the baby’s room for her, show it to her afterwards or something?” Rio suggested desperately.

 

“How exactly would you do that if you’re at the party?” Jen frowned.

 

“Right…It would probably have to be before the party.” Rio bit her lip concernedly

 

“Are we doing this while she’s at work or something?” Alice asked

 

“Oooo bad idea. She is not going to want to do this after work.” Jen warned 

 

“Then we’ll need a distraction.” At that suggestion Rio and Alice zeroed in on Jen.

 

“Me? Why do I have to be the distraction?” Jen whined.

 

“It’s either that or put together a bunch of baby shit.” Rio shrugged. 

 

Jen rolled her eyes as she bit under her breath, “Fine I’ll be the distraction.”

 

“Take her out for a girls day or something before the party. Get her as relaxed and amiable as possible.” Alice proposed

 

“Right, and why don’t I just end world hunger while I’m at it!” Jen scoffed. 

 

“Making big plans there Jen! Don’t hurt yourself.” Agatha taunted as she reappeared in the hallway, a hand braced against the crest of her stomach. “What were you three talking about?” She asked as she eased back down into the chair.

 

“Just sorting out details for the party. You ok?” Rio asked, seeing her grimace and groan as she sat back down.

 

“Fine, just braxton hicks, my stomach feels as hard as a rock.” She took a slow breath in and out while she waited for the pressure to pass.  

 

“Getting more of those these days?” Jen asked 

 

“Eh, they happen here and there and usually aren’t too bad but every once in a while I’ll get one that’s kind of…intense.” Agatha sighed, still catching her breath. 

 

“Sounds about right. They’ll likely get more frequent as you get closer. Have you thought anymore about your birth plan?” 

 

“What’s there to think about? When I go into labor I’ll head to the hospital, you’ll drug me up and I’ll push him out.” Agatha rambled disdainfully

 

“You’ve not looked at a single thing I’ve sent you have you?” Jen scolded, disappointed but not surprised.

 

“No, not yet.” Agatha admitted as she took another bite of her food. 

 

“Why do I even bother?” Jen huffed as she rolled her eyes annoyed, “You’re about to be in for a rude awakening. This shit is not a walk in the park, even if there aren’t any complications. I’m not trying to scare you but, especially with your age and your blood pressure being high, it puts you both at risk. You have to be mentally prepared for whatever may happen!” 

 

Agatha pursed her lips in annoyance before shooting a look at Rio who quickly diverted her attention back to her plate, not wanting to get caught in the impending blowback. Then, just as Agatha was about to retort, Alice piped up. 

 

“You know, Jen, maybe you two could get together and talk through things. Help Agatha come up with a plan?” Alice suggested earning her a side eye from Jen. 

 

“What an excellent idea, Alice! What do you think about that, my love? You and Jen have a girls day, maybe get a few things for the baby, get a better idea of what to expect and plan for?” Agatha stared daggers at Rio before turning to glare at Jen. 

 

Jen sighed as she turned back to face Agatha “What do you say, Harkness?” 

 

Agatha raised her eyebrows in suspicion. “You want to do this?” She asked skeptically

 

Jen grinned through clenched teeth. “Yes.”

 

“Why does this feel like a trap?” She asked, looking around at all of them watching her intently. 

 

Rio’s eyes darted to Jen and Alice before returning to Agatha, “No! No trap. We just want to make sure you’re as ready as you can be.” she insisted reassuringly 

 

“Ah! So you are all in on this together!” Agatha jumped in sleuthing pride.

 

“No you stubborn bitch! We’re not in on anything! We just want what’s best for you and the baby.” Jen snapped. “Are you in or out?”

 

“Fine Jen! Don’t get your panties in a wad! I’m in.” Agatha relented

 

“Fuck! It’s like pulling teeth just to do something nice for you!” Jen huffed, annoyed at her own tolerance for the lack of gratitude.

 

“I said I’m in, what more do you want?” Agatha spat

 

“I don’t know, a thank you would be fucking nice!” Jen half-shouted back

 

Agatha grumbled as she took another bite of food. 

 

“ Agatha!” Rio scolded under her breath

 

Agatha rolled her eyes back to Jen. “Thank you, Jennifer. Now can we please talk about anything else?” There was a moment of silence as everyone sat there, feeling the tension in the air as they waited for someone to be brave enough to speak. 

 

“Rio,” Alice started, clearing her throat, “How…how’s your aunt doing?” Alice asked, heroically obliging the request. 

 

“Lilia? Oh she’s… she’s doing alright.” Rio chuckled nervously. “Up to her usual shenanigans I’m sure.”

 

“Have you talked with her much since everything happened?” Alice continued

 

“A bit. She knows Agatha and I have worked things out and is happy for us. To be honest I haven’t really seen her since then. Just trying to focus on us and this guy for the time being.” Rio explained as she rubbed a hand against Agatha’s belly. Agatha smiled lovingly as she placed her hand atop Rio’s. 

 

“That must be hard given she’s your only family in the area.” Alice commented. 

 

“Oh, she’s my only family.” Rio clarified.

 

“What?” Jen and Alice asked in unison

 

“She’s my only living relative.” Rio explained, “Sorry, I thought we had talked about this?”

 

“No we did not!” Jen gasped

 

“Oh, wow, I didn’t realize! I’m so sorry.” Alice sighed. 

 

Rio chuckled. “It’s alright. It’s been that way for a while.” 

 

“Still, I would imagine that makes it even harder, if things are unresolved between you two.” Alice pressed

 

“It’s not that they’re unresolved necessarily, at least between us. We’ve had a chance to talk through things and she’s admitted her actions, though well intentioned, were misguided at best. I would hope, given how serious we’ve become, eventually she and Agatha could sit down and talk things over, but I’m not going to force anything. It’ll happen in its own time.” Rio insisted as she rubbed her thumb reassuringly against the taught surface.

 

“Would you talk with her?” Jen asked, directing her attention to Agatha.

 

“I…I don’t really know. We hadn’t really discussed it before now and I haven’t given it much thought. Honestly, I kind of forgot with everything else going on.” Agatha frowned

 

“Really, it’s not something you need to worry about right now anyway.” Rio assured

 

“But if she’s like literally your only relative…” Jen started, chuckling in disbelief that Rio would be so calm about such an important issue.  

 

“It’s fine, really! We’re still settling things and that’s what I need to focus on. She understands that.” Rio insisted

 

“Are you opposed to talking with her?” Jen persisted

 

Agatha gazed over at Rio. Though she did her best to hold an air of nonchalance, Agatha could see the pain buried behind her eyes. “No, I guess not, assuming she’s remorseful for her actions. It’s not like she could do it again at this point.” 

 

“Are you sure?” Rio asked, eyebrows raised in caution. 

 

“I mean, I’d love to get an apology but yeah, I’d be open to talking with her. She is your only family after all, even if she makes wildly impulsive decisions and is a bit… eccentric.” 

 

“Sounds like someone else I know.” Jen mumbled under her breath earning a glare from Agatha before she continued. 

 

“Honestly, I think she might be the most sane family member between the two of us, which is…well…a low bar, really, but she does clear it, barely .”

 

Rio beamed “That…that would be amazing. I’ll talk with her and see if we can all go out to lunch or something soon. Not until after next week of course!” She assured, squeezing Agatha’s hand in excitement. “She’s going to be thrilled! She’s been asking about you, if everything’s ok and how the baby is doing. I know it didn’t really seem like it but she does care and genuinely wants what’s best for us.” Rio urged, hoping to gain some favor for Lilia in the meantime.

 

“It’s more than I can say for my mother!” Agatha laughed, surprisingly unbothered by the idea. In truth she liked the idea of having some sort of elder maternal figure in their lives for her son.  

 

“I know that’s right!” Jen snorted as she finished off her glass of wine before turning to Alice. “You about ready?” 

 

“You guys headed out?” Rio asked

 

“Yeah, I’ve got an early start and I’ve got to try and hit the gym beforehand. Let us know how things go with your lawyer tomorrow and how things go with your mother next week. I don’t know that I’ll see you again before then!” Jen said as she gathered her things

 

“Oh don’t worry, I'm sure I’ll have a saga to tell you.” Agatha grunted as she pulled herself from the chair once again.

 

“Please at least read over what I sent you, I promise it’s helpful! And take it easy, as much as you can. You’re in the home stretch here, we want to make it to the finish line.” Jen warned as she leaned in to give Agatha a hug goodbye. 

 

Agatha stiffened in the embrace, feeling a cold chill run down her spine at the caution. She knew Jen was only trying to help, but the warning left an ominous pit in her stomach. She flashed Jen an awkward and annoyed half-smile, attempting to keep her composure but couldn’t bring herself to say a thing as they parted. 

 

“Keep an eye on her, she has a terrible habit of not taking good advice.” Jen gleaned as she moved to say goodbye to Rio.

 

“Oh, don’t worry, I’m all over it!” Rio reassured, giving Jen a quick hug goodbye. “You still down for the game on Monday?” she asked, turning her attention to Alice.

 

“What game?” Jen and Agatha asked in unison, side eyeing each other.

 

“Rio invited me to play in her pick up game on Monday. I wouldn’t say it’s my best sport, but I’m pretty quick and can keep them on their toes.” Alice preened.

 

“She’s going to be my secret weapon.” Rio chuckled as she and Alice high fived.

 

Jen snickered, astonished as she side eyed Agatha who shook her head and shrugged in response. “Well, ok then. Hope you two have fun. Have a good night!” and with that they stepped into the night.

 

As Rio closed the door behind them she could feel Agatha’s eyes on her. She slowly turned, “What?”

 

“You and Alice? Seriously?” Agatha snorted in sheer disbelief. 

 

“What, she's cool! I thought it’d be fun to hang out.” Rio shrugged innocently. 

 

“When did this happen?” Agatha scrunched her brows in an attempt to understand. 

 

“We talked a bit about it at karaoke night. We text every so often. She just seems like a nice person.” Rio said matter of factly. 

 

“You text?” Agatha raised her eyebrows as she smirked.

 

“We mostly send each other memes but yeah, she’s become a good friend. She’s your best friend’s girlfriend, it makes sense for us to be friends too.” Rio threw her hands up in honest surrender. 

 

“It does…I guess I just wasn’t expecting it. I’m glad you two have hit it off.” Agatha said as she gathered plates and headed towards the kitchen. 

 

“What are you doing?” Rio asked as she quickly followed her. 

 

“What does it look like? I’m cleaning up!” 

 

“No! You don’t need to be doing that, go sit down. I’ll take care of it.” 

 

Agatha’s eyes narrowed at Rio as she took the plates from her hands and nodded her head towards the couch. She let out a defeated sigh, knowing this was a battle she wasn’t likely to win, and resigned herself to the sofa where she was quickly joined by scratchy. She laid down on her side, allowing him to find a comfortable nook at the top of her swollen belly and settle in, purring loudly. As if on cue her son wiggled towards the familiar sound, pressing up towards her ribs. She met his movements with the palm of her hand as another kick pressed firmly against her side. 

 

“How’s he doing?” Rio asked as she came to collect the empty wine glasses. 

 

“He seems perfectly happy. I think he likes Scratchy’s purring. He always stirs when it happens.” She smiled down lovingly at the fluffy beast curled in her arms.

 

“Of course! It’s like you attached a motorboat to your belly, I’m sure it’s very interesting. How are you feeling, really?” Rio inquired, unconvinced she had divulged her true state of being. 

 

“Bloated, swollen, and very tired.” Agatha admitted

 

“I bet! You’ve had a long day! I was surprised you were still up for dinner with them.” Rio said as she loaded the dishwasher.

 

“Well I’d have to eat anyway. I figured they wouldn’t be here long as it is. It was good to see them and catch up, though I wasn’t expecting you all to team up against me!” she groaned

 

“Against you?! Cariño, we were just trying to help. Are you really that upset about having a baby shower?” Rio snorted

 

“The idea makes me nauseated. Who would even come besides you three?” Agatha spat, still not fully convinced of the idea. 

 

“Well, given you’re open to working things out with Lilia I know she'd be delighted to join. Nat and Yelena would definitely make the trip up for it, I bet Hela would tag along with them. Then, of course, your friends from work.” 

 

“What friends from work? I don’t have any friends at work.” Agatha insisted

 

“Herb I think would probably come. Your friends on the board. We can’t forget Sharon!” Rio began listing

 

“Absolutely not! I don’t need my colleagues that involved in my personal life.” Agatha wrinkled her nose in disgust. 

 

“Fair enough, though I know Sharon is going to be disappointed, she’s been asking about it.” Rio shook her head in disappointment. 

 

“You’re joking!” Agatha gasped in disbelief. 

 

“Not at all! She’s very excited for you! She asked if she should be planning something, I told her to hold off until we’ve talked about it, but I wouldn’t be surprised if they already had something set for you at the office.” 

 

“Oh no!” Agatha groaned, pressing her hands against her face in frustration. “We’re going to have to have a talk tomorrow, she must be stopped.” 

 

“You can’t blame them for being excited and wanting to celebrate with you. You’re having a baby, people want to help and be there to support you, they care about you.” She said as she made her way over to join Agatha on the couch. “Aren’t you excited?”

 

“I’m getting there.” Agatha groaned

 

“What’s holding you back?” Agatha bit the inside of her cheek nervously as fearful thoughts tugged at the back of her mind. “Does it have anything to do with what Jen brought up? Are you nervous?” 

 

“Of course I’m nervous! A human is going to come out of my body in like three months! I know she thinks I’m just avoiding it but I’m well aware of the potential outcomes, for him and for me, I can’t really control it.”

 

“I know it’s intimidating but I’m sure talking things over with Jen will set your nerves at ease, she is an expert after all. She’ll get you as prepared as anybody can be.” Rio suggested, guiding a hand soothingly along Agatha’s leg. 

 

“If you say so.” Agatha groaned, not quite ready to accept the idea. 

 

“We all just want you and the baby to be happy and healthy. Which reminds me, it’s time to take your blood pressure.” Rio patted her leg with a smirk.

 

“Ugh, if we must!” Agatha grumbled

 

Rio pried herself from the couch and went to grab the blood pressure monitor. Agatha pushed herself to sit and felt her son roll within her. She inhaled sharply as his foot found a tender spot in her side just as Rio re-entered the room. 

 

“Alright, Cariño?” Rio asked, seeing the twinge of pain on her face.

 

“I’m fine, though it feels like he’s running out of room. He always manages to wedge himself into the worst spot these days. I’m pretty sure he’s standing on a kidney.” 

 

“Is that right?” She asked as she sat down next to Agatha. “Are you wreaking havoc in there little one?” Rio hummed against the surface.

 

“I can already tell it’s going to be another long uncomfortable night.” Agatha sighed exhaustedly. 

 

“Not if I can help it!” Rio leaned closer, pressing her hands to either side of the swell. “Knock, knock mister! Can I have your attention please?”She called, rapping her fingers against the surface. At the request she could feel the child shifting and moving under Agatha’s skin. Rio’s eyes grew wide in awe at the sensation as she glanced back at her. 

 

“I think he’s listening for you. It felt like he turned his whole body to hear you better.” Agatha informed her.

 

“Wild!” Rio breathed amazed as she continued. “Listen here you little squirt, your mama’s got a big day tomorrow and needs her rest. If you can behave I’ll buy some more of those spicy pickles you like. Deal?” She asked, rubbing her hands gently across the swell. Before long she felt a confident nudge against her palm. “He’s really listening?” She gasped astonished. 

 

“Not sure that he understands but he definitely recognizes your voice.” Agatha’s heart skipped a beat at the wonder Rio held in this moment. She could see the deep love she already had for this child she barely knew, it was precious and deep, radiating through every cell in her body. She could see days where she would read and share all the knowledge she had acquired. Nights where Rio would hold him close and soothe him back to sleep after a frightening dream. Summers at the beach covered in sand searching for sea shells. Winters warm at home by the fire huddled together on the couch reading late into the night. Their quiet, adoring perfect little family. The kind of family she hadn’t ever dared to dream of now knelt before her, cradling the growing life inside her. She wanted to share every detail of this journey with her.  “

Do you want to try and hear him?” She offered. Rio's eyes widened in excitement as she nodded ecstatically. “The monitor thing Jen brought is over by the chair.” 

 

As Rio moved to stand the blood pressure cuff fell to the floor from her lap. “Oh, right. Sorry, I got a little distracted.” She quickly retrieved it and slipped the device onto Agatha’s wrist, turning it on before running over to grab the monitor. “Where are we at?” She asked as she fumbled with the device.

 

“122/80” Agatha replied as she tore the cuff from her wrist.

 

“Amazing! That’s the best read yet today. Crazy what some rest will do!” Rio applauded as she turned the heart monitor on. “Alright, lift her up!” Rio instructed as she knelt down again in front of Agatha. As Agatha peeled back the hem of her shirt Rio leaned in, pressing a kiss to the swell before squirting a small, heart shaped glob of gel onto the surface. Once the wand made contact with her stomach the screen lit up, clearly reading the rapid beats within but no sound resonated. “Huh, well, that’s a little underwhelming.” Rio scrunched her face in disappointment as she started pressing buttons at random.

 

Agatha frowned as she reached for the device. “Here, let me see.” She turned the device over in her hands until she found a small wheel on the side that she began to scroll. As the wheel turned under her finger tip the rhythmic sounds of her son’s heartbeat began to grow louder through the small speaker. “There, we just needed to turn the volume up.” 

 

“Jeeze! And I’m the one who went to medical school.” Rio scoffed as she slapped a hand to her forehead. 

 

“Well, we can’t be good at everything, right dear?” Agatha snickered

 

“Touché!” Rio chuckled as she took the device back from Agatha. “140, nice and steady.” As she looked down she saw a ripple dance across Agatha’s taught skin. “Woah, and strong! Just like his mama!” She beamed, “Did… did that hurt?”

 

“No!” Agatha laughed “it definitely feels weird though.”

 

“Alright little man, that’s enough showing off, time to settle in for the night.” Rio said as she set the monitor down and wiped the residue from Agatha’s stomach with her sleeve before pressing another kiss to the surface. 

 

Agatha’s heart swelled with an overwhelming warmth. How could she have been so lucky, so fortunate to have found this indescribably wonderful person exactly when she needed her. 

 

“Thank you.” She uttered as she lowered her shirt. 

 

“For what?” Rio chuckled as she helped Agatha up from the couch. 

 

“For everything. I…I couldn’t imagine doing any of this without you.” she admitted in a rare moment of vulnerability.

 

“Of course! Anything for you, my love.” She leaned in, drawing Agatha’s lips into hers. She filled the touch with every drop of tenderness and love her body could summon. As she pulled away gently she caught Agatha’s swimming, crystal blue irises and wiped away the single tear that had fallen. “I am forever grateful that fate brought you to me!”

 

————————————————



The next day as Agatha left for work she was pleasantly surprised to not be greeted by another terrible gift from Evanora. She had enough to occupy her mind between all the urgent work still needed for the festival and their impending meeting with Victoria to sort through their plan for dealing with her lawsuit that afternoon. And, thanks to whatever magic Rio had worked, she had been able to have a restful night cradled in her arms as her son rested peacefully within her. 

 

The day passed by quickly as she was pulled from meeting to meeting, reviewing companies, interviewing vendors, and revising plans to submit to the city. Thanks to Sharon she had been able to manage it all and somehow find time for lunch in the midst of all the chaos. As her final meeting drew to a close she was practically counting down the seconds until Rio would come to pick her up to head to meet the lawyer. 

 

“We’ve accounted for a second stage at the rear of the building and the west side entrance will host the murals and interactive light display. Food and craft vendors will be located along the street leading up to the main entrance and on either side of the East corridor. The fire marshal has aligned to stationing performers along the main entrance so long as they’re not blocking any of the exits. Then, of course we’ll have the fire department and paramedics stationed at both the front and rear of the building. I think we have all our bases covered. Am I forgetting anything?” Herb asked as he ran through the final plans. 

 

“Are we still keeping the entry hall open to the public throughout all of this?” Agatha questioned, raising an eyebrow in concern.

 

“That’s the plan.” Herb replied as his focus remained on the map in front of him.

 

“How exactly are we going to accommodate for the sound during the performances in the main theatre, let alone account for anyone who has or hasn’t purchased a ticket?” She glared, annoyed at having to point out the obvious flaws in this plan. 

 

“I have some ideas but that is still something we’ll have to work out with the management company. We’ll definitely have to get creative. Speaking of, have you had a chance to read over the final proposals?” Herb asked eagerly.

 

“I skimmed through them during lunch. I think there’s only one that’s going to be able to pull together what we need in time but it’s not going to be cheap. It’s nearly $25,000 over what we were planning to spend, which wouldn’t be an issue if we hadn’t had to hire that marketing company.” Agatha sassed, reminding him of their not so unfortunate loss.

 

“Is there anything we can afford to cut?” Herb pried, hoping to find some leeway. 

 

“A few things here and there but the largest cost is going to be staffing and with all that we have planned we can’t afford to skimp on workers. This proposal at least includes the additional security we will absolutely need given how open this whole thing is. The last thing we want is for any sort of disturbance to break out and ruin the whole series of events we’ve painstakingly planned.” Agatha explained.

 

“What does finance say?” Herb asked, undeterred.

 

“It’s really a choice of do we invest everything now in this event and likely forgo a guest artist in the winter season or take several steps back, pair down the vendors to the one street and take out the second stage to come in under the currently allotted budget.” Agatha proposed, though she could see the hesitancy in Herb’s expression.

 

“You know me, I’m going to say risk it because I think we’ll get more return on this investment. If we lose a guest artist in the winter, so be it.” He threw his hands up in surrender. 

 

“You’re really willing to lose a guest artist we’ve already had sign a contract?” She pressed, reminding him of their current obligation.

 

“If it comes to it I’ll talk with legal and see what our options are there. We’ve come too far not to do this properly.” Herb insisted.

 

Just then there was a small knock at the door before Sharon appeared in the doorway. “Ms. Harkness, your ride is here for your next appointment.” she whispered cheerily. 

 

“Thank you Sharon. Tell her I’ll be out in a minute.” She replied as she waved her out. Sharon nodded before quietly closing the door behind her. “If you’re comfortable taking that risk send the agreement over to legal for one final read through before we lock in. I’ll have Sharon take the plans over to the city this afternoon so hopefully we’ll get the approval by the end of the week. I’ll let finance know our decision once everything is signed.” She said as she began gathering her things.

 

“It will be worth it in the end, I promise! I know it’s been no small feat on your part to get to this point so thank you for everything you’ve done to get us here.” Herb praised, hoping to get some excitement out of her. 

 

“Well, it is my job. You know this is only the beginning right? Once everything is settled is when the real work starts, actually making it all happen and hoping it comes together in time.” Her eyebrows raised in caution as she heaved herself from the chair.  

 

“I do and I understand the pressure that puts on you so please don’t hesitate to delegate. Let me know what’s needed to make this as easy on you as possible.” Herb insisted.

 

“As long as everyone has their shit together it should all fall into place. I don’t want to be chasing people down to do what they’re supposed to do. That goes double for the artists and musicians.” She warned as she made her way to the door.

 

“You have my word, I’ll stay on top of them. Take care, I’ll see you tomorrow with a signed agreement.” Herb said as he closed the door behind her. 




Agatha let out a deep sigh as she headed down the hallway towards her office. She was glad to have aligned on a management company and have the finalized festival plans in hand but now her mind was swimming with the ever growing list of tasks that were now laid before her. It was like battling a hydra, for every feat she accomplished 3 or 4 more popped up in its place. Though the end was in sight it was clear that the demands would only increase as the festival grew closer. As she neared Sharon’s desk she could hear Rio’s effervescent laugh echoing down the hallway, the light, bubbling joy already setting her swirling mind at ease. 

 

“What’s got you so giddy?” She asked with a smirk as she rounded the corner, finding Rio perched atop Sharon’s desk. 

 

“There you are, my love!” Rio shouted as her face lit up with joy at seeing Agatha. “Sharon was just telling me about her grandson’s first soccer game.” she explained.

 

“He got too excited when he finally got the ball and ended up scoring into his own team’s  goal.” Sharon elaborated. 

 

“Cute.” Agatha snorted as she made her way to her office, breezing past them both.

 

“Are you ready to go?” Rio asked as she hopped up from Sharon’s desk to follow her.

 

“Nearly, just putting away some things and then I’ll need to run to the restroom on our way out.” 

 

“Why don’t I go grab the car and meet you out front?” Rio suggested

 

“That works, I still have to go over some stuff with Sharon anyway.” Agatha shrugged in agreement.

 

“Alright, I’ll see you downstairs in a few!” Rio snuck a kiss onto Agatha’s cheek before bounding out the door. Agatha couldn’t help but smile after her as she headed back out to Sharon’s desk.

 

“Here are the final plans we need to submit to the city. Can you drop them off on your way home today? Their office closes at five so you’ll want to head out soon. I also need to set up another meeting with finance for tomorrow. We’ve made our final selection and I’ll need to give them a heads up that we will indeed be going over budget so we’ll need to review some of our plans for the rest of the year.”

 

“Of course, dear! Is there anything else you need?” Sharon asked as she took the file from Agatha.

 

“Yes, actually. Rio had mentioned you were asking about a baby shower?” Agatha’s eyes narrowed with warning suspicion. 

 

“I…yes, well…I hadn’t heard anything” Sharon babbled, feeling the weight of Agatha’s stare. “and…I know at least a few people here have expressed interest in throwing something together for you…” 

 

“Really?” Agatha frowned in skeptical disbelief. 

 

“I warned them that it might not be something you’re up for with everything else going on so the suggestion was to see if you had a registry or anything else in place that people could contribute to instead.” she rushed to explain. 

 

“And you didn’t think to ask me directly?” Agatha asked, pursing her lips in annoyed disappointment. 

 

“I…I just happened to catch Rio when she brought you lunch the other day. It was top of mind. I’m so sorry if I overstepped.” Sharon’s eyes began to well with fear and regret. The poor woman was quickly crumbling under her interrogation and for once Agatha chose to take pity on her.

 

“No, it's…it's alright. I appreciate the thought, but that is the last thing I want. I don’t need these people involved in my personal life any more than they already are. Just let them know the best gift they can give me is to buckle down and make sure this festival goes off without a hitch. I don’t need to be putting out any unnecessary fires.”

 

“Yes…yes, of course! I completely understand. I’ll make sure that’s clearly communicated.” Sharon sighed in relief that she hadn’t just been chewed out. 

 

“Good. I’ll see you bright and early tomorrow then.” Agatha slid on her sunglasses and turned to leave.    

 

—----------------------------------------



“How was your day, my love?” Rio asked as they set off for their meeting.

 

“Exhausting as usual but I think we’re in a good place with everything. How about you?”

 

“Relatively uneventful which I’ll take any day of the week. I did get to talk with Lilia, she’s looking forward to talking with you. I suggested we meet up next weekend, depending on how you’re feeling of course.” Agatha could hear the excitement in her voice. 

 

“That should be fine as long as she’s not going to pull any stunts this time.” She smirked knowingly at Rio. 

 

“I warned her to be on her best behavior and she seemed amiable to the idea so I think we’re in the clear.” Rio smiled, “How are you feeling about this meeting?”

 

Agatha let out a deep sigh as she shifted her mental gears to the task ahead. “I’m interested to hear what Val has to say. None of this makes sense, why would she go through all that trouble to get me to sign the documents and take possession of the house if she was just going to sue me for it?”

 

“Exactly! And where did she even get this new document? The whole thing is suspicious to say the least. Between that and the presents I can’t understand what her end goal is.” Rio shook her head in irritated confusion.

 

“To torture me one way or another. That’s always been her goal. For whatever reason she can never just leave me be.” Agatha rolled her eyes in annoyance.

 

“We’re going to figure that out one way or another, I promise.” Rio reassured, grabbing Agatha’s hand and bringing it to her lips for a kiss. “Having her hovering over you like this is only adding more stress for you and the baby. Speaking of, when was the last time you checked your blood pressure?” Rio glanced over at Agatha with a sly smile across her lips. 

 

Agatha groaned, “Ugh, not since this morning before I left. I accidentally left the cuff on the counter.” 

 

“You know, I thought this looked familiar.” Rio smirked as she pulled the cuff out of the center console. 

 

“Ugh…seriously?” Agatha whined at seeing the device. 

 

“Yes, seriously.” Rio chuckled, “Go ahead, let's see where we’re at.” she insisted as she handed the device over to Agatha.

 

She reluctantly secured it around her wrist before turning it on then laid her head back against the headrest and closed her eyes. She took a few calming breaths before the monitor beeped. “125/80” she announced as she ripped the cuff from her wrist and threw it on the floor before laying back once again. 

 

Rio tilted her head in consideration. “Ok, not great but also not the worst it’s been. I wouldn’t say it’s unexpected, given the day, but we’ve got to work on getting you to relax.” 

 

“I am relaxed.” She grumbled, opening one eye to glare at Rio. 

 

“Maybe like meditation or something?” Rio continued, ignoring the side eye.

 

“Mediation my ass” she mumbled under her breath

 

“Have you ever tried it?” Rio asked

 

“Once and I did not enjoy it!” Agatha groused

 

“Then it’s definitely worth another shot. We can do it together to start out.” Rio suggested encouragingly.

 

“I can think of a few other things we could do together that would be far more stress relieving than sitting still and listening to endless ambient music.” Agatha proposed as her hand wandered down to Rio’s leg. 

 

“Oh that is definitely on the table, but I was thinking more of what you might be able to incorporate throughout the day when you have stressful moments that pop up. Like having to meet with your lawyer over what I’m sure is a frivolous lawsuit.” She elaborated as they pulled into a parking space outside the law office. “You ready for this?”

 

“I can’t tell if it’s going to make me feel better or worse but I’m ready to get this over with.” Agatha sighed as she started to get out of the car.





As they entered the brick business complex Agatha could already feel anger and frustration bubbling within her. On the way up in the elevator she bit her cheek in annoyance, stewing over the fact that her mother had gone to such lengths that she had to take time out of her day to deal with her bullshit. Sensing her irritation Rio placed a hand against her back and began rubbing calming circles in an attempt to soothe her nerves. Agatha sighed leaning into the touch as she rested her head against Rio’s shoulder for comfort. Rio smiled as she glanced over at Agatha, her eyes closed as she let herself succumb to the embrace. Despite the pressure of the situation, they were each grateful for this brief moment of peace. 



When at last they stepped through the glass doors to Valentina’s office they were greeted by a bubbly young 20-something who dropped her phone and whatever app she was doomscrolling on to pop up from her desk and acknowledge them. 

 

“Hey! You must be Ms. Harkness! I’m Ali, so nice to meet you. Val’s wrapping up another meeting but I’ll let her know you’re here. Can I get either of you something to drink while you're waiting? Tea, coffee, Bubbly?” She prattled, clearly having had one to many energy drinks for how late it was in the day.

 

“No thank you, I’m fine.” Agatha grumbled, taken aback by her youthful exuberance. 

 

“No, I’m good. Thanks!” Rio replied with a smile. 

 

“Cool! Then I’ll be right back, feel free to have a seat and get comfortable. She’ll be out to get you in a few minutes.” 

 

Agatha flashed Rio a cringing smile as they moved to the plush array of waiting chairs. She collapsed into the nearest chair with a grunt, before crossing her arms around her bump where her son was practically swimming laps within her, the movement aligning with the nervous energy she was doing her best to contain. 

Rio settled into the chair next to her, her eyes carefully observing the building tension hovering around her. The way her foot bounced in rhythm to soundless music, the tapping of her fingers on her arms, the way she was practically chewing a hole into her own lips. She hated the distress this whole situation caused her. She stretched a hand across to rest on Agatha’s knee, pouring calm and stillness into the limb. 

At the touch, Agatha released an arm and clutched at Rio's hand, aching for her steady grounding presence to keep her tethered to the moment instead of lost in the chaos that her mind was spinning. 

 

Before long the office door opened once again revealing Valentina. A shorter woman with wavy shoulder length dark brown hair that featured her signature streak of silver at the front which swooped down framing her sharp features. Her well fitted navy pantsuit gave the air of the no-nonsense lawyer she was but the smile she gave Agatha and Rio was warm and reassuring, providing Agatha with a sense of calming confidence as they stood to meet her. 

 

“Agatha! So good to see you again, though I wish it was under different circumstances.” Valentina leaned in to give Agatha a quick hug. “And look at you! I had no idea! Congratulations!”

 

“Oh, thank you.” Agatha replied bashfully as she ghosted a hand along the swell.

 

“And who have you brought with you?” Valentina asked, glancing at Rio. 

 

“This is my girlfriend, Rio.” She turned introducing her. 

 

“Nice to meet you!” Rio said as she took Val’s hand. 

 

“Well, if you’ll follow me we’ll head to my office and sort through some things.” Valentina turned abruptly, setting a brisk pace. 



Val led them through the doors and down a long hallway until they reached her office at the end. The room was spacious with floor to ceiling windows on the right hand side overlooking a park just below. The paneled walls held an array of degrees and artwork tastefully arranged around the room. In the center sat a large mahogany desk with a few papers strewn about near the computer. Behind the desk on either side were immense matching wooden bookshelves filled to the brim with volumes of law books. In between them, bathed in the light of a single wall sconce was an enormous painting of Lady Justice carrying scales and brandishing a sword. 

 

“Please, make yourselves comfortable!” Val insisted as she closed the door behind them and rounded her desk to sit across from them. “So I’ve had a chance to review the documents your mother’s lawyer sent over but I want to hear from you first about the situation. Can you tell me a bit about what has led up to this moment?”

 

“Well, you remember a few months back when I sent you those documents my mother and her lawyer had given me?” Val nodded politely, encouraging her to continue. “I did sign them and eventually took possession of the home. Rio and I traveled to Boston to sort through the stuff that was in the house and sold most everything in an estate sale. Well she showed up to that and ended up causing a scene and we had to remove her from the premises. She wasn’t happy that I was selling everything, including the house, so that’s why, I assume, she’s trying to pull this stunt now.” Agatha explained.

 

“The scene she caused was attacking Agatha, by the way.” Rio clarified

 

“Excuse me?” Val asked, eyes bulging in stunned confusion as she looked between the two of them.

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. “It wasn’t like that. She just slapped me.”

 

“Were there any witnesses and did you file a police report?” Val asked as she furiously began scribbling notes.

 

“I along with about 10-15 other people witnessed it. The police were called so there may be an incident report but she didn’t want to press charges.” Rio clarified

 

“That’s…unfortunate but I understand. How recent was this?” Val continued in her questioning though her hand never moved from the paper. 

 

“A few months ago? I didn’t really think anything of it until you called. I should have figured she would retaliate eventually one way or another. She’s relentless.” Agatha groaned

 

“I’m so sorry you’re having to deal with this. While it won’t be easy I do believe we have a strong chance of getting this dismissed next week. With that said, there are a few things I do want to go over with you.” Val shuffled a few folders around on her desk until she found what she was looking for and handed a file over to Agatha. “This is a copy of the document they submitted with the suit. I want to bring your attention to a few things. For one, this looks like a revised document. While that can still be completely legitimate, the date of the revisions has raised some suspicions. This seems to have been aligned to barely a week before your grandfather’s passing.” Val noted, circling the date for her. 

 

Agatha could feel her throat dry and tighten as she attempted to swallow away the lump that had formed in her throat. She hadn’t thought much of her grandfather's passing but seeing the date had stirred a host of complicated feelings within her. “I see,” she choked out, “and…what would that mean for our defense, exactly?” she asked as her eyes carefully scanned the document.

 

“Given that timing it definitely brings into question his testamentary capacity.” Val said, matter of factly, as if the case had already been won.

 

“Meaning?” Rio asked

 

“Was he even competent enough to know what he was agreeing to at the time? I’ve looked into it a bit and he was under hospice care for his last few months. I’m not entirely sure what mental state he was in but I don’t know many 95 year olds on their deathbed that retain their full cognitive capabilities. That, along with the fact that she and her lawyer were the ones who presented you with the original documents weakens their claims.” She elaborated

 

“Thats been my question. Why did they even involve Agatha in the first place if they had this document?” Rio asked

 

“I’d been wondering the same thing myself. My best guess is someone had misplaced or misfiled this document and they had to comply with what was on file at the time of his death. Now having recovered it she wants to pursue her claim.” Val reasoned.

 

“But you do think this is a real document, not something she forged?” Rio questioned

 

“That was my initial thought but the signature, to a reasonable extent, matches that of your grandfather. He did sign this.” Val confirmed.

 

Agatha glanced over the document in her hand again and again as she recalled the original conversation with her mother. “ There are a few items I would like to collect... ” She mumbled to herself

 

“What was that, my love?” Rio asked, placing a hand on her arm to draw her attention back into the room.

 

“She had been so insistent about me signing the documents and going to the house. This must have been what she was after!” Agatha exclaimed as the dots finally clicked into place.

 

“Ah, that very well may have been the case! With you listed as the beneficiary she would not have been able to gain access to the property without your permission.” Val explained

 

“What a conniving little cunt!” Rio scoffed in disbelief

 

“Now, beyond getting this dismissed,” Val continued, ignoring the brash remark, “Are you wanting to pursue a counter suit? I will let you know, based on what you’ve told me, you would likely have a solid case.” 

 

“I don’t know that I want to give her the satisfaction of that attention.” Agatha grumbled as she slammed the folder back down on the desk.

 

“I can’t blame you; however, I would really like you to consider it. We’d have until Friday to file and it would likely get resolved the same day so it’s not like you would have to return to court and see her again.” Val urged.

 

“It’s more of the fact that I don’t want anything from her other than for her to leave me alone. I’m so tired of dealing with her incessant prodding and poking into my life!” she whimpered in growing frustration.

 

“That can be built into the request. It would be more difficult for her to appeal that type of order as well and it would likely come with heavy penalties, up to and including jail time.” Val clarified

 

“I think that’s more what we’re looking for.” Rio replied as she reached for Agatha’s hand in comfort. “Her constant harassment of Agatha is adding additional stress at a time when she needs rest and peace for her and the baby’s health.” 

 

“How constant are we talking?” Val asked, her eyebrows raised with piqued interest as she drew her pen into her hand again, ready to take notes.

 

Agatha and Rio exchanged glances. “She’s been sending gifts .” Agatha admitted

 

“Ok, interesting. Can you elaborate?” she asked, once again scribbling furiously

 

“The last few days I’ve received a series of… gifts, for the baby. A stuffed animal, a bible, a christening gown. All of which have found their way into the trash.” Agatha explained

 

“Huh, interesting. How exactly is she going about this?” Val questioned without ceasing her notetaking. 

 

“The first one showed up at my office. The second one tried to and I refused the delivery so she sent it to my house along with a third one the next day.” 

 

“And when did this start?” Val continued in her questioning.

 

“Last Friday. They’ve been showing up almost daily. So far nothing's appeared today but there’s still time.” Agatha replied

 

“That’s… convenient .” Val commented, flashing her eyes in knowing concern.

 

“How do you mean?” Rio asked, her face scrunched in curious concern.

 

“Well, that’s the day after we had received our court date. Not that it means anything but the timing is…interesting.” Val reasoned

 

“It does feel like an ominous threat. It’s like her way of intimidating Agatha, letting her know she’s still keeping my tabs on her.” Rio explained, watching Agatha sitting in silent contemplation, clearly working through all this new information.

 

“Had you told her about the pregnancy when she came to you in Boston?” Val asked.

 

“No, actually, at the time I didn’t even know I was pregnant.” Agatha whispered, her mind still transfixed on the lengths Evanora was going through to torture her.
