“She would have had no way of knowing if she wasn’t stalking her.” Rio insisted

 

“I see.” Val said as she continued to write. “I hate to be insistent upon this but I would be remiss if I didn’t bring up the counter suit again. Given your concerns I feel it would be the best way to resolve these issues with your mother. With all of this information we’ll get her suit dismissed and likely be able to institute a protective order.”

 

“What do you say, cariño?” Rio asked, rubbing her hand along Agatha’s arm.

 

Agatha glanced back at Rio, seeing caring encouragement in her eyes. “If it gets her out of my life once and for all then let’s do it.” she agreed

 

“Fantastic! I’ll get the paperwork submitted to the court tomorrow. Do you have any other questions for me?” Val asked

 

“No, I don’t believe so.” Agatha shook her head.

 

“Alright! Then I’ll see you bright and early at 8:00 at the courthouse a week from today. If there’s anything that pops up in the meantime don’t be afraid to reach out.” Val offered as she rose from her desk to see them out.

 

“Thank you as always for your help. Hopefully this will be the end of it.” Agatha replied as she and Rio headed for the door.

 

“I’ll do my best to ensure it is. You two have a good night!” Val said as she closed the door behind them.




They walked in silence back down the hallway and through to reception. Ali chipperly waved them out to which Agatha didn’t respond and Rio merely smiled. As they stepped back into the elevator Rio reached out, catching Agatha’s hand. 

 

“It’s going to be alright, my love.” She murmured, hoping to soften the anxieties she could see written across her face. 

 

Agatha sighed, letting a weak smile dance across her lips. “It will be…eventually.” she replied as she turned to take in Rio’s glowing amber eyes. “I have you after all.” she hummed.

 

Rio’s heart fluttered at that. The smile that radiated from her was impossible to contain. “Always, my love.” She leaned in, taking Agatha’s lips tenderly into hers, savoring the sweet moment between them in the midst of this debacle. As the elevator dinged their arrival she pulled away, taking Agatha once again by the hand and led them both out of the building. Once they approached the car Agatha could sense something amiss in the air around them. As Agatha moved to enter the vehicle she froze suddenly, her heart pounding as fury began to quickly build within her. Blinded by rage she let out a curdling shriek, 

“AHHHHhhhhhhAAHHHHHAAAH!”

 

In a panic Rio rushed to her side. “Agatha, what is it!? Are you ok? Is it the baby?”

 

“She fucking knew I was here!” Agatha shouted as she began to pace.

 

“What!?” Rio panted, her nerves still set on edge by the reaction.

 

“My mother, she knew I would be here!” She elaborated as she pointed to what had sparked her anger. Rio turned, eyes following the direction of Agatha’s finger to land on another carefully wrapped present sitting on the ground just beside the passenger door. 

Chapter End Notes

Court with Evanora in the next chapter and you are not ready! Again, I will try to get it up as soon as I can but life it lifeing so we'll see when that will be. I truly appreciate each and every one of you that is still following along on this wild journey. There is so much to come and I can't wait to share it with you!

Chapter 24: The Court Date

Chapter Summary

Agatha and Rio face Evanora in Court

Chapter Notes

So glad to finally post this chapter it's been a battle. Warning - Evanora doesn't mince words. ALSO this courtroom scene is for entertainment purposes only. The extent of my legal knowledge is from Law and Order SV-University and a mentorship under Judge Judith Scheindlin so please don't @ me for legal inaccuracies. This is just supposed to be fun and dramatic so I hope you enjoy!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The day broke too early that morning. It had been a restless night of tossing and turning and Agatha’s mind was awash with anxious anticipation about the day ahead in court. Seeing her mother again after all she had been putting her through, and the now nightly routine of getting up every few hours to relieve herself as her son continued to take up every available space within her left her depleted and overwhelmed. When the alarm sounded she whimpered with exhaustion as she quickly silenced it then rolled back over to snuggle into Rio’s side. 

 

“Morning, cariño.” Rio grumbled sleepily as she wrapped her arms around her. “Did you get any sleep last night?” 

 

“Ugh, barely. My mind was working a million miles a minute then every time I finally got comfortable I had to get up to pee. I don’t know how I’m going to do two more months of this!” She groaned.

 

“Well hopefully after we kick your mothers ass in court today it’ll help quiet your mind.” She leaned down, kissing the crown of Agatha’s head. “As for this little guy…All the trouble you’re causing!” she brushed her hand against the swell, feeling him stretch and move as if waking for the day with them. “It won’t be much longer, my love, then we’ll get to hold him in our arms.” 

 

“It can’t come soon enough!” She grumbled as she buried herself deeper into Rio’s side. Rio squeezed her in close, peppering kisses on her head before she began shifting to rise. “No! Just ten more minutes please!” Agatha whined as her grip tightened around Rio’s waist. 

 

“Ten more minutes? I don’t know, I can already hear Scratchy trying to break down the door.” Rio chuckled 

 

“He can wait, I just need you for a little while longer.” Agatha batted her icy blue eyes up at Rio, her lip bending down into a pitiful pout. 

 

“Oh really? You’re going to use that face on me?” Rio snorted, well aware that this was a battle she was quickly losing. 

 

“Is it working?” Agatha’s pout broke at the corners into a smirk. 

 

“How about this, we can snuggle for a few more minutes if you meditate with me.” Rio offered.

 

Agatha’s face fell into a blank, annoyed stare. “Really?” 

 

“We’ll be laying here anyway, we have a tough day ahead. Now’s the perfect time to calm the mind and focus our energies.” Rio smiled, closing her eyes as if blissfully at peace. 

 

Agatha rolled her eyes “If it buys me ten more minutes in bed with you I’ll do it.” 

 

Rio reached for her phone and scrolled to find a guided meditation. Soon the sounds of crashing waves poured out through the speakers as a deep soothing voice called for them to close their eyes and breathe deeply. Always one to be defiant, Agatha’s eyes remained open and drifted up to observe Rio. Her sleep tossed hair curled and tangled around her face, the rosy flushness of her cheeks which still bore the slight imprint of where the pillow had been pressed against her face, the subtle flair of her nostrils and the rise and fall of her chest as she breathed in time with the instructor. She was a vision of warm serenity and to be wrapped in her arms, sheer bliss. As her gaze drifted down to Rio’s plump, delicate lips she caught a smile breaking through. 

“I can feel you staring.” Rio mumbled. “Close your eyes, Agatha.” she drew her hand up and slid her fingers down Agatha’s face, forcing her eyes closed. 

Agatha at last accepted her fate, resting her head on Rio’s chest as she took a deep breath in time with her. As the waves continued to crash and Rio’s heartbeat sounded in her ear, she could feel a sense of calm begin to creep over her. As she continued to breathe slowly, deeply, inhaling Rio’s warm, earthy fragrance, the knot of anxiety in her own chest started to loosen. She felt safe and at home cradled against her and she couldn’t imagine ever leaving this moment. Slowly, the waves began to fade and a hushed quiet filled the room, the only sounds remaining were the soft pulses of their breathing and Scratchy's urgent pawing at the door. 

 

“How do you feel, my love?” Rio’s voice washed over her in a whisper as she felt her lips brush against her head. 

 

“Like I could fall asleep. Do we have to get up? I don’t want to go!” Agatha whined 

 

“I know, cariño,” Rio hitched a finger under Agatha’s chin, drawing her face upward as she pressed a kiss to her lips. “But we must! Don’t want to keep your mother waiting.” She chuckled as she pried herself from Agatha’s grip and rolled out of bed.  

 

“Ugh I still can’t fucking believe she’s doing this! Why did I have to be cursed with such a horrible mother?” Agatha groused as she pounded her fists into the bed. 

 

“Well hopefully after today the curse will be broken. I’m going to hop in the shower really quick then whip up breakfast. Anything specific sound good?” Rio asked as she padded over to sit beside Agatha at the edge of the bed. 

 

“Do we have any more of that bread we got at the market on Sunday?” Agatha asked, biting the tip of her finger as she pondered what she wanted. 

 

“If you didn’t have a midnight snack then I believe we have a couple slices left.” Rio replied

 

“Ok then” Agatha smiled deliciously as she began to rattle off her request, “toast with some of the guacamole you made last night with two eggs, some of those spicy pickled peppers and onions and top it with maple syrup and chocolate chips.” 

 

Rio snickered to herself, “Alright, anything else?” 

 

“If we have any of those frozen cherries will you make us a smoothie?” She added, biting her lip and batting her eyes in playful pleading. 

 

“Us, huh?” Rio snorted as she rested a hand on Agatha’s belly. “Does he want it with the chocolate almond milk like last time?” 

 

“Ooo! Yes and cinnamon!” Agatha gleamed with delight.

 

“Of course!” Rio smiled as she pressed a kiss to the swell. “Hungry this morning, are we?” She murmured as she guided her hands along the surface, feeling his morning stretches just beneath Agatha’s skin. 

 

“Starving, actually.” Agatha grunted as she tried to sit up. 

 

“Well, then I’d better get moving!” Rio chuckled as she helped Agatha sit at the edge of the bed. “You good?” She asked, seeing her twinge in discomfort. 

 

“Yeah, just letting things settle. Go on, I’ll be in in a minute, I’m going to feed Scratchy.” 

 

“I can go feed him now if that’s easier.” Rio offered

 

“No, I’ve got this!” She insisted as she rose to stand, wobbling a bit as she adjusted to her center of gravity. 

 

“Careful!” Rio urged as she reached to hold Agatha steady. 

 

“Rio, I’m fine! Go take a shower!” Agatha insisted as she brushed her away. 

 

“Alright, alright! I’ll be out in a flash.” She winked before sneaking a kiss onto Agatha’s cheek and then scurried away. 



Agatha waddled down the hallway wincing a bit as her joints creaked and popped, waking with each step. Scratchy followed closely behind, mewling loudly as he waited impatiently for his breakfast. 

“I know mister! I’m working on it, if you hadn’t noticed I’m moving a little slower these days.” Scratchy replied with an insistent rippling screech as he butted his head against her legs. 

“Here!” she groaned as she squatted down, placing the bowl in front of him. “You’re going to have to learn some patience here sir! You’re not going to be the center of attention for much longer.” She warned him as she stroked her hand through his fur, wrapping his fluffy tail around her finger. 

She moved to stand, having to grip the edge of the counter to pull herself up. She groaned as she straightened, feeling the familiar ache in her back as her son rolled to press at her side. Her hand met his movement as the other worked to relieve the tension in her back. 

“Good morning, little bug. You have enough room in there?” She hummed, rubbing circles against the surface. “Are you as ready for this day to be over as I am?” She felt a resounding nudge press against her palm. “I know, your grandmother is a piece of work isn’t she!” She shuddered as the word left her mouth. “Don’t worry, this should be the only time you ever have to deal with her. We just have to get through today.” She said more to herself than him as she waddled back down the hallway. 




A shower and three outfit changes later Agatha burst from the bedroom in a flowy, long-sleeved lilac dress, unzipped and hovering on the edge of her shoulders. Her cascading hair was still damp in places and half pinned up on the left side as if she had started to fix it and gave up halfway through. She had one shoe on and was hobbling down the hallway towards Rio. 

 

“Need help, cariño?” Rio chuckled seeing her disheveled state. 

 

“Yes! I can’t find the other shoe, I can’t get this fucking dress zipped, and my hair just isn’t cooperating today! If this is any sign of how the rest of the day is going to go I’m going to call it now and crawl back into bed.” Agatha sighed shakily, on the verge of tears. 

 

“Mi amor! Come here!” Rio urged soothingly with outstretched arms. Agatha stumbled forward and let herself be wrapped into Rio’s embrace. 

 

“I don’t think I can do this!” She shuddered into her shoulder. “It’s all too much right now!” 

 

“Take a deep breath.” Rio urged. They breathed in synchronicity as Rio held her close. “We just have to get through today and it will all be over.” She released Agatha, pulling her away so she could cradle her face in her hands. “And I’ll be right there with you.” She drew her thumb across her cheek wiping away a few stray tears. “You’ve got this!” Agatha cracked a smile as she nodded, wiping away the last of the tears. “Turn around, let me help you with the dress.” 

 

Agatha turned slowly, pulling her fallen locs to the side to give Rio better access. She felt her warm hands brace her shoulders and the back of her neck tickled as she felt Rio’s lips kiss along her hairline before she tugged the zipper closed. Rio’s hands then returned to her shoulders as she invited her to turn back around. 

 

“There’s one problem solved and you look absolutely stunning!” Agatha blushed at the compliment as she rolled her eyes in disbelief. “Now I will admit, I have no talent when it comes to hair so I’m not even going to attempt to put it up for you, but I will say it drives me absolutely wild in its natural state.” She reached up, unpinning the few strands Agatha had managed to conquer. “Fuck that’s hot! Your mother will be lucky if I don’t take you right there in the courtroom!” 

 

“Rio!” Agatha chided, though her bashful smirk betrayed her. 

 

“As for the shoes, why don’t you take a seat and have some breakfast and I’ll look for the missing one.” She nodded over to the counter where Agatha’s earlier order was waiting for her. 

 

“What did I ever do to deserve you?” Agatha sighed as she headed for her seat, mouth practically drooling at the sight.

 

“You put up with this clingy dork!” Rio chuckled as she kissed Agatha’s cheek on her way to search the bedroom. “Eat! We have to leave in like 10 minutes!” Rio warned as she disappeared through the door. 

 

Agatha quickly devoured the meal and before long Rio reemerged with the missing shoe. “Where did you find it?” She gasped as she took her empty plate to the sink. 

 

“It was hiding!” Rio smirked, scrunching her nose. “I had looked through everything and couldn’t find it, then I decided to think like a shoe.”

 

“Think like a shoe?” Agatha snorted, her eyebrows raised in astonished amusement.

 

“Yeah, I got down on the floor, you know, shoe height, crawled around to some of the obvious corners and then I spotted it right under the bed.” She tossed the shoe to Agatha. “Hate to say you never would have found it.” 

 

“Only you would know to think like a shoe and actually find it!” Agatha laughed as she dropped the shoe to the floor and wedged her foot into it.

 

“You ready?” Rio asked as she grabbed the keys

 

“As I’ll ever be.” Agatha groaned as she headed for the door. Rio caught her along the way, taking her hand in hers as she moved to open the door for them both. As it swung wide Agatha’s face began to contort in anger as yet another “gift” had miraculously appeared overnight, blocking their exit. 

 

“I swear I’m going to kill her!” Agatha grunted through gritted teeth. Rio peered around the door to find an ornate wooden cradle placed against the threshold with a sign tented in the center that read, See you later, dear , scrawled in scripted writing. “This is the last straw!” She roared as she tried to push it away unsuccessfully to which Rio waved her out of the way.

 

“Damn this thing is heavy as fuck!” Rio groaned as she lifted it just enough for them to pass. “What the hell is it even made of, lead?”

 

“It’s kingwood.” Agatha corrected as she stared, disgusted at the sight.

 

“How do you know that?” Rio turned to her in shock

 

“Because I sold it at the estate sale. It had been in the family for generations.” Agatha explained flippantly

 

“You’re kidding! She tracked it down and dumped it at your doorstep?!” Rio exclaimed

 

“More than likely she paid someone to buy it for her. She’s surprisingly sentimental, though not about me.” Agatha replied as she brushed past the object. “Come on, we can deal with it when we get back.” 




The drive to the courthouse was silent as they each pondered the day ahead. Agatha sat, arms crossed above her stomach, stewing over her mother’s latest stunt. Rio drove with both hands gripping the wheel, eyes narrowed on the road as she contemplated the many ways she would enjoy watching Evanora suffer. As Rio rounded the corner to the courthouse she pulled up in front of the monumental staircase, unlocking the doors and moved to open her door. 

 

“What are you doing?” Agatha spat in a panic, grabbing Rio by the arm. 

 

“I thought I’d let you out here so you don’t have to walk as far.” Rio explained

 

“No! No way, I am not going in there without you.” Agatha’s voice trembled with trepidation. 

 

“Oh, ok, no problem. I’ll try and find a spot nearby.” She settled back into her seat and pulled away from the curb. They cycled the block until they found a parking garage and descended 3 floors before they found a spot. As Rio turned off the car she glanced over at Agatha who was busy gnawing at the corner of her lip as she stared off into nothing. 

“Hey,” Rio cooed as she gathered Agatha’s hand in hers. “It’s going to be ok, we’re going to get through this.” 

 

Agatha let a smile creep into the corner of her lips as she broke her stare to catch Rio’s reassuring gaze. “Of course we will, together.” 

Rio beamed as Agatha kissed the edge of her knuckles. “Come on, let’s get this over with.” 

Agatha huffed as she moved to exit the vehicle. Rio hurried out of the car to catch her at the back so they could walk hand in hand to the elevator. They waited for a brief moment before the doors opened and they stepped inside. They pressed the button for the street and just as the doors were about to close a hand shot through the opening and forced them back open. Agatha recoiled in disgust, stepping to the back of the elevator as her mother’s lawyer, Christian, stepped inside. 

 

“Ah! Agatha! I thought that was you. Long time no see.” He said cheerily with a smarmy grin as the doors closed behind him. His oversized grey suit hung loosely on his portly frame though the shirt he had chosen looked ready to bust at the buttons. Agatha said nothing as she glared at him and gripped Rio’s hand tighter. “Well alrighty then.” He rolled his eyes before narrowing in on Rio. “And who might you be?” 

Rio raised an eyebrow to Agatha as she replied confidently, “Dr. Rio Vidal, Agatha’s girlfriend.” She shot her hand forward to shake his, eyeing him directly as she squeezed his hand aggressively enough to cause him to wince. “And you are?” She posed. 

 

“Christian Atwood, opposing counsel.” He replied, shaking his hand loose from her grip. 

 

“Ah! I see. Are you the same Christian who accosted my girlfriend on her porch not too long ago?” She asked, shifting herself to stand slightly in front of Agatha as her hands dipped into her pockets. 

 

“Accosted?” He scoffed, “I think between the two of us she was the aggressor. You’re lucky I didn’t press charges!” He added pointing at Agatha. 

 

“I don’t think luck had anything to do with it.” Rio shrugged. “Would have been an impossible case to win, given she was acting in self defense.” 

 

“Yeah, yeah.” He waived his hand dismissively. “I’ve made a full recovery by the way, if you were wondering.” He spat back at Agatha over Rio’s shoulder.

 

“I wasn’t” Agatha finally grumbled to him.

 

“Oh, she speaks!?” He chuckled mirthlessly, “I hear congratulations are in order,” he said as he eyed her round figure, “though can you really be happy about being an unwed, single mother?”

 

“Man! You really want to lose that other ball don’t you?” Rio growled as she cracked her knuckles.

 

“Rio…” Agatha cautioned

 

“All I’m saying is you’re setting that kid up for failure from the start. Fatherless and a psycho for a mother. It’ll be a miracle if it doesn’t off itself the moment it realizes the fucked up life you’re forcing it to live.” Christian snorted with laughter sending Rio over the edge.

 

Agatha caught her just as she was launching at him which caused him to stumble back through the now open elevator doors and fall flat on his ass. After a moment of shocked silence they both broke into a fit of laughter as he struggled to right himself, face red as a beet with embarrassment, and scurry off down the street. 

 

“Gods, I love instant karma!” Agatha cried as they stepped out of the elevator and started down the street. 

 

“Right?! That guy was more of an asshole than I could have imagined. He’s lucky you were there to stop me, I was ready to beat him to a pulp for talking to you like that! Fuck, I still might.” Rio bounced as she walked, attempting to shake off the adrenaline.

 

“Rio, you promised you wouldn’t.” Agatha warned. 

 

“I know, I know, but damn that shit made my blood boil!” Rio admitted as she tried to refocus herself.

 

“This is only the beginning. We’re in for this shit all day and the best thing you can do is ignore it and not respond. That’s all these people want is for us to react and give them a justification for playing the victim. You can’t let them get to you.” Agatha reminded her.

 

“Ugh, you’re right, I’ll try and reel it in. But best believe if anyone starts anything I will be the one to finish it.” Rio confirmed, matter-of-factly.

 

“By walking away right?” Agatha insisted. 

 

“Yes, dear, by walking away.” Rio rolled her eyes as she reluctantly agreed. 





As they ascended the marble stairs and pushed through the ornate wooden doors of the courthouse, joining the line for the security checkpoint, Agatha’s gaze darted around the hall, her heart raced as she kept an eye out for Evanora. She knew, of course, they would cross paths sooner rather than later yet she didn’t want to be caught off guard by her presence. 

“Any sign of her?” Rio asked, removing her belt and wallet to pass through the metal detector. 

 

“Not yet, but it’s only a matter of time.” Agatha huffed as she waited for Rio to be further inspected by security.

 

“Agatha! There you are!” They each turned abruptly to see Valentina walking towards them. “Glad to see you made it in alright. Any trouble with parking?” 

 

“No, not at all. But we did have the unfortunate displeasure of running into my mothers lawyer on the way in.” Agatha groaned

 

“That dude was way out of fucking line!” Rio bit, still on edge from the earlier confrontation. 

 

“Oh I am all too aware! I’ve run into him in one other case of mine, a civil dispute, and he made the process as long and difficult as he possibly could. It got pretty nasty but we won out in the end.” Agatha and Rio exchanged an anxious look. “Not to worry, we’ve been blessed with Judge Horowitz today and she has zero tolerance for his kind of bullshit.” Agatha sighed a breath of relief at that. “Well, shall we?” Val asked as she beckoned them towards the elevator. Agatha reached for Rio’s hand, hoping her grounding presence would help to reassure the waves of anxiety that were swelling within her as each step drew them nearer to her mother. As the doors closed behind them she could feel a lump beginning to form in her throat as her son danced circles just beneath her skin.

 

“Do you have any fun plans for this weekend?” Val asked, as if today was just another day and not the panic inducing nightmare she had been dreading for weeks. 

 

Luckily Rio wasn’t as burdened by this travesty and was happy to lead the conversation for them both. “We’re supposed to have lunch with my aunt on Sunday and we might try and go shopping for some things for the baby.” 

 

“Oh that should be fun! Do you know what you’re having?” Val asked.

 

“It’s a boy. She’s due at the beginning of June and we’re a little behind on preparation so it may be more of a shopping spree.” Rio explained. 

 

“I remember with my oldest I tried to buy everything I thought I might possibly need and ended up not using half of it. As long as you have the basics to start, clothes, diapers, a place for him to sleep, you’ll figure out the rest as you go!” She gave them a reassuring smile as she led them out of the elevator and down the hallway. “We’re in room 333 and have about 15 minutes before we have to head in. If you need a snack or something to drink there are a few vending machines at the end of that hallway to the right.” Val indicated as they hurried down the corridor. “We’re coming up on our room, if either of you need to use the restroom just continue on and it’s down at the end.” 

 

As they reached the alcove that led to their room Agatha searched but saw no sign of her mother. All she could see was her mother’s lawyer pacing back and forth impatiently, sending a wave of nauseating disgust throughout her body. “I…I think I’m going to head to the restroom.” She announced as she continued down the hall. 

 

“Do you want me to go with you?” Rio offered, seeing the unease in her face.

 

“No…no, I’ll be alright. I’ll be back in a minute.” She continued down the hallway, darting a furious glare at Christian as she passed him along the way. She had warned Rio to contain herself but seeing him again brought a fresh wave of fury to the surface. If she could have squashed his pigheaded face with her mind she would have done so in that very moment. She needed a few minutes alone to refocus herself and cool down before this impending shitstorm began. 

 

She pushed through the restroom doors and darted straight for the sink, hoping the cool water would help relieve the furious tension. As she padded her chest and neck she heard one of the stall doors swing open. She glanced up into the mirror and her heart dropped in horror. 

 

“Well, well, well! There she is! Mother of miraculous conception!” echoed the sinister voice of Evanora against the tiled bathroom walls as she sidled up next to Agatha at the sinks. “My, aren’t we looking fruitful!” Agatha swallowed hard, gaze pointed downward as she clenched her teeth in an effort to contain the rage that was threatening to lash out at the woman standing far too close for comfort. “When I had heard the news I expected this had been a more recent development but you, my dear, look practically ready to bust!” Evanora cackled. Agatha turned away to dry her hands and immediately headed into a stall slamming the door behind her. “Oh! Seems I may have struck a nerve! You’ll need to learn to control that temper of yours before my grandchild arrives. You don’t have the luxury of resorting to tantrums and obscene behaviour like I know you are inclined to.” Agatha remained silent as she sat, refusing to engage in the obvious inflammatory sentiments her mother was spewing, though the words cut deep. “Not speaking are we? Shocking! Very well then, I’ll leave you with this; you may be comfortable living a life of self-serving indulgence and sexual sin but I refuse to allow my grandchild to be corrupted by your moral impropriety. Enjoy motherhood, dear…while you still can. I’ll see you in court.”

 

She held her breath as she heard her mother’s footsteps retreat and the door swing closed behind her. Her heartbeat rushed furiously throughout her body, pounding in her ears as a tingling numbness began to prickle at the tips of her limbs, creeping quickly as her mind began to swirl in a heady dread. She blinked listlessly at the floor in front of her as her breath drew quick and shallow. Evanora’s words hung forebodingly in her mind. Enjoy motherhood while you still can? What did she mean by that? It was clearly a threat but what was she threatening? She braced her arms against her pregnant belly, allowing the swimming hum of her son to soothe her anxieties as best they could. He was there, he was alive, he was safe tucked within her…for the time being. There was nothing her mother could do to change that… could she? As her mind continued to buzz she heard the door swing open vigorously and the panicked shuffling of feet soon after.

 

“Agatha! Are you still in here?” Rio’s voice shouted as she searched the room. 

 

Agatha slowly pressed the stall door open and stepped out. “Rio…” she called out with a wavering quiver in her voice. 

 

Rio turned and rushed to gather her in her arms. “Are you ok? I saw her walk out of here with a smug look on her face and was so worried for you.”

 

“I…I think so...it’s just…she…she said something…” Agatha started, trying to clear her thoughts. 

 

“What did she say to you?” Rio pressed

 

“I think…I don’t know. It didn’t make much sense.” Agatha frowned as she struggled to recall the exact words. 

 

“What did she say!?” Rio commanded, drawing Agatha’s eyes to hers in urgency. 

 

“She told me to enjoy motherhood…while I still can.” Agatha mumbled, still trying to make sense of those words. 

 

Rio’s eyes blazed with fury “What the fuck is that supposed to mean?”

 

“That’s what I’m trying to figure out. It made no sense!” Agatha shook her head frustratedly

 

“It sounds like she was trying to intimidate you, throw you off before we see the judge.” Rio offered as she tumbled the idea over in her head. 

 

“You're probably right. It…It just makes me nervous, like she might be up to something.” Agatha bit her lip anxiously. 

 

“Something other than suing you for the house?” Rio scrunched her face in confusion. 

 

“I don’t know, it was just so odd, even for her, which is saying something.”  

 

Just then Val pushed through into the room. “Everything alright in here? It’s time to head in.”

 

Agatha sucked a breath in, readying herself for further mind games. “Yeah…yeah, right of course. We… we should go.”

 

“Are you sure you’re ok?” Rio asked, stopping her as she turned away.

 

“Yeah, I’ll be fine once this is all put to rest.” Agatha insisted. 

 

Rio’s eyes darted between Agatha’s ocean blue orbs, worried but determined. “Alright, Agatha. I’m right behind you.” 





As they stepped into the courtroom Agatha could feel all eyes turn on them. There were a smattering of people in the pews, none of whom she recognized save for the row of seven women who sat directly behind Evanora, all clad in black as if they were crows hovering on a telephone line. Each of their eyes bore judgement and fury as she and Rio made their way to the desk at the front. Her mother’s lawyer was bumbling about, shuffling along papers as he tried to sort himself out. A grey dusty stain still present on the seat of his pants from his earlier fall. Her mother sat stoic and unyielding, her modest grey dress pressed to perfection, hair pulled tightly into a bun, and her eyes fixed on the judges bench before them, as if Agatha’s appearance were merely happenstance and beneath her acknowledgement. 

 

Just as they were settling in, the bailiff called them all to attention, “All rise for the honorable Judge Horowitz.” They each stood as an older woman, who couldn’t have been more than five feet tall, shuffled into the room. Her short, curly auburn hair a cloud around her face. She wore large black spectacles which made her eyes the size of golf balls and she practically disappeared in the black judges cloak she was wearing.

 

“Thank you, you may be seated.” She mumbled into the microphone. There was a moment of silence as she re-read over the case before her before speaking again. “Alright, I see we have here Harkness v Harkness. That’s going to make things quite confusing. Who is representing the plaintiff?”

 

“That would be me, your honor.” Christian replied, standing to address the judge.

 

“Hmm, I see.” She mumbled, seemingly annoyed as she scribbled something down. “That must mean you are representing the defendant, Ms. Fontaine?”

 

“That is correct, your honor.” Val replied

 

“And you are bringing a counter claim as well?” The judge confirmed. 

 

“Indeed your honor.”

 

“Well let’s sort this matter first and then we can get to your counter suit.” She offered as she adjusted the papers in front of her. “I see this is an issue of inheritance and you are disputing the contents of the will?”

 

“More or less, your honor” Christian started as he began to gather his papers. “It appears that the will that was executed in this case was invalid as there had been another agreement made after the fact.” Christian explained. 

 

“I see, and do you have the document you’re referring to?” Judge Horowitz asked. 

 

“Yes, your honor. May I approach the bench?” Christian grabbed the paper and began to head towards her. 

 

“No you may not!” Spat the judge, stopping him in his tracks. “My bailiff will collect the document from you.” Judge Horowitz replied sharply as she motioned for the bailiff to retrieve the item from him. 

 

“Alrighty then.” Christian huffed under his breath as he made his way back to his chair.

 

“What was that Mr. Atwood?” The judge snapped

 

“Oh, um, as you wish, your honor!” he corrected bashfully

 

“That’s what I thought!” she replied as the bailiff handed her the document. She quickly reviewed it and brought her attention back to Christian. “Do you have a copy of the will you are contesting?”

 

Christian rifled through the mess of papers in front of him before pulling out a particularly crumpled one. “Yes! Right here, your honor.” 

 

“I can see you’ve prepared diligently for court today Mr. Atwood.” She grumbled as she motioned for the bailiff, “Karl, if you would.” She reread the document in hand as she waited for the bailiff to return. Once he handed her the copy of the will her face scrunched in revulsion. “Where have you been keeping this? On the floor of your car? It’s hardly legible in this current state!”

 

“If I may, your honor!” Val piped up. 

 

“Ms. Fontaine?”

 

“I happen to have a copy that might better suit your needs.” She held the forms aloft for the bailiff to take. 

 

“Indeed, Karl” she waved for him to collect the papers. As soon as he returned she handed back Christian’s documents. “Be sure this finds the trash.” She grumbled as she looked over the will. They waited in silence as she reviewed them slowly, her enormous glasses slipping down her nose as she read. She moved back and forth between the documents a few times before speaking again. “I already have several questions about what has been presented but I would like to hear from the defendant before we get into that. Ms. Fontaine…” She called to which Valentina rose. 

 

“Is your client currently in possession of the property?”

 

“Yes, your honor.” 

 

“What about the contents within, mentioned in each of the documents?”

 

“She had taken it upon herself to sell the contents of the home, given the understanding it was her property, according to the plaintiff’s own lawyer.” Val explained with a side eye to Christian. 

 

“I see, and how much did she make from the sale of those items?” Val looked down to Agatha who scribbled a figure onto the available notepad.

 

“Approximately $250,000.00, your honor. Though we can get a more accurate figure from the estate sale company, should you wish.” As soon as the number was read aloud Agatha could feel her mother’s eyes boring into her, no doubt infuriated that she had earned such a sum for many of the priceless antiques her family had collected over the years. 

 

“I’m fine to accept that for the time being, we’ll dig into it further if I deem necessary.” She scribbled her own notes before continuing. “Mr. Atwood!” 

 

Christian shot up from his seat, nearly knocking the chair over. “Yes, your honor.”

 

“Time for my questions! It appears, you yourself were the one to execute the will you are contesting. Where was this document at that time?” she asked, holding up the new will. 

 

“It…it had been misplaced, your honor.” He explained bashfully. 

 

“Is that a common practice in your law firm, Mr. Atwood?” Judge Horowitz asked, peering over her glasses.

 

“No, not at all your honor. There were…extenuating circumstances.” He babbled nervously. 

 

“Enlighten me.” The judge replied, unamused. 

 

“At the time Mr. Harkness was on bedrest. Therefore this document was agreed to at the family home mentioned in the will and filed away there by his assistant per the request of the now deceased. At the time of his death I was unable to uncover the whereabouts of this will and my firm was required to comply with what was on file. My client had some theories as to where it may have been placed but, being restricted from the property, she was unable to assist in locating it”

 

“I see. And why was your client restricted from the property?”

 

“There was a minor familial dispute between Mr. Harkness and my client a few years back and she was henceforth restricted from entering the property as long as it was considered a part of his estate.” Christian explained

 

“Is there a record of this dispute?”

 

“I do have a copy of the no-trespassing order, your honor, if you would like to see.” He shuffled through some more papers before pulling out a file.

 

“Yes, as long as it’s still legible.” She motioned, once again, for the bailiff to collect the document. She quickly reviewed it and turned her attention back to Christian. “I see, yet, despite this dispute, in the end he decided to award her the property and assets?”

 

“Yes, your honor.” Christian insisted

 

“So who eventually uncovered the document?” The judge asked with a frown

 

“My client, your honor.”

 

“And how exactly did she gain access to the property?”

 

“Access was eventually granted.” Christian claimed

 

“Granted by whom?”

 

“The defendant.” 

 

Agatha leaned over and whispered to Val, “I did not grant access, she just showed up at the estate sale. I didn’t even know she had been banned.” Val nodded in acknowledgment as she scribbled the note down. 

 

“Do you have anything else you would like to share with me Mr. Atwood?” The judge asked. 

 

“Not at this time your honor.” Christian said as he returned to his seat.

 

“Very well, Ms. Fontaine, you may plead your case.” 

 

“Thank you, your honor. I have two pieces of evidence I would like to submit. The first being the death certificate of Mr. Ebenezer Aloicous Harkness.The other is an affidavit signed by the hospice nurse caring for him during the last three months of his life outlining the various conditions he was suffering from.” The bailiff secured the documents and handed  them to the judge. “I would like to note that the date of the contesting will is merely a week before the passing of Mr. Harkness and, as you’ll see in the affidavit, amongst his many ailments, Mr. Harkness was suffering from dementia which would render him incapable of being of sound mind or body at the time of signing.” 

 

Judge Horowitz scowled as she reviewed everything carefully. “Well, Mr. Atwood… anything to say for yourself?” 

 

 Christian cleared his throat as he stood. “He was lucid at the time of signing your honor.” 

 

“The 95 year old dementia patient was lucid at the time of signing?” The judge stared him down above the rim of her heavy glasses. “I find that hard to believe, Mr. Atwood.” Judge Horowitz said as she began stacking the papers before her. “Given the evidence presented by the defendant I am dismissing this suit. Mr. Atwood, I would get your ducks in a row as you should plan to expect a thorough review from the state board in your near future. We will take a brief 30 minute recess and return to settle the counterclaim. You are dismissed.” With a bang of the gavel the judge stood and began to exit.

 

“All rise!” Shouted the bailiff as the judge made her way back to her chambers. 

 

“That worked out well!” Sighed Rio as she plopped back into the chair. 

 

“Right? I knew that man was an incompetent buffoon but he really outdid himself here!” Val chuckled

 

“Yeah…” Agatha whispered in reply though her attention lingered on her mother and the coven of women gathered around her engaged in casual conversation as if they were at brunch, not in court trying to rip her life apart. Evanora seemed relatively unphased, disappointed clearly, but she held none of the rage Agatha had expected at losing the suit. Her calmness stoked the fear she had sparked in Agatha earlier in the bathroom, sending a panicked chill down her spine. “Something’s off” she murmured.

 

“What was that, cariño?” 

 

“She’s not nearly as furious as I would have expected her to be after losing.”

 

“She probably knew they had no case!” Rio shrugged. 

 

“Then why did she even bother?” Agatha grunted in frustration. She stared for another moment as they conversed conspiratorially, taking in the prattle amongst them. Her eyes and ears searching for the conversation just out of reach. She caught a word here, a sentence there, but nothing she could entirely piece together. Still, she couldn’t shake the feeling like they were plotting something, undeterred by their loss. 

Then, just as she was about to return to her seat her mother caught her gaze, eyes glinting with smug, self-satisfaction and something darker, something ominous and alarming. A viscous grin crept along her face causing Agatha’s heart to stutter in her chest, her stomach to lurch and her knees to nearly give out beneath her. “I…I need some air.” She gasped as she stumbled out from behind the desk and hurried down the aisle through the wooden doors. She rushed down the hallway, unsure of where she was headed, only knowing she had to get as far away from Evanora as she could. 

 

“Agatha! Agatha, wait!” Rio called after her as she chased her down the corridor. She caught up with her just as she rounded the corner and found Agatha, back pressed against the wall, her breath coming in shattered bursts as her face froze in panic. “Mi amor! What’s the matter? What’s wrong?” 

 

“She's up to something!” Agatha huffed as she began to pace “I…I just know it!”

 

“What do you mean?” Rio frowned in confusion. 

 

“You should have seen the way she looked at me, it’s the kind of looks she has when she’s plotting my demise. I just…I know this isn’t the end of it.” Agatha huffed.

 

“How so? She lost, now we’re going to get to banish her from our lives for good. What else could she possibly do?” Rio chuckled nervously

 

“I DON'T KNOW!” Agatha shouted, still pacing “Ugh, I feel like I’m going to be sick.” 

 

“Here, my love, have a seat, catch your breath. You need to calm down.” Rio encouraged as she began to guide Agatha to a nearby bench. 

 

“Don’t tell me to calm down!” Agatha shouted, pushing Rio off of her. “You have no idea the kind of shit she’s pulled! She will do anything to tear my life apart. She tried to get me kicked out of college multiple times, I was suspended twice. She tried to drive Wanda away when she found out about us and it nearly worked. I was fired from my first two jobs because of her. She hates to see me happy and she’s relentless!” 

 

“I’m sorry, I wasn’t trying to dismiss your feelings, I just…I was trying to help. It’s…it’s not good for your health, all this stress.” Rio’s eyes gleamed with care and worry. 

 

“I know! That’s what terrifies me. All the shit she’s been pulling lately, sending those horrendous gifts, what she said in the bathroom, this fucking lawsuit and whatever else she has up her sleeve…I just…I don’t know how much more of this I can take!” Agatha began to crumble as she collapsed into Rio’s arms. “I’m just so ready for this day to be over! I just want to crawl into bed with you and forget any of this happened.” 

 

“Soon, mi amor, I promise!” Rio held Agatha close as she kissed her forehead. “You know what might help?” 

 

“I swear if the word meditate comes out of your mouth I’ll throttle you!” Agatha hissed over Rio’s shoulder.

 

“Cariño! Save that energy for the bedroom!” Rio snorted in laughter. “No, I was going to say a snack, though some deep breathing wouldn’t be bad either.”

 

“What kind of snack?” Agatha whimpered

 

Rio shrugged, “I bet I can find some cookies in the vending machine!” 

 

“Oooo, I would kill for an Oreo right now.” Agatha gushed as she righted herself.

 

“Then Oreos you shall have! Do you want to head back in with Val or wait here for me?” Rio asked

 

“I’m not ready to go back in there. I want to spend as little time in my mother’s presence as possible!” 

 

“Completely understandable! This spot’s kind of tucked away, why don’t you have a seat, do try and take some deep breaths, relax as best you can, and I’ll be back before you know it!” She gave Agatha a quick peck on the cheek then rushed off down the hallway. 

 

As soon as Rio disappeared around the corner Agatha sunk into the bench against the wall with a groan. The weight of everything, the aches and pains of pregnancy, having to be here in court, having to deal with her Mother, it was crushing her. She could feel her heart pounding throughout her body as her son rolled and pressed against her causing her to twinge in discomfort. She took a deep calming breath as she guided her hands along the surface. “I know, I know little bug! I got you all worked up. Let’s take a minute together, like Rio suggested, and try to calm down.” She closed her eyes and leaned her head back against the wall as she breathed in through her nose. “She can’t hurt us...not anymore.” she sighed just as much to herself as to her son. As she sat there, silently breathing, settling her nerves and waiting for Rio to return, her ears picked up on chattering whispers from a couple familiar voices just around the corner.

 

“I still can’t believe she tracked down that nurse!” Said the first woman, who Agatha recognized as Florence, one of her mother’s close congregants.

 

“I know, I was sure this was going to go in her favor! Clearly the Lord works in mysterious ways.” Replied Bernice, another congregant. 

 

“Indeed he does! Though, I don’t know that she cares much at this point so long as the visitation goes through.” Florence explained

 

“So she did end up filing?” Bernice asked.

 

“I think Christian is drafting the paperwork while we’re waiting to continue. She’s much further along than we thought.” Florence exclaimed.

 

“I know! When I found out I prayed, hoping the Lord would spare this child like her last one, but it appears it may be doomed to suffer her obscene parentage.” Bernice growled.

 

“Not if Evanora can help it! She was going to file for full custody but was advised against it considering the slim margin for success. But, given Agatha is unmarried, there seems to be a chance they would grant her some sort of visitation. It is her grandchild after all!” Florence reasoned.

 

“Too true! Then again, there is always the chance she doesn’t survive the birth. Evanora would undoubtedly be granted custody then. We both know that child has no father and that horrid woman she’s cavorting with would have no claim.” Bernice replied.

 

“From your lips to God’s ears. We can only pray that He sees fit to make it come to pass.” Florence said as their voices drifted further. 

 

Agatha sat, silently as she could, shaking with fear and rage at the conversation being had as the women continued down the hallway. So this was her plan. This is why she had flashed that shit-eating grin in Agatha’s direction even after she had lost the suit. This is what she had meant when she had told her to enjoy motherhood while she still can. She was coming after her child! Of all the things she had done to her this was the most diabolical, but how could she stop it?!

She could hear her heart racing as the color drained from her face and a cold sweat gathered on her brow. She felt saliva filling her mouth as her stomach lurched and turned threatening to spill its contents. Her eyes searched for a receptacle as the nausea continued to build. With nothing in sight she hurried as best she could to her feet and stumbled out into the hallway, at last finding a trash can a few feet away. She rushed forward and ripped off the metal lid just in time for the contents of her stomach to make their appearance. As the final heaves convulsed throughout her body Rio returned to the alcove. 

 

“They didn’t have any Oreos in the machine up here but I went down a floor and found…Agatha?” She stepped back from the entrance and searched for her, quickly finding her doubled over the trash can. “Agatha!” She shouted as she rushed to her side, dropping the cookies as she gathered her sweat drenched hair away from her face. 

 

Agatha rested her face on her arm as she caught her breath, urging her body to relax as she felt Rio’s hand rubbing soothing circles on her back. 

“Rio…” she cried as she lifted her head. 

 

“I’m right here, Cariño.” She cooed as Agatha righted herself, face streaming with tears. “Oh! Mi vida! Are you ok?” Agatha shook her head as she stumbled back from the trash can and reached to steady herself on the bannister overlooking the entryway. “Do you feel like you’re going to be sick again?” Agatha shook her head again as she worked to calm her breathing. “Maybe you should sit back down.” Rio suggested, bracing Agatha’s back as she took her hand to lead her back over to the bench. As she sat Rio kneeled in front of her, her hands brushing away the tear soaked curls clinging to her face. “If you’re comfortable here I’m going to go get a towel from the bathroom and grab your bag, we need to check your blood pressure, you do not look good!” She pressed her lips to Agatha’s forehead as she rose and turned to leave but was stopped by Agatha whose hand clung to her wrist. 

 

“NO! Please…don’t go!” She begged, her gaze awash with fear and panic. “She’s…coming for him! I…I heard them!” She gasped through hiccups that had taken the place of her sobs. 

 

“What are you talking about?” Rio turned back in confusion

 

“My mother…she’s filing for visitation.” Rio’s eyes flashed with a fury that startled Agatha as her ears and cheeks began to grow flush with rage.

 

“Over my dead body!” She growled as she stepped back to pull Agatha protectively against her. “I swear that woman is begging to be carried out on a stretcher!”

 

“Rio, please!” Agatha scolded as she clung to her. “We have to do something! She…she can’t have him!” 

 

“We will, my love, we’ll figure this out!” Rio assured as she ran her fingers through Agatha’s hair. “Do you have your phone on you?” Agatha nodded silently as she released Rio from her grip and wiped away a fresh tear. “We need to talk to Val, now!” Rio urged. Agatha reached into her dress pocket, pulled out her phone and immediately dialed Val. “Here, cariño, let me talk to her.” Rio motioned for Agatha to hand her the phone. “You relax as best you can.” 

 

Rio brought the phone to her ear and began pacing as Agatha rested her head against the wall and braced her arms securely around the swollen mound in her lap, currently vibrating with the swimming motions of her son. She moved a hand over a ripple as she closed her eyes, soaking in the feeling of him tucked inside her, safe and close. She had been wary of his birth before, the pain, the risks, but now, with this added threat, she was utterly terrified. How would she protect him once he was born? How could she ever ensure his safety in a world that was so cruel? Then of course, if worse came to worst and something happened to her…? She shuddered at the thought. There were so many things she hadn’t considered before now and it was deepening the pit of fear inside her, threatening to swallow her whole.

 

“ Hey, where are you guys? We’re going to get started again in about 10 minutes! ” Val asked as she answered the call.

 

“Hey it’s Rio! We’re out in the hallway around the corner. Is there any way we could get more time? We need to talk with you, now, somewhere private.” 

 

“ I can ask the bailiff. Is everything alright? ” 

 

“No, not really. There’s been…a development.”

 

“ Oh! Ok. I can probably get us another 30 minutes. ”

 

“That should be fine. Where can we meet you?” 

 

“ Are you down near the elevators? ”

 

“Yeah, not too far.”

 

“Room 303 is nearby, it’s a conference room and should be free. I’ll meet you there shortly.”

 

“Amazing! Thank you! Would you mind bringing Agatha’s bag with you?”

 

“ The black one? ”

 

“Yeah that’s it. And maybe a bottle of water?”

 

“ You got it! ”

 

“You’re the best. We’ll see you in a minute.” She hung up the phone and turned to Agatha. “You ok to get up and walk?”

 

“Yeah, I’ll be fine as long as we’re not going far.” Agatha replied, still looking a bit pale. Rio stuck her head out from the alcove and peered around the corner, spotting the room nearby.

 

“We’re just going around this corner so take your time.” Rio reassured as she moved to sit next to Agatha. 

 

Agatha breathed slowly, gathering her energy to move as her thoughts continued to spiral around this new threat. “Why?” she whispered as her chest heaved. 

 

“Why what, mi amor?” Rio asked

 

“Why does she have to be this way?” She opened her eyes and turned to look at Rio. “Why does she hate me?” 

 

“I’m so sorry, cariño.” Rio brought a hand up to cradle Agatha’s face, pulling it close to allow their foreheads to rest against each other. “You don’t deserve this, any of it.” She wrapped her arms around Agatha, holding her close in a comforting embrace.

 

“I love you.” Agatha hummed as she prepared herself to stand. 

 

“I love you too, mi vida!” Rio placed a kiss on her cheek as she moved to help Agatha. “You ready?” she asked, offering her hand. Agatha nodded as she placed her hand in Rio’s, allowing her to help her to her feet before she led them to the room. 



As they stepped into the fluorescently lit room Val was already seated and waiting. She jumped up from her chair as soon as she spotted them, seeing the state Agatha was recovering from. “Oh my gosh!” she gasped as she pulled out a chair for Agatha to quickly collapse into. “Are you ok?” she asked as she went to grab the bottle of water she had brought with her.

 

“I’ll be fine.” Agatha brushed her off

 

“You sure? You look like you’ve seen a ghost! Should I call a medic?” Val asked, turning to Rio.

 

“We’ll see, I do need to check her blood pressure.” Rio b-lined for Agatha’s purse to dig out the cuff. 

 

“What happened?” Val asked, looking confusedly between the two of them.

 

“My mother!” Agatha groaned as Rio slipped the device onto her forearm. “She’s planning to file for visitation with my son.” 

 

“WHAT?!” Val shouted, shocked and even more confused than before.

 

“That’s what I overheard at least.” Agatha huffed breathlessly

 

“That doesn’t make any sense!” Val chuckled in disbelief.

 

“Is that even possible? Can she do that?” Rio asked as she started the reading.

 

“I don’t know! I’d have to dig into what exactly they’re filing.” Val explained

 

“The fact that she’s even trying is what scares me! Well that and…” Agatha started. 

 

“And what?” Rio asked, frowning in concern.

 

“They had also mentioned that, if anything were to happen to me, she would try and take custody of him.” Agatha revealed.

 

“Absolutely not!” Rio shouted.

 

“Who’s they?” Val asked

 

“I heard a couple of her friends talking in the hallway when Rio went to find cookies.” Agatha explained.

 

“They were so fucking lucky I wasn’t there with you!” Rio mumbled as she removed the cuff.

 

“What was it?” Agatha asked, seeing Rio’s concerned look.

 

“Don’t worry about it right now.” Rio replied, attempting to brush her off.

 

“Rio…” she urged

 

“Higher than it should be but…”

 

“Rio!” she demanded

 

“145/90” Rio replied starkly. “I’m not calling emergency services yet but you need to take a minute and actually calm down. We’ll check it again later. I’m sure it’s just the stress of the situation.”

 

“No shit!” Agatha scoffed, as her body rang numb in shock. 

 

“Drink some more water, take some deep breaths.” Rio instructed, “Well, what can we do?” Rio asked, turning to Val.

 

“For right now, the best thing to do is stay our course. I’m feeling quite confident in our countersuit after our earlier hearing. If it goes the way I think it will I can easily get whatever else she’s planning to file thrown out immediately in conjunction with the ruling. So, try not to worry as best you can.” Val looked on encouragingly. 

 

They each sighed a breath of relief but a question still pricked at the back of Agatha’s mind. “That does make me feel a bit better…but then again…if something were to happen to me?”

 

“Nothing’s going to happen to you, my love.” Rio rested her hands on Agatha’s shoulders and kissed the crown of her head.

 

Agatha closed her eyes and gritted her teeth “But if something were, even if it were far in the future, how can I ensure she never claims him?”

 

“The best thing to do would be to write up a living will. Have it clearly laid out what the chain of custody would be in a worst case scenario.” Val suggested.

 

“Is that something you could help us with?” Rio asked.

 

“Certainly! With regards to that I do have a few questions, which may seem personal but it’s important to know as it can impact what’s even possible.” Val explained

 

“Of course.” Agatha whispered, voice weak and shaky with fear.

 

“I take it you intend for Rio to assume custody in the unlikely case of your passing?”

 

“I…well…we hadn’t really…” Agatha stuttered as she fidgeted nervously

 

“Of course!” Rio answered assuredly. “I mean, if that’s what you want.”

 

“Are you sure?” Agatha asked, tilting her head to face Rio. “I don’t want you to feel obligated.” 

 

“I promise, I don’t. I love him so much already, and if something were to ever happen to you, I just… I’d be a wreck! But…I couldn’t imagine him not being a part of my life.” Agatha gave Rio a teary smile as she reached for her hand on her shoulder. 

 

“So yes then, I would want Rio listed as the legal guardian.” Agatha replied.

 

“Alright, well that’s certainly possible but there are just a few other things we need to be aware of. I don’t want to assume but was this child donor conceived or what kind of relationship do you have with the other biological parent?” Val asked

 

“I guess it would be considered a known donor situation, though I don’t know that he would seek custody. He’s not really the parenting type.” Agatha explained

 

“Has he signed over parental rights?” Val questioned

 

“No, not directly.” Agatha muttered

 

“Then, currently, he would be entitled to custody over Rio or your mother. However, if you believe he would not be willing or able to take custody then it would fall back to your intentions outlined for the child in your will. Nine times out of ten the court will align with what is in the will as long as it’s in the best interest of the child.”

 

“He’s somewhere cruising in the south of France at the moment, though I’m sure if I sent him the documents he’d be able to fill them out and send them back.” Agatha explained.

 

“That’s perfectly fine! I can get you the documents to send him by the end of the week and have something fleshed out by end of next. I wouldn’t stress too much but it would be good to have things solidified before the baby arrives so the sooner you can get him to sign the better since you are getting close. Also, just to make sure we cover all the bases, I would suggest adding an additional chain of custody, in the unlikely off chance that something happened to Rio as well, as in…if the both of you were to…simultaneously perish, so to speak.” Val offered delicately.

 

Agatha glanced back at Rio before replying, “I would have to talk with them but my friend Jennifer and her partner would be my next preference as guardians.” 

 

“Great, confirm with them, get me their info, and we could have all this buttoned up within the month.” Val assured.

 

“That would be incredible! Really! She needs some peace of mind at this point and to focus on getting ready for the baby. All of this nonsense is getting in the way of that and, as you can see, it’s been really detrimental to her health.” Rio explained as she ran her fingers soothingly through Agatha’s hair. 

 

“Don’t worry, this is on my list of things to bring up in the countersuit. Not only impacting your health but the health of your child. Oh, I meant to ask, has she sent you any other gifts?” 

 

Rio and Agatha shared a knowing glance. “Practically one a day since we’ve seen you. A blanket with a cross stitched into it, too many stuffed animals to count, dozens of religious children’s books, it’s all been inconvenient to say the least.” Rio groaned

 

“The latest one was a family heirloom cradle she managed to track down from the estate sale that she shoved in front of my door this morning. That one at least came with a note.” Agatha snorted.

 

“And these have all been delivered to your house?” Val confirmed

 

“There’s something sitting out there nearly every morning.” Rio explained

 

“Did you happen to catch any footage?” Val asked

 

“Oh, yeah I have it on my phone!” Rio whipped her phone out of her pocket. “It’s never her leaving it, but some of the faces I recognize in the courtroom.” She said as she scrolled through the app. “Oooo, today it looks like she hired actual movers to deliver at like 4 in the morning?” She turned the phone around to show Val and Agatha. 

 

“Can you send me those, I’ll plan to include them as evidence of the harassment.” Val asked

 

“Oh, absolutely!” 

 

“No, I recognize them, they’re brothers and deacons at her church.” Agatha pointed out as she watched the video.

 

“See! It’s all of them, it’s her whole cult. That’s the only thing that worries me, even if we do get this protection order in place she still has hoards of people that will harass Agatha on her behalf.” Rio grumbled, exasperatedly.

 

“If it can be proven that they are contacting Agatha on her behalf that would constitute a violation of the order.” Val explained.

 

“That sounds difficult to prove.” Agatha groaned skeptically

 

“It may be easier than you think. If it can be shown they have no relationship with Agatha outside of Evanora and are continuing established behavior, such as leaving the gifts, it would give us grounds to exercise the consequences of the order. At the very least we would have it investigated.” Val shrugged.

 

“That makes me feel a lot better! How about you, Carino?" Rio asked, turning to Agatha.

 

“As long as everything works out I’ll feel a lot better. Right now I’m just anxious for it to all be over. For her to be out of my life for good!” she sighed.

 

“I’m quite confident that after today, if she tries to contact you it’ll be a one way ticket to jail.” Val assured.

 

“Oh, wouldn’t that be nice!” Rio grinned as her eyes flashed with delight at the thought. 

 

“If neither of you have any further questions it would be a good idea to head back in, they’ll be planning to start soon.” Val rose and headed to the door. 

 

“I might need a minute to pull myself together. I’m sure I look like a disaster and I don’t want to give any of them the satisfaction.” 

 

“Do what you need to do and I’ll review the footage you sent me and meet you both in there shortly.” Val said as she exited into the hallway. 

 

“Can you hand me my bag?” Agatha asked

 

“Of course, my love.” 

 

“Thank you.” Agatha immediately began digging for gum and a makeup wipe. 

 

“Are you sure you’re alright to go back in there?” Rio questioned.

 

“Why wouldn’t I be?” Agatha dismissed non-chalantly 

 

“Oh, I don’t know, with everything that just happened. Your blood pressure skyrocketing. I’m worried about you, both of you!” 

 

“I’m fine, really, and he’s currently swimming laps inside of me. That was a lot but we’re both ok, I promise.” She said, patting Rio’s cheek as she passed to inspect herself in a mirror. 

 

“You would tell me if you weren’t right?” Rio asked

 

“Uhuh.” Agatha hummed as she started to braid her hair. 

 

“Because I don’t know what I would do if anything happened to you.” Rio muttered as she glided to stand behind Agatha, resting her chin on her shoulder as her hands moved to wrap around her pregnant belly, feeling the motion within. Agatha leaned into the hold as she let her hands fall atop Rio’s. 

 

“You’d really take him? If anything did happen?” Agatha asked as she rested her head against Rio’s cheek, her gaze fixed on their intertwined fingers holding the tiny life inside her. 

 

“In a heartbeat! But let’s hope it never comes to that!” Rio placed a soft kiss on Agatha's cheek before stepping back and holding out her hand. “You ready to go banish this bitch for good?” 

 

Agatha smirked as she took Rio’s hand “Ugh, more than you know!” 






As they re-entered the courtroom Agatha held her head high. All of her mothers antagonistic harassment was about to come to an end. Rio was locked in step with her, their hands held together in a magnetic pull as they sauntered down the aisle way back to their table. They looked confident, formidable, and ready to squash this annoyance once and for all. 

 

Agatha could feel her mother’s eyes on her, urging her to look and break once again, but she held fast, reassured by Rio’s grounding presence and the confidence she had in Val’s plan. All her bases were covered and she found an almost giddy joy growing inside her at the thought of her mothers demise. Her heart fluttered as the bailiff stepped out and asked them once again to rise as Judge Horowitz resumed her seat at the bench. 

 

“You may be seated. Ms. Fontain are you prepared to present your countersuit?”

 

“Indeed your honor.” 

 

“The floor is yours, you may proceed” 

 

“Thank you, your honor. Family disputes are never easy but my client and the defendant have a particularly tumultuous relationship. There is a long history of childhood abuse and trauma perpetrated by the defendant which caused my client to establish no contact when she was 18. I don’t want to waste any more of this court’s time digging that far back, for now we will simply cite the most recent events. The previous suit, for example, was one incident in a long series of incidents where the defendant has harassed and badgered my client. The elder Ms. Harkness and her lawyer sought my client out months ago and pestered her repeatedly urging her to sign an agreement to overtake the property, so she did in an effort to end their communication. 

Once signed; however, they campaigned for her to visit the property without disclosing the reason they were so adamant. She was reluctant, given her own personal history with the family and the property as well as her availability, but harassment only increased to the point where opposing counsel accosted her on her own doorstep. 

After that incident she made plans to visit the property and manage her inheritance in the way she saw fit. Part of which was to sell the contents of the home in the estate sale and eventually sell the property itself. The defendant took it upon herself to visit the property at the time of the estate sale, which we now know was only in an effort to recover the invalid will, where she too accosted my client and caused physical damage to her person before once again being banned from the premises. 

Even after this incident there has been continued threatening contact from the defendant leading up to our court date today. This is but a small glimpse into the many reasons we are seeking a harassment and protection order from the elder Ms. Harkness for my client.” 

 

“What evidence have you brought with you regarding these incidents and threats?” 

 

“I have an incident report from the encounter at the property in Boston. There wasn’t a report made when Mr. Atwood attacked my client but I’m sure he’d be happy to share his medical records showing the aftercare he required when she defended herself against him.”

 

“Thank you Ms. Fontaine, but I am only interested in the police report.” She handed over the report to the bailiff as she continued. 

 

“I do have video evidence of the many people she has instructed to trespass on my client’s property on her behalf.” 

 

“I would be interested in that as well. Karl, would you turn on the screen?” The judge requested as she reviewed the report. “If you would, Ms. Fontaine, share the video evidence you’ve procured.” 

 

Val connected her phone to the screen and played the first video. “You’ll see this dated a week ago when my client first installed the surveillance. You’ll see a woman leave an item on the porch then return to a black Cadillac Escalade waiting on the street. I’ve confirmed the license plate and the vehicle does in fact belong to the defendant.” They all sat in silence as the video played. “You’ll find that woman in the video sitting directly behind the defendant in court today.” All heads turned to pick out which of the seven had been featured. 

“The next video is the following morning. Another item left by another woman sitting in court here and returning to the same black Escalade.” Hushed murmuring began to break out amongst the viewership. 

“These continue on each day, including this very morning where two gentlemen placed a large item directly in front of my client’s door before returning to the same parked Escalade at four in the morning. This had been going on for a week before my client installed the surveillance. At one point before this they even sought her out at an appointment she had with me.” Val clicked to another video that showed security footage from her building where they saw Evanora herself placing an item outside Rio’s car.

 

“Couldn’t find a stooge for that one I guess.” Rio muttered to Agatha as they watched.  

 

“These actions, though seemingly benign, have been a great source of stress for my client to the point that it’s put not only her health at risk but also the health of her unborn child. The defendant knows these actions are unwarranted and unwanted yet she pursues them in an attempt to intimidate my client and without a protection order in place this kind of behavior will continue and cause further damage.” 

 

“Thank you Ms. Fontaine. Is there anything else you would like to submit to the court at this time?”

 

“No, your honor.” 

 

“Very well, Mr. Atwood, you have the floor.” With no immediate response from Christian, Agatha chanced a look in his direction. He was huddled with Evanora as the two of them exchanged harsh whispers. 

 

“Mr. Atwood?!” Judge Horowitz called again, growing impatient as another few minutes passed. 

 

“One moment, your honor.” He eventually responded, holding up a finger to the judge in pause as he continued his conversation with her mother. 

 

“If you need some time with your client to review your arguments I’d prefer to postpone this until the end of my docket today as you have, so far, wasted enough of this court's time in your unpreparedness!” Agatha’s heart sank at the thought of prolonging this any further. She bit her lip as she waited for him to respond. 

 

“That won’t be necessary, your honor. We are prepared to move forward now.” 

 

“See that you do.” 

 

“Your honor, my client is being vilified as some horrendous monster for wanting to ensure her grandchild is well provided for. All of these items that Ms. Harkness and her community have gifted the plaintiff are for the child to ensure a healthy and stable home that my client strongly believes her daughter is incapable of providing. Yes, she is aware that her presence is a disturbance but the wellbeing of the child outweighs the plaintiff’s own discomfort.” 

Agatha could feel her face radiating with anger at the statements. Of course she would feel Agatha was incapable of providing for her own child. 

“With regard to the property my client shared the information she felt was necessary and her pursuit of ownership was only to keep the home and its contents within the family, as it had been for over a century, instead of being sold off to the highest bidder. We don’t disagree that their relationship is strained but a protection order is an unnecessary reactionary measure.”

 

“What leads your client to believe the child will not be provided for to cause her to take such actions?” Judge Horowitz asked

 

“Her daughter has a history of emotional instability causing her to make irrational and irrevocable decisions that my client believes may put the child in danger. Along with the fact that her lifestyle doesn’t lend itself to child rearing.” Christian sneered

 

“Objection! Your honor this hearing is not to determine my client’s ability to parent her child. If anything it aims to highlight the defendant’s inability to emotionally regulate herself to the point that she assaulted her own daughter.” Val snapped back

 

“Indeed. Objection sustained. Mr. Atwood, do you or your client have any comment regarding the incident cited in the police report?”

 

“There was…” Christian started as he glanced back down at a scowling Evanora. “An unfortunate disagreement that did elicit a physical action from my client but that was paled in comparison to the violence the plaintiff’s friend took against her in retaliation.”

 

“I’m not seeing that mentioned in the police report.” 

 

“My client left immediately after the confrontation and was unable to give her statement of events.” 

 

“That is unfortunate. Ms. Fontaine, do you have any additional statements at this time?” 

 

“The defendant claims her actions are in the best interest of the child, a child she would have no knowledge of if she and her cohorts hadn’t been stalking my client in the first place. My client along with her partner , who is a medical professional, are more than capable of caring for this child on their own. Therefore the defendant’s actions are manipulative and harmful, both physically and emotionally and if this court is interested in protecting the interest of the child they will see this protection order is justified and well overdue.” 

 

“Your honor, if I may?” Christian piped up

 

“Yes, Mr. Atwood?”

 

“They tried this once before and it was already struck down in a court of law.”

 

“Citing insufficient evidence!” Val retorted “There has been more than enough evidence collected since to justify this request. That was before the incident in Boston and before any of this additional “gift giving” harassment.” 

 

“Your honor, my client knows there is no hope in salvaging the relationship she has with her daughter and she does not want to pursue it. What this order really intends to do is sever any possible relationship with her grandchild before it’s even begun.”

 

“Be that as it may, Mr. Atwood, I’m finding little reason to deny this request. Your client’s actions, however well intended they may have been, do constitute harassment and stalking at the very least. I have further concerns given that there are documented violent tendencies and given the delicate nature of the plaintiff’s state I fear I’m not willing to risk any further actions. Therefore I’m ruling a judgment in favor of the plaintiff. A five year protection order will be put into place with the option to renew for an additional five years at that time. The defendant will not be permitted to contact, pursue, or be within 100 yards of the plaintiff or the child during that time. You have the right to appeal this ruling; however, you must abide by this order until such a judgement is made. Any violation of this order will result in a $1,000.00 fine and a six month jail sentence. My clerk will have the appropriate documents available within the hour, any questions please direct to him. Court Adjourned.” 

 

With a bang of the gavel the stillness was broken. Feet shuffled, voices murmured in shock and confusion, and a wave of relief washed over Agatha. It was over, she had won and her child was safe. She sat still and stunned as a smile grew across her face.

 

“We fucking did it!” Rio gasped as she turned to beam at Agatha. “You fucking did it!” She jumped up and gathered Val in a hug. “Holy shit! I can’t thank you enough!” 

 

Val chuckled nervously as she pried herself from Rio’s grasp, “My pleasure, as always!”

 

“Really, Val, thank you for everything!” Agatha sighed as she stood from the table. 

 

“I’m just glad it all worked out! You two should head out, I’ll wait around for the documentation and send it over with the forms for your donor. Until then, try and get some rest. I know today has been a lot.”

 

“Oh, as soon as we get home I am crawling into bed and not leaving until work tomorrow!” Agatha snorted. “Really I could probably sleep the rest of the week!” 

 

“Oh, I don’t doubt that! You take care of yourself and that baby. Keep me in the loop if you can and let me know when he arrives. I’m excited for you, both of you! Especially now, you’ll really get to enjoy it!” 

 

“Oh, we certainly will! Thanks again!” Rio called as they quickly shuffled down the aisleway, bypassing the crowd of distraught and perplexed women hovering around Evanora. They hurried down the corridor and quickly jumped into an elevator that was just about to close. They stood like sardines squished into a can with the many other passengers along for the ride, pressed face to face so that the bump was squished between them. Rio looked down and laughed silently to herself.

 

“What?” Agatha whispered, her crystal blue eyes gleaming curiously at her amusement.

 

“I felt that.” Rio chuckled

 

“Seriously?” Agatha snorted in bemused bewilderment

 

“Yeah, kid’s got a helluva kick. Who knows, he might end up being a soccer pro!” 

 

“Oh wouldn’t that be something!” Agatha chuckled. 

 

“You better get ready for some early Saturday practices. Games in the afternoon. We could set up some goals in the back yard to practice!” Rio babbled animatedly

 

Agatha’s face scrunched with laughter, “I’m glad you’re excited but let’s give him a chance to get here before you redesign my backyard.” 

 

“Fine! I’ll be patient, but as soon as he’s walking I’m teaching him some drills! Can’t let that talent go to waste!” 

 

“If you say so dear.” Agatha said, patting Rio’s cheek before stepping out of the elevator. 

 

They rushed down the hallway hand in hand towards the entrance. As they neared the doors Rio stopped suddenly. “Really quick, I have to grab something from security.” 

 

“What?” Agatha frowned as she watched Rio walk up to one of the guards and strike up a conversation. They spoke amicably for a moment before he handed something back to her which she stuffed into her pocket before jogging back over to Agatha. “What was that?” 

 

“They confiscated something on the way in. I was just getting it back.” She shrugged as she started to usher Agatha towards the door. 

 

“What exactly did they confiscate?” Agatha hitched an eyebrow as a smirk tugged at the corner of her lips.
