“My father’s switchblade.” Rio quickly mumbled. 

 

“Rio!” Agatha gasped as they pushed through the first set of doors. 

 

“I forgot it was in my pocket. I’m just glad they gave it back.” Rio shrugged. 

 

“Is that something you normally carry around?”

 

“Eh, depends on the day. Today it seemed appropriate.” She smiled back at Agatha who just rolled her eyes and pushed through the final door. 

 

As they stepped out into the crisp spring air Agatha breathed in the sweet scents of the daffodils and hyacinth in the nearby garden. Birds were calling to each other and the sun was just beginning to peek behind some passing clouds. It was as if nature itself was rejoicing in their win. 

Rio guided her down the first few steps before glancing back with a smile to ensure she was alright. Then, just as she was about to turn back, her face fell. 

“Whatever happens, keep walking.” She warned Agatha as she pulled her in front of her. She pressed a hand to her back and hurried her down the stairs as a voice rang out. 

 

“AGATHA!” Shouted Evanora as the heavy doors slammed shut behind her. Agatha’s heart sank but she refused to turn around. 

 

“AGATHA MARIE HARKNESS! YOU LOOK AT ME WHEN I'M TALKING TO YOU! THIS IS NOT OVER!”

 

“Keep going, I'll meet you at the car.” Rio whispered to her before stepping away. 

 

“Rio don’t…” she cried as she turned and reached out to stop her but Rio was already half way up the stairs and almost toe to toe with her mother. 

 

“I don’t know, it seems pretty over to me! I’d go back inside if I were you before you end up behind bars.” Rio informed coolly. 

 

“I’m not talking to you you insolent little faggot. This is between me and my daughter.” Evanora spat viciously. 

 

“Oh it’s going to be like that is it? Well, you’re going to have to get through me first.” Rio postured confidently in front of her. 

 

Evanora tried to side step Rio but she swerved and blocked her path. “Out of my way before I do something we’ll both regret.” Evanora warned. 

 

“Do it.” Rio inched closer, hands in her pockets and eyes glowing with antagonistic fury. “I dare you.” 

 

Evanora growled with rage as she brought up her hands to push Rio down the stairs. Rio quickly stepped to the side, dodging the attack and grabed one of Evanora’s arms to twist it around her back as she pulled out her switchblade with the other hand and pressed the tip of it firmly against her lower spine. Evanora’s breath hitched in shock as she winced at the way her arm was being held. 

 

“Rio! Please! You promised!” Agatha cried in horror from the bottom of the stairs. 

 

“I’d listen to her if I were you.” Evanora snarled. 

 

“No you listen to me!” Rio grunted as she tightened her grip on Evanora. “You feel this blade pressing at your back? You wouldn’t believe how easy it would be for me to slide this in between your vertebrae and paralyze you right here on these steps.” Her voice was calm but menacing. “Now, because I love your daughter more than you ever possibly could, I’m not going to do that. Not today at least. But if I ever catch you or any of your fucking cult members sniffing around either of us again, a fine and a jail sentence is going to be the least of your worries. Got it?” She said as she pressed the blade just far enough in to slice a hole into the back of Evanora’s dress. Evanora nodded reluctantly. “I’m sorry, I didn’t quite catch that.” Rio said, twisting her arm further. 

 

“Yes…I understand.” Evanora grunted in pain. 

 

“Good. I’m glad we could come to an agreement on that. Now I’m going to let you go and you’re going to turn around, say nothing, and head back inside. Do I make myself clear?”

 

“Crystal.” Evanora grimaced. 

 

Rio tucked the blade back into her pocket and released Evanora who scurried in embarrassment to the crowd of people gathering at the doors to watch the confrontation. 

 

Satisfied that she had avoided a catastrophe, Rio shuffled down the stairs to Agatha who greeted her with a slap. 

“Ouch! Hey! What was that for?!” She exclaimed as she rubbed her cheek. 

 

“You promised me Rio!” Agatha groaned in frustration. 

 

“I didn’t hurt her! I could have done a lot worse!” Rio explained as she stretched out her jaw. 

 

“What did you say to her?” Agatha demanded. 

 

“I told her to back off, that whatever it was she was after wasn’t worth going to jail over.” Rio insisted. 

 

“That’s it?” Agatha asked, eyeing her skeptically. 

 

“I may have been a little more persuasive with my word choices but that’s the gist.” Rio shrugged innocently. 

 

Agatha pursed her lips, trying not to be amused by Rio’s antics as she started to walk towards the car. “You’re lucky you’re cute otherwise I’d make you walk home.” 

 

“Ah! You think I’m cute?!” Rio giggled as she rushed to catch up with Agatha. 

 

“Sometimes.” Agatha smirked as Rio caught her hand. “When you’re being naughty.” 

 

“Ooo, I should be naughty more often!” Rio smirked. “Would you slap me again if I was?” 

 

“You want me to slap you again?” Agatha snorted 

 

“Um…yeah. It was kind of hot.” Rio admitted bashfully

 

“Hmm, I’ll have to keep that in mind.” She winked playfully as they continued to the car. 

 

Despite the manner in which it had happened she was grateful that Rio had handled her mother and they were free to finally move on. Free to be excited about her future, their future together, and the new life that was going to be joining them before they knew it.

Chapter End Notes

I am so proud of Rio lol. Let's just hope this was the last we saw of Evanora. Things to look forward to - reconnecting with Lilia and the baby shower so please hang in there! I promise it's coming at some point!

Chapter 25: Thirty Four

Chapter Summary

Agatha and Rio meet up with Lilia - Rio has concerns about Agatha. Are the unfounded?

Chapter Notes

As always thank you for your patience! Suffered through some wicked writers block but happy with where this ended up.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

It had been a long and busy shift and Rio was pouring over case files when the call came in. A mother and child had just been admitted by ambulance through to the emergency bay. The child had been breathing on his own but was now having difficulties, chance of a collapsed lung, also signs of cardiac issues. She would find out more when the team transferred to surgery. 

She wasted no time and rushed out into the darkened hallways, eerily silent, void of any other signs of life. She ran for what seemed like forever before she made it to surgery prep to scrub in. Still not a soul in sight but she could hear a flurry of voices and movements bustling just behind the door. She suited up, head to toe in hospital teal and pushed her way through the doors to join the rabble already working. 

She was hit with a wash of antiseptic, iodine, and the iron-y sweet smell of blood. The bodies around her moved in a furious focus as machines blared their songs in a steady blaring rhythm around them. She tried to push her way through to the table but found it too crowded to gain access. She called out for an update but was met with silence and dismissal. Growing frustrated she tried to shout. 

 

“STATUS UPDATE!?”

 

Her throat ached with the fury of her shouting but it was as if her voice was moving through water, nearly soundless and indistinguishable from the cacophony of chaos around her. Bodies continued to shuffle and move as if she was invisible, merely a ghost observing the scene. She looked around in a panicked confusion trying to find someone that would acknowledge her but even as she cornered a nurse the man refused to respond and only rushed past her to care for the patients.  

She stepped back for a moment and watched everyone buzz around her like a swarm of wasps until the alarms began to blare their unyielding drone. Slowly, one by one, people began to step away from the scene, their efforts now in vain. The lights around her dimmed as they left until a single bulb flickered on the tiny form on the table and the woman now shrouded in hospital blankets beside them, her arm dangling loosely off the side of the bed. 

 

Rio let out a shuddering breath as she stood in this tomb, trying to make sense of the chaos and aftermath. What had even happened? Why didn’t they let her in? Why did no one let her help? She slowly crept forward to hover over the bodies, her eyes first drawn to the infant. This frail and feeble creature freshly torn from his mother’s womb. He was so small, he couldn’t have been more than five pounds if that. It had been too soon, his body unable to sustain itself outside his mother’s protection. The evidence of their recent separation still adorned his body, the cord that gave him life still tethered to the organ that had grown alongside him. Couldn’t she have given him a chance to survive? If only they had allowed her the chance to try! 

She drew her mask down as she reached out a finger to press into his minuscule palm. It was so tiny it would have barely wrapped around her finger. She let her other hand drift to rest atop his head as her thumb combed back the few soft brown curls that clung to his peaceful face. His eyes settled closed, his mouth curled into a pout as if at any moment a cry could burst forth. But no sound came, no movements made, just a cold stillness beneath her fingertips. She could feel the tears beginning to well in her eyes, the grief she held for him, for his mother whose last moments brought him into this world only to perish. 

She turned slowly to face her, the woman who had sacrificed everything, her body, her soul, for the life that now lay still beside her. Her arm that hung loose from the table never having a chance to hold him close and whisper to him of the love she must have held. Rio’s heart broke at the thought, each of them so close yet so far. How could she let it remain? 

She turned back to the child and gathered him up in blankets, at last separating him from his bind, and cradled him close. She ducked down and gathered the mother’s arm so that it rested at her side under the cover. It too was cold to the touch but stiffness had not yet reached her. She settled the baby on her chest and brought her hands up to rest around him. 

As she did so the blankets slid down revealing a halo of untamed dark brown curls and waves that seemed to go on forever. Her heart stuttered in her chest as she gathered a strand between her fingers and pulled the length towards her. The faintest hint of lilac and honeysuckle drifted up towards her and she could feel her body go numb with terror. It couldn’t be! She stood, hand hovering just above the edge of the sheet, her fingers shaking in fear as they dared to inch closer and reveal what her heart already knew. She slowly slid the fabric down to reveal a familiar pair of icy blue eyes glazed over and staring back at her. Rio wailed in horror at the image of Agatha’s lifeless body before her. She flung herself atop her as she screamed out,

 

“NO! NO THIS CAN’T… THIS CAN'T BE HAPPENING! PLEASE, MY LOVE! COME BACK TO ME!” 

 

As she lay there heaving with sorrow at her loss she heard a voice calling her name. 

 

“Rio? Rio…”

 

Then she felt her body being shaken and opened her eyes to see who was disturbing her grief. As she blinked into focus she saw Agatha, perched on the edge of the bed, a look of worried concern strewn across her face. 

 

“Sweetheart are you alright?” Agatha asked as she brushed Rio’s sweat drenched hair back away from her face. Rio’s heart flooded with relief at the sight of her. It was just a bad dream, a nightmare that had seemed all too real. She let out a heaving sigh in solace as she sat up and quickly gathered Agatha in her arms. 

 

“That bad huh?” Agatha chuckled as Rio squeezed her tight, unwilling to let her go. 

 

“You have no idea!” She buried her head in her cascading locs, breathing in the fresh, sweet, floral scent. “I thought I’d lost you!” 

 

“Don’t worry! I’m right here.” She cooed as she rubbed soothing circles along Rio’s back. “What time did you end up getting in last night?” She asked as Rio finally released her. 

 

“Not until like 3:00. What time is it?” Rio asked as she searched for her phone.

 

“Almost 11. I came in to wake you to get ready for lunch and you were whimpering and smothering that pillow.” She nodded towards a crumpled pillow that featured an unmistakable drool mark. “Did you have a rough night?” 

 

“Definitely more intense than I had anticipated.” Rio yawned as she stretched. “Someone went into labor a week before their scheduled c-section so it was all hands on deck. Nothing like open heart surgery at one in the morning.” Rio sighed as she flopped back down onto the bed. 

 

“I figured when I didn’t see you during our midnight snack something had come up. Did everything go well?” Agatha asked

 

“Yeah, everyone made it out alright but it was touch and go for a while.” Rio admitted as flashes work the night before blended with the remnants of her dream. “Do you…feel alright?” 

 

“Yes!” Agatha laughed. “Perfect fine! In fact we went down to that donut shop you like and picked out a few. I tried to save you some of the hot pepper jelly donut but he had other plans.” Agatha shrugged in apology as she stroked a hand along the surface of her swollen belly. 

 

Rio sighed in relief as a smile rested on her lips “Oh! I see how it is! You’re gonna talk mama into eating all the good ones.” Rio chuckled and propped herself up to nuzzle her face against the bump. 

 

“He’s very convincing, you know!” Agatha insisted as she smiled down at Rio’s affection. 

 

“I don’t doubt that for a second.” Rio scoffed as she pressed a kiss to the surface. “What did you manage to save for me?” 

 

Agatha nodded towards a box on the nightstand. “They’re in there. There’s a coffee one, something with cinnamon and salted caramel, and a strawberry one. Eat as much as you like, I’m going to finish getting ready.” She said as she struggled to pull herself from the bed. 

 

“Finish what? You look fine! It’s just lunch with Lilia!” Rio called after her as she shuffled to sit at the edge of the bed. 

 

“Rio, this shirt barely covers my stomach and these pants aren’t going to fit if I’m planning to eat anything.” She explained as she breezed over to the closet. 

 

“Ok I get the pants thing but that shirt’s fine. So what if your stomach shows a bit, you are like 8 months pregnant!” Rio shrugged as she reached for the box of donuts.

 

“No! Not yet! Seven and a half! I don’t need you rushing this any more than it already has been.” Agatha chided.

 

“Sorry. Seven and a half.” Rio rolled her eyes as she opened the box. “Hey! There’s a bite out of every one of these!” 

 

Agatha wandered out of the closet, half undressed with a new outfit in hand, sporting a less than apologetic smile as she headed to the bathroom. “What can I say? I needed to know which one he preferred.” 

 

“Likely story! I guess I should be glad I’m getting any at this point.” She grabbed the salted caramel donut and threw the box on the bed before wandering into the bathroom to sit on the counter and watch as Agatha got ready. “You sure you’re up for this today?” She asked, eyebrows raised skeptically as she took a bite of the donut.

 

“Why wouldn’t I be?” Agatha frowned as she placed a few bobby pins into her mouth to hold while she put up her hair. 

 

“I wasn’t sure if you’d rather rest today, I know you have a crazy week coming up and you heard what Dr. Allen said.” Rio reminded her, treading cautiously as to not spark an argument. 

 

“And I’m following those guidelines. Not doing anything too strenuous, reducing stress where I can, resting as much as possible.” Agatha replied snidely.

 

“Except for today.” Rio scoffed under her breath. Agatha turned to glare at her as she took a large bite of the donut. 

 

“Like you said, it’s just lunch with Lilia, I think I can manage.” Agatha replied with an irritated smirk. 

 

“Ok, so maybe it’s a little more than just lunch. Do you really want to hash everything out right now? We could always wait until after the baby is born, she’ll understand.” 

 

“Why? I'd rather get it over with and move on.” Agatha waved her hand dismissively as she continued getting ready. 

 

“I get that, I do, I’m just worried it might be a bit stressful right at this moment.” Rio posited

 

“Stressful for who, hon? Between the two of us you’re the one who's been a nervous wreck lately.” Agatha scoffed

 

“For good reason! Last week with your mother was intense to say the least. Then Dr. Allen only reaffirmed my concerns about your health and the risks that it poses as we get closer to delivery. And of course you refuse to slow down or take a step back at work, despite what she told you!” 

 

“Are we really doing this again?” Agatha groaned as she rolled her eyes.

 

“No, at this point I know there’s no changing your mind about it, even though it drives me crazy!” Rio sighed heavily as she finished her donut. “I love you, and I love her, and I want everyone to be happy and get along but I’m also well aware of the potential this has to turn into a thing which you don’t need right now.” Rio stressed

 

“Rio, I’ll be fine! After dealing with my mother this is going to be a breeze. There’s definitely a few things we’ll need to discuss, but your aunt seems…reasonable. Coo coo for sure, but at least we can have a conversation without her spewing some bigoted nonsense. And as long as she doesn’t pull any stunts…” Agatha narrowed her gaze to Rio as she brought up a warning finger. 

 

“Oh believe, me she is on thin ice and she knows it! She promised me she would be on her best behavior.” Rio groaned as she leaned back against the mirror. “I guess you’re right. She was really excited when I called and asked if she wanted to meet us for lunch. Despite what she did, she does really like you.” Rio let a shy smirk play on her lips.

 

“Oh? That’s news to me!” Agatha snorted a little doubtfully as she began brushing her teeth. 

 

“Really though. I don’t think she would have gone to those lengths with any of my other girlfriends. She probably would have sat back and waited for it to blow up on its own. Not to say that that would have happened in our case but…she does have a sense about these things.”

 

“Oh really?” Agatha mumbled through a mouthful of toothpaste.

 

“I think she saw how happy you made me and wanted to make sure I didn’t fuck it up.” Rio chuckled to herself, her gaze drifting to fixate at a point on the floor as her mind pondered a familiar question. “I do sometimes wonder what would have happened if she never told me.”

 

“Oh yeah? And how does that usually play out?” Agatha asked as she dried her face. 

 

“Honestly it could have gone any number of ways. I figure, you would have probably realized eventually, definitely before me.” Rio reasoned

 

“Don’t be so sure!” Agatha scoffed as she started to dig through her makeup bag. 

 

“But then I wonder…would you have even told me or just ghosted me?” Rio smirked as she raised an eyebrow in Agatha’s direction.

 

“Hmm, hard to say…” Agatha replied only half engaged in the conversation as she applied a lip stain. 

 

“Come on, if you had to guess…” Rio urged as she turned to gather Agatha’s attention in the mirror. 

 

“I mean…I don’t know how I would have told you!” Agatha sighed exasperatedly as she threw the lipstain back in the bag. “I probably would have assumed this would scare you away and called the whole thing off without ever saying anything about it.” She shrugged as she picked up her eyeliner.

 

“You know I wouldn’t have gone quietly. Once I have my mind set it’s pretty hard to dissuade me.” Rio insisted as she laid herself down in front of where Agatha was trying to ready herself.

 

“Well I know that now!” Agatha gruffed as she threw down the pencil in her hand. “And what if I had told you? Huh? Do you think if I had come to you and told you I was pregnant you would have been as adamant about making this work?” Agatha asked, eyebrows hitched in challenge. 

 

Rio mulled the question over for a moment. “I want to say yes…but really… I don’t know. I’ve been burned in so many other relationships I could definitely see myself taking it as a hint to move on.” Rio replied as she blinked up at the ceiling. Agatha could feel a lump form in her throat at that admission. “But then again,” Rio smiled, turning to Agatha, “for that brief moment you did ghost me, I thought I was going to go insane without you. Having that heads up really did give me time to think about what I really wanted.”

 

“Oh? And what was that?” Agatha asked as she crossed her arms above her bump.

 

 Rio hopped down off the counter and moved to stand behind Agatha, resting her head on her shoulder as she watched them both in the mirror. “You!” That simple word elicited a spark that drew a flush to Agatha’s cheeks. “And him, of course” She guided her hands down around the swell, feeling him move along the surface. “And this life we are building together.” 

She pressed a kiss to Agatha’s cheek, who turned her head in response, her ocean blue eyes reflecting the love Rio held for her. She turned further, bringing a hand up to guide Rio’s lips to hers in a tender but all consuming kiss. Their mouths moved in sync, a perfect rhythm of exploration and discovery as they vied to show and receive the love between them. 

Agatha, at last, smiled, parting their lips. “I guess I should be thanking your aunt then.” 



—-------------------------------------------------------



An hour later they were seated at the restaurant, Agatha was on her phone sorting through work emails, her knee bouncing in irritated anticipation as they waited for Lilia to arrive. Rio was resting her head against the back of the booth, her gaze fixed on Agatha as she soaked in every detail of the woman beside her. How her long hair was swirled in a loose bun on top of her head that had already surrendered a few strands to fall and frame her sharp features. How her lips puckered as her eyes darted over one diatribe after another as she sorted through her inbox. The way her nose would scrunch when she read something that particularly displeased her. Every feature, every mannerism she studied carefully as if it might disappear right before her eyes. For, even though it had been hours since she woke from her horrid dream, she couldn’t shake the nagging worry it had stirred in her. 

 

“Cariño, did you remember to take your medication this morning?” She asked as her worrying became insurmountable. 

 

“Yes, dear.” Agatha rolled her eyes dismissively as she continued tapping away on her phone. 

 

“Just making sure.” Rio breathed nervously. 

 

“You’re always so worried about me!” Agatha snorted as a smirk tugged at her lips. 

 

“Who me? No! Never!” Rio snorted as she tried to play off her concern. 

 

“You can relax. I told you I’m doing everything Dr. Allen said.” Agatha set her phone down as she turned her attention fully to Rio. “In fact, you’d be proud of me, I even meditated after my walk this morning.” She said as she preened, tucking a loose piece of hair behind her ear.

 

“Oh really?” Rio replied with a look of amused suspicion. 

 

“So maybe it was only five minutes, and I may have been eating a donut at the same time but I’m counting it.”

 

 “Hey, I’ll give you an A for effort.” She leaned over and gave Agatha a peck on the cheek before resting her head on her shoulder. 

 

“You did tell your aunt we were meeting here at noon right?” Agatha grumbled as she looked at her watch.

 

“I actually told her 11:45.” Rio snorted

 

“You know she’s nearly 20 minutes late!” Agatha gruffed, growing ever more impatient by the minute. 

 

“She’s usually running late but I’ll admit, this is a record even for her.” Rio sat up and quickly checked her phone and saw it void of notifications. “I’ll give her a few more minutes and then give her a call. We can order something to snack on if you’re hungry.” 

 

“No, I’m sure as soon as we order something she’ll show up so we might as well wait.” Agatha sighed disappointedly

 

“You sure? She won’t mind. Besides you do seem… a little…”

 

“A little what?!” Agatha snapped

 

Rio bit her lip, debating with herself before she finally responded “Hangry.”

 

“I am not hangry, I just find it irritating when people are inconsiderate of other people’s time.” Agatha replied, doing a poor job of hiding her frustration.

 

“Where else do you have to be?” Rio snickered 

 

“Nowhere, but if you say we’re eating at noon and we don’t even order until 12:30, that means the food isn’t even going to get to our table until almost one. I feel like I’m allowed to be a little…”

 

“Hangry?” Rio snorted

 

“Fine! Yes! I’m hangry.” Agatha groaned. 

 

“Then let’s get an appetizer at least.” Rio chuckled to herself as she reached for the menu. “Look, they have shishito peppers, he’ll love those. Marinated cucumber salad, basically pickles. Roasted artichoke? Anything sound good?”

 

“Ugh, all of it! I’m so hungry I could eat my face.” Agatha groaned as she collapsed forward resting her forehead on the table.

 

“Then all of it you shall have, my love! Just help me flag down our waiter if you see him.” 

 

“Honestly I’ve not seen him since we sat down.” Agatha pouted as she sat up and scouted the restaurant. “That’s it! I’m going to go track him down.” 

 

“Are you sure? I can go find him.” Rio offered

 

“Rio, I’m fine, I need to stretch my legs anyway. You figure out where your aunt is.” Agatha pointed at Rio as she pried herself from the booth with a grunt.

 

“I’ll give her a call and make sure she knows today is Sunday. Sometimes she gets her wires crossed.”  

As Agatha shuffled off Rio quickly dialed Lilia and brought the phone up to her ear. It rang a few times before going to voicemail. Rio groaned as she hung up and immediately redialed. Just as the phone began to ring again she caught sight of Lilia’s ancient conversion van rolling into the parking lot. She hung up the phone and sat back as she watched her struggle to park, in the end taking up a space and a half. After a few minutes Lilia stumbled out of the vehicle, flung a mammoth sized tote bag over her shoulder, fumbled with her keys for a bit, then scurried into the restaurant to meet them. Rio rolled her eyes as she rose to wave her over to the table. 

 

“So sorry I’m late, doll! I was gardening and lost track of time then I couldn’t find my damn keys!” Lilia huffed as she swallowed Rio in a hug. 

 

“Or a matching pair of shoes apparently.” Rio snorted

 

Lilia glanced down only now realizing her mistake. “Ah, well, it’s a fashion statement. How are you? How’s your lady love? Is she here?” Lilia looked around expectantly

 

“Yeah, she went to find our waiter, she’ll be right back. Remember, when she gets here, no funny stuff. Ignore whatever your intuition is telling you to do. At least for today alright?” Rio pleaded.

 

“I know, I know, best behavior! Are you alright dear? You’re looking a little knackered.” Lilia asked as they settled into the booth.

 

“I’m alright, just tired.” Rio yawned

 

“Late night?” Lilia asked as she shoved her enormous bag into the corner. 

 

“Yeah but I slept pretty much until we had to leave. I shouldn't be this tired!” Rio frowned. 

 

“Bad dreams then?” Lilia pried, her eyes twinkling knowingly.

 

“We’re not doing this.” Rio warned

 

“Doing what?” Lilia shrugged innocently

 

“Reading into things! I don’t need you overanalyzing my nightmares right now.”

 

“What’s there to overanalyze? You’ve told me practically nothing!” Lilia threw her hands up in surrender as Rio glared daggers at her. “Though…”

 

“Don’t.” Rio grumbled through gritted teeth

 

“If you’re having nightmares again…” Lilia continued

 

“Lilia I said don’t!” Rio’s tone was severe and final.

 

“Alright! Alright! I’ll drop it, for now at least.” She agreed, at last resigning herself.

 

“What did I tell you! As soon as I order this food she’s going to show up!” Agatha scoffed as she sidled up to the table. “Hello Lilia, glad you could finally join us.” she huffed as she scooted into the booth. 

 

“I was honored by the invitation!” She beamed back at Agatha, seemingly ignorant of her irritation. “It’s so good to see you again, dear! How’s everything? How have you been feeling? How’s the little one? It’s been a while since we’ve all seen each other!” 

 

“It certainly has! I think the last time I saw you you managed to run a pregnancy test on me without my knowledge.” Agatha leaned back in her seat as she crossed her arms over her stomach and glared annoyedly at Lilia.

 

“Ah! Right to it I see. Well, I guess there is no point in beating around the bush then.” Lilia shrugged apologetically “A terribly regrettable decision on my part. Truly. I’m so sorry for overstepping and pulling that stunt. I should have known better.” 

 

“That’s the understatement of the century.” Rio mumbled

 

“Why though? You didn’t have to do all of that, you could have just come and talked to me.” Agatha insisted

 

“That’d be a little rude wouldn’t it? You’re not really supposed to ask people if they’re pregnant.” Lilia snorted as she took a drink of her water. 

 

Agatha let out a breath of laughter in disbelief. “So, let me get this straight. You knew it would be rude to ask me if I was pregnant but not rude to rig up a pregnancy test in the bathroom and go to Rio with it?” 

 

“It seemed like the right idea at the time, but then again so did the mushrooms.” Lilia winced in regret.

 

“Wait, you had taken mushrooms?” Rio glared at her

 

“I was microdosing, but may have gotten carried away with it. That’s beside the point.” Lilia waved her hands as she redirected the conversation. “I can’t tell you the number of times I’ve tried to warn or inform people directly of what lies ahead only for it to completely backfire and cause more damage than I could ever imagine. I suspected you might not have known, but then again I couldn’t be sure. I knew if I’d talked to you I would’ve inevitably said the wrong thing or you wouldn’t have believed me and it would likely have destroyed this beautiful relationship you two were building.”

 

“Um…it nearly did!” Rio grumbled.  

 

“And yet here you two are, closer than ever!” Lilia smiled tightly before turning her attention back to Agatha. “This one barely believed me and I had the tests to prove it! People don’t tend to listen to warnings, especially if there’s no evidence to back it up, so I’ve learned to either bite my tongue or find the proof. I chose the latter. Which was selfish of me and I’m so incredibly sorry for that. As for choosing to tell Rio, we’re family and she’s used to my eccentricities. I knew I wouldn’t be blamed for ruining everything if I talked with her first. Besides, she needed to know, especially if you didn’t.”

 

“Why exactly?” Agatha asked through pursed lips, eyebrows hitched in doubtful skepticism. 

 

“I know my niece quite well, better than she knows herself half the time,” Lilia glanced pointedly at Rio, “after all these years of disastrous relationships she was just within reach of having the life she always wanted and deserved so long as she kept her head about her. Telling her gave her the chance to put things into perspective and be there for you in the ways you needed, especially if you didn’t know.” Lilia elaborated, explaining casually as if this was all reasonable justification for what she had done. 

 

Agatha’s face twisted in contemplation as she considered what Lilia was saying just as a more personal question rose to the surface. “How did you know I was pregnant, before the test?”

 

“Oh honey, I saw it the moment I met you!” Lilia laughed as if she had asked the most obvious question.

 

“How could you? I didn’t even know!” Agatha half shouted, exasperatedly

 

Lilia bit her lip as she glanced at Rio who rolled her eyes and motioned for her to continue. “Call it a blessing, call it a curse, but I’ve always seen things for what they truly are. You had that glow about you for sure but more than that, this little one already had quite an aura about himself. Then, of course, your cards only reconfirmed my suspicions.” 

 

Agatha shook her head laughing at the incredulity, “Unbelievable! So sheer dumb luck and obscene nosiness! Got it!” She barked back at Lilia. 

 

“Insight darling! If you’re open minded enough and willing to receive it the universe will tell you all you need to know!” She explained with another pointed glance to Rio. 

 

“I have an order of the peppers, a cucumber salad, and a roasted artichoke. Have you all had a chance to decide on your entree?” The waiter interrupted as he plopped down the plates between them.

 

“Um…I think we may need another minute.”  Rio replied as she watched the simmering tension threatening to burst forth from Agatha. 

 

“Don’t go far, it will only be a minute!” Agatha snapped as he started to walk away.

 

“Uh, yeah, no worries, I’m just going to check on a couple other tables and I’ll be right back to get your order.” He replied nervously before bolting from their table.

 

“Why don’t we take a break, figure out what we want, and eat a bit before we dive back in?” Rio suggested trying to de-escalate the situation.

 

“Fine by me!” Agatha huffed as she slid the plate of peppers towards her. 

 

They sat in an awkward silence as Lilia perused the menu and Agatha proceeded to devour the food in front of her. Rio sat cautiously on the edge of her seat, her body practically vibrating with anxiety at how the conversation was devolving. She held her breath, hoping that with some sustenance in her, Agatha would be more open to resolving things before they escalated any further. 

 

With the plates cleared and their order having been taken, Rio cautiously checked in with Agatha. “Feeling better, cariño?” Rio asked gently as a small smile tugged at the corner of her lips. 

 

“I don’t feel like I’m about to murder someone anymore, if that’s what you’re asking.” Agatha replied snarkily as she shot a glare to Lilia.

 

“Good, now as we continue, let’s all try and stay calm, there’s no need to get worked up at this point. What’s done is done. We’re all just trying to figure out how to move forward, ok?” Rio posited as her worried eyes bore into Agatha. 

 

Agatha rolled her eyes and let out a deep sigh. “I guess at this point my only question is how am I expected to trust you, given everything?”

 

“Fair enough. I haven’t really given you any reason to trust me, even though I was right about my suspicions from the start.” Lilia grumbled. 

 

“Lilia!” Rio scolded 

 

“That’s beside the point.” She waved her hands, brushing off Rio’s scathing glare. “All I can say is I’m sorry for how I acted, and I regret it deeply. Overall I just want the best for you, all of you, and though it may take time to earn your trust back I’m willing to do what it takes for us to be on good terms, even if that means giving you two space.” 

 

Agatha gave a sideways glance to Rio as she considered Lilia’s apology. She seemed genuine in her remorse and though she was a bit kooky, Agatha couldn’t deny her authenticity and the care she had for them both. Somehow, despite all Lilia had done, she had found this soft and tender place inside Agatha’s heart where she could only assume her mothers love would have existed, if Evanora had had the capacity to show it. 

 

“Thank you Lilia, I appreciate your transparency and effort. You are an important part of Rio’s life and she is an important part of mine now. Given that, I’m willing to move forward and put the past behind us, so long as you feel comfortable coming to me with any questions or concerns rather than plotting behind my back going forward.” 

 

Lilia shot a quick glance at Rio before replying, “Seems reasonable enough.” She flashed Agatha a tight but agreeable smile. “Oh, before I forget, I did bring you something!” Lilia gasped as she began to dig around in her purse. “I found it the other day when I was cleaning out one of my closets, right before you called me about this lunch actually, and it struck me as something you might like.” Agatha threw an anxious glance at Rio as she waited nervously for Lilia to find whatever she was looking for. “Ah! Here it is!” She pulled out a small purple satin pouch and handed it to Agatha. “It was something I had saved for Rio but it never really seemed to suit her taste and I figured she wouldn’t mind if I gave it to you.” 

Agatha cautiously undid the ribbon holding it closed and shook the item out of the bag into her palm. As she turned it over in her hand she realized it was a small golden locket, the face of which held a purple stone with three white, statue-like figures inlaid in the center. She glanced over at Rio whose eyes were growing glassy with tears.

 

“It was my mother’s.” Rio breathed as her voice cracked. “I didn’t realize you still had it.”

 

“Of course I did! I figured one day you’d find someone worthy of gifting it to, so I held onto it. It’s good luck, you know! A family heirloom, one of the few we still have.”

 

“Are you sure you want me to have this?” Agatha asked as she looked back and forth between the two. Rio nodded as she wiped a tear from the corner of her eye.

 

“Consider it a peace offering and a welcome to the family.”

 

Agatha examined the small token in her hand. The weight of it felt more significant than any of the numerous items her family had ever owned. She slid the locket around her neck and leaned over to press a soft kiss to Rio’s lips. 

 

“Thank you, that…that means a lot. More than you realize after the week we just survived with my mother.” Agatha groaned

 

“Oh dear, Rio mentioned that whole ordeal was hellacious!” Lilia exclaimed just as the rest of their food arrived.

 

“Hellacious doesn’t even begin to cover it.” Rio grumbled “That woman is the spawn of Satan himself! You wouldn’t believe the shit she tried to pull!” 

 

“I’m sorry to hear that.” Lilia cooed sympathetically.

 

“It’s fine, really. It all worked out in our favor and now she’s legally bound from interfering in our lives.” Agatha sighed, relieved.

 

“It’s always baffling to me how parents can turn on their own children. And now, she’s missing out on what I’m sure would have been the highlight of her life because of it.” Lilia reasoned

 

“Oh, she never wanted me. I’m more than convinced of that and I’ve made my peace with it. But, for some reason, she had it in her head that grandmother was the role she was really meant to play.” Agatha groaned as she dug into her salad.

 

“Ha! As if! Even the judge saw how terrible she was and set that shit in stone for 10 years.” Rio scoffed

 

“Well five but we can renew it.” Agatha clarified. 

 

“I’m glad you have some peace of mind at least and can focus on more important things. Speaking of, how much longer until we get to meet the little bambino?” Lilia asked

 

“I’m due in about six weeks, ugh which feels horrifying to say!” She turned to Rio half shocked. “Is it really only six weeks?”

 

“Yeah, just about.” Rio chuckled. “I told you we really have to start moving with getting things ready now that the lawsuit is settled.” 

 

“Fuck! It’s all happening so fast. I have no idea how we’re going to get everything together in time, especially since I’m in crunch time now with the festival.” Rio flashed a sideways half annoyed half concerned look in Agatha’s direction.

 

“What festival?” Lilia asked as the waiter delivered their food. 

 

“Agatha is in charge of organizing the May Festival for music hall.” Rio explained

 

“Oh! That’s always been one of my favorites. I’ve heard you’re expanding it a bit this year.”

 

“Expanding is an understatement! Not only will we have our regular festivities inside, we’ll be taking over the block and hosting a night market with artists and performances stationed around the building and a second stage in the back. This is set for every weekend in May and each weekend is a different theme. It’s been an undertaking to say the least. Only this week and next to try and pull everything together, hopefully.” Agatha let out a deep sigh of frustration. 

 

“Knowing you it will all come together perfectly in the end.” Rio beamed as she gathered Agatha’s hand to press a kiss to her knuckles. 

 

“Well if you need help getting anything together for the baby I’m more than happy to assist. I have too much time on my hands as it is.” Lilia offered

 

“Honestly I’ll probably take you up on that. I don’t think we’ll have a choice at this point, we’ll need all the help we can get. Ooo, which reminds me, what are you doing next Saturday?” Rio asked excitedly.

 

“Same as yesterday, same as everyday, whatever the fuck I want. Why? You got something in mind?” Lilia replied, eyes gleaming in anticipation.

 

Rio shot Agatha a devious look to which she just rolled her eyes. “I’m throwing Agatha a baby shower, would you like to come?”

 

Lilia’s face couldn’t hide her initial displeasure but she quickly put on a brave face, “You know if it were anyone else I would say absolutely not, those things usually make me want to pull my hair out, but for you two of course I’ll come.”

 

Agatha snorted in laughter at the bluntness of her reply. “Honestly I feel the exact same way! I tried to convince her it wasn’t worth the effort but she insisted.”

 

“The two of you are party poopers! I promise it’s going to be a good time!” Rio exclaimed as she scowled at them both. 

 

“It’s going to be nauseating but I fear I don’t have a choice at this point.” Agatha groaned.

 

“You really don’t trust me to pull this off do you?” Rio challenged

 

“Oh I trust you completely, it’s the rest of those people I’m not too sure about!” Agatha sneered, her nose wrinkling in disgust. 

 

“Our friends?” Rio laughed

 

“Please! They’re going to make a bigger deal out of this than it needs to be. You know Jen won't be able to help herself!” 

 

“I think you’ll be pleasantly surprised, in fact I bet you’ll even enjoy yourself!” Rio goaded with a taunting smile. 

 

“Oh really? Is that so? And what exactly are the stakes?” Agatha replied, narrowing her eyes in challenge. 

 

“If you enjoy yourself like I know you will, smiling, laughing, having an overall good time, you get to be the one to write the thank you notes.” Rio said decisively.

 

“And if it’s the moderately enjoyable afternoon of forced pleasantries that I expect it will be you’ll write them?” Agatha reasoned

 

“Seems fair.” Rio shrugged, unbothered by the challenge. 

 

“Alright, deal.” Agatha agreed as she returned to her salad. 

 

“Haha! Bet! You’re going to have so much fun you’re not going to know what to do with yourself.” Rio replied giddily, nearly overcome with excitement. 

 

“You’re setting that bar pretty high. I hope you know that.” Agatha warned

 

“Oh baby I’m the high jump champ! Better get that writing hand ready. You don’t want to get a cramp!” Rio taunted

 

“You two really are made for each other!” Lilia chuckled as she observed the two bickering. “Is there a registry or anything specific I should bring?”

 

“Agatha’s friend Jen, you remember her from karaoke, she put together a registry, I’ll send it to you.” Rio replied

 

“That would be lovely!” Lilia smiled as she pushed her empty plate away from her. “Well ladies, I hate to eat and run but I have hot yoga at two and Bob, who’s running the session today, won’t let you in if you’re more than five minutes late!” Lilia groaned as she scooted herself from the bench. As she stood she sifted through her bag to pull out a crumpled wad of cash that she threw on the table to cover the bill. 

 

“You don’t have to do that! I’ve got it!” Rio chuckled as she and Agatha stood to say their goodbyes. 

 

“Please, it’s the least I can do!” Lilia replied with a dismissive wave. “It was so good to see you, sweetheart!” She leaned in, smothering Rio in a hug before turning to Agatha. “You two take it easy, don’t let this one give you any trouble!” She said, pointing a thumb in Rio’s direction before she wrapped an arm around Agatha’s side and let the other rest on the swell. Just as her fingers grazed the surface her breath caught. She glanced down at the bump before her eyes locked with Rio’s, flashing her a brief but undeniable look of worry and alarm with Agatha none the wiser. She quickly hid her concern with a smile as she turned back to Agatha, “Take care of each other.” she muttered with a slight unease in her voice as her gaze flashed back to Rio, “Get some good sleep while you can and I’ll see you both on Saturday.” With a wave of her fingers she scurried out the door and sped away in her van.

 

“She is absolutely bonkers, but I have to say I’m fond of her…” Agatha babbled as she settled back in to finish her meal. Rio stood silently for a moment, eyes fixed on the door, as she tried to decipher the warning look Lilia had given her, the concern in her eyes reigniting the pang of worry she had woken up with.  What did she know? What had she seen? The questions were making her sick. 

 

“Rio!” Agatha’s voice shook her from her daze

 

“Yes, my love?” Rio replied reflexively 

 

“Are you going to sit back down or just stand there staring at nothing?” Agatha scoffed as she looked her up and down. 

 

“Sorry, I was… I was just thinking.” Rio mumbled as she moved to join Agatha. 

 

“About what?” Agatha asked, more engaged in finishing her salad than Rio’s answer. 

 

Rio stuttered as she tried to piece together a thought that wouldn’t raise alarm bells. “That….um…that went well, don’t you think?”

 

“Yes, dear, that’s what I was just saying. I’m glad we did this.”

 

“Yeah me too.” Rio said softly, staring at Agatha as if at any moment she could disintegrate before her.

 

Agatha frowned with an amused smile as she took in Rio’s concerned expression. “Why are you looking at me like that?”

 

“Like what?” Rio shook her head as she’d eyes grew wide with caution. 

 

“You look like a sad puppy.” Agatha chortled

 

“Oh, I’m… just tired.” She tried to pry a reassuring smile from her lips. “Agatha…I love you.”

 

“I love you too, weirdo.” 

 

————————————————

 

Over the next few days Rio did all she could to distract her nagging thoughts. She poured herself into her work as Agatha returned to her hectic schedule of festival planning. She cleaned relentlessly, organizing each room of Agatha’s house, putting all of her energy towards preparing for the baby and the baby shower. Every moment they were together she hovered over Agatha, attending to her every whim, ensuring she was calm, relaxed and comfortable and wanted for nothing. All this in an effort to quell the anxieties that grew as the nightmares continued night after night. 

 

By the time Thursday rolled around, Agatha couldn’t help but notice this renewed effort as she stumbled upon Rio in the kitchen early that morning, elbow deep in the freezer, the contents of her pantry and fridge spread across every available surface.

 

“Have you gotten any rest this week?” She asked, startling Rio who knocked her head on the shelf above her.

 

“OUCH! Jeez you scared the shit out of me!” Rio groaned as she rubbed the sore spot at the back of her head. “Yeah, I’ve had a few hours here and there. I made breakfast. Have a seat, I’ll make you a plate.”

 

“That’s alright I can get it myself. You’ve been going non-stop the last few days. I’m worried if you keep this up you’re going to burn yourself out!” Agatha chided as she grabbed some food and settled into the stool at the counter. 

 

“You’re one to talk, not getting home until nearly 9 last night! Besides, I’m just trying to get things ready and make sure you both have what you need before he gets here.” Rio said as she resumed cleaning out the freezer.

 

“I told you, this week and next are going to be demanding getting the final details to fall into place but as soon as we get through the first weekend things will ease up.” Agatha reiterated. 

 

“And you’ll take some time off?” Rio pressed as she furiously scrubbed the inside of the fridge. 

 

“I didn’t say that, but I will be back to a more normal schedule, I promise.” Agatha assured.

 

“Uh-huh.” Rio grumbled, not quite buying that pledge

 

“Rio, take a break, come sit with me.” Agatha asked, beckoning her over.

 

“I’m just finishing wiping everything down and then I have to put all this stuff back in before it spoils. You go ahead and eat.” Rio replied as she continued to rush around the kitchen.

 

“Rio, sit.” Agatha demanded as she shot her a non-negotiable glare. Rio threw down her rag and reluctantly closed the freezer then padded over to sink into the chair next to Agatha. “What’s going on? You’ve been a little tightly wound this week.”

 

“What do you mean?” Rio asked as she grabbed herself a plate of food.

 

“Sweetheart, you’ve been working your crazy shifts at the hospital then you come home and you won’t let me lift a finger, even to grab a snack. You barely sleep, you’re up at all hours of the night cleaning this place from top to bottom. While I appreciate your doting nature you’ve taken it to another level. And don’t think I haven’t noticed the way you look at me, like I might fall apart at any minute. So again, I ask, what’s going on?” Agatha pressed as Rio avoided her gaze. 

 

Rio let out a heavy breath as she stared down at her plate, thinking of how to respond to Agatha. She didn’t want to add any worries or concerns that would cause Agatha any stress, yet she knew Agatha would only continue to pry without some sort of explanation.

 

“I don’t know, I think it just hit me how little time there is left and there’s so much to get done. You have enough on your plate, too much in my opinion and I can’t deny, it bothers me. I know you don’t really have a choice so anything that I can take off your plate I will, to make sure you’re ok, both of you.” She explained as she picked at some breakfast potatoes. 

 

“I appreciate that, my love, I really do, but seeing you like this, it is worrying. Yes, there’s a lot to get done and I admire that you’re willing to pick up the slack, but we have time, it doesn’t all need to happen right now. It’s more important to me that you take care of yourself too.” Agatha urged as she dug into her own meal.

 

Rio bit her lip as she shifted the food on her plate. “You’re right. I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to worry you.”

 

“Of course I’m right! And you have nothing to be sorry about. It’s a selfish request on my part. I’ll need you at your best, well rested with a clear head when he arrives. If you keep this up you’ll be running on fumes and no good to either of us.” She reached over and hooked a finger under Rio’s chin and turned her face towards her. “I can’t do this without you.” 

 

Rio let out a nervous breath as her lips twitched into a smile. She wished she could just refocus and relax the way Agatha was urging her to, but every time she took a break or closed her eyes, the horrid visions and thoughts of Agatha in distress flooded her mind. And how could she tell her? How could she begin to explain the depth of the fear that was holding her hostage in her own mind? Doing so would only inspire panic and if she truly wanted to avoid these visions coming to fruition she had to do all she could to reassure her and set her mind at ease.

 

“I know. You won’t have to, I promise. I’ll…take it easy.” Rio agreed, relenting to Agatha’s request. 

 

“You could always meditate.” Agatha quipped with a cheeky grin as she booped Rio on the nose.

 

“Using my own advice against me I see!” Rio snorted as she took a bite of her food at last. 

 

“If I have to do it, so do you! I’m told it can help with stress, and you, my dear, seem very stressed. Are you working today?”

 

“No, I’m off through Saturday though I do have to start getting ready for your party.” Rio reminded with a smirk.

 

“Ugh, we’re still doing that?” Agatha groaned as she rolled her eyes.

 

“Yes, my love, it’s happening.” Rio insisted

 

“Well, if nothing else you should find something to do that has nothing to do with me or the baby, just for today. You’ll have plenty of time tomorrow to prepare.” Agatha instructed

 

“But…Agatha” Rio began in protest.

 

“But nothing! In fact, I’m banning you from the house, at least for the day. You can come home for dinner. Give me your key.” Agatha turned and held out her hand.

 

“You can’t be serious!” Rio chuckled as she gave Agatha an disapproving glare.

 

“Deadly serious, my love.” Agatha’s eyes flickered with a kind of warning certainty that let Rio know this was not up for debate. 

 

She slid off the stool and went in search of her keys. “When is this supposed to start? I at least have to finish putting the kitchen back together before I leave.”

 

“You can stay until I have to leave for work, then go find something to do.”

 

“Like what?!” Rio groaned as she rifled through her bag.

 

“I don’t know! Go see a movie, go to a bookstore. Hell, see if Alice is up for one of your little games or something. Just give your mind a rest with all the baby stuff while you still can. You'll have plenty of time to worry about all of that when he’s here!” 

 

“Fine!” Rio grunted as she dropped the key into Agatha’s hand. “I guess I’ll see if Alice wants to join a pick up game later or something. I’ve been meaning to catch up with her anyway.” Rio sighed begrudgingly. 

 

“Perfect! Now, I’m going to finish getting ready, you work on putting this place back together, I’m leaving in about 30 minutes.” 

 

“Yes, dear.” Rio grumbled as she moved their plates to the sink. 

 

Before she wandered down the hallway Agatha moved to stand behind Rio, her arms wrapping around her waist as best she could with her swollen belly squished between them and rested her chin on her shoulder. “You know that I love you, deeply, otherwise I wouldn’t be doing this.” 

 

“I do.” Rio sighed as she let her head rest against Agatha’s. “I know if it were you I’d probably be telling you the same thing.”

 

“Good!” Agatha said as she pressed a kiss to Rio’s cheek, “I’m glad you understand.” She pried herself away and began to head down the hall just as Rio’s voice called out to her.

 

“Agatha…”

 

“Yes, my love?”

 

Rio appeared around the corner holding a glass of water with a pill in the other hand, “Forget something?” she smirked as she raised a scolding eyebrow at her.

 

“Ah…right. How could I forget?” Agatha grimaced as she quickly swallowed the pill and handed the glass back to Rio. “See! What would I do without you?” She said as she patted her cheek before waddling back down the hallway. 

 

—-------------------------------------------

 

Half an hour later Rio was seated in Agatha’s driveway, utterly nauseated at the dismal thoughts running through her mind in the quiet stillness. Now, alone, in the silence of her car her fears screamed their persistent worries. What if something happened to Agatha? To the baby? What if she wasn’t there when she needed her? What if she couldn’t save them? How could she live with herself if she lost either of them, or worse, both? She shook her head and pressed her hands against her face. Even if there was something to be concerned about there was nothing she could do about it at the moment and there was no use wallowing in this self pity at something that was likely not to pass. She let out a frustrated growl as she released what tension she could before reaching for her phone. She quickly pulled up Alice’s contact and called her, putting the receiver on speaker. It rang a few times before Alice picked up.

 

“Hey dude! What’s up?! I wasn’t sure if I was going to hear from you before Saturday or not.”

 

“Yeah, it’s been pretty crazy around here. Any chance you’re free for a game today? I think I need to let off some steam.”

 

“Yeah, I’m down. Jen’s at work and I don’t have anything until 4. I can meet you at your place in an hour?”

 

“Sounds like a plan, I’ll see you there.” Rio hung up the phone and flung it into the passenger’s seat beside her. She took a deep breath and started the car before finally peeling out of Agatha’s driveway. 




As she pulled into the parking lot she felt this odd sense of deja vu settle over her. This was her home that she was still paying rent for, but after the last few weeks of living with Agatha it felt more like she was a visitor returning to see an old friend. She pried herself from the car, slamming the door behind her and made her way into the vast entryway of the former school building. The sunlight gleamed through the opulent stained glass as she ascended the grand staircase, opting for the scenic route to her apartment. The colorful prisms gleamed along the walls and floors breaking her out of the cloud of grey that had been hovering over her these past few days. 

The quiet, empty halls echoed with her footsteps as she continued down the hallway to her door. The familiar smells of antique wood and something sweet and cinnamony wafting out from a neighboring apartment welcomed her back. As she stood before her door, sunlight illuminating the frosted glass, she searched her bag for the ancient key to unlock it. She dug through a few pockets, shifted some contents to the floor and eventually located it, magnetized to the band of her smart watch that hadn’t been charged since she last stayed at her place. Just as she bent down and gathered the things she had thrown on the floor she heard footsteps approaching.

 

“Vidal! Hey Vidal! What’s up?” called a husky, gruff voice from the other end of the hall.

 

“Hey Marco! How’s it going man?” Rio replied to the towering, meat head in a cut off shirt and basketball shorts barreling towards her. 

 

“Tell me you’re playing today! We got our asses handed to us on Monday!” He groaned as he greeted her with a high-five and a pat on the back. 

 

“Yeah, that’s the plan. Alice is coming back too.” 

 

“That little speed demon? Awe hell yeah! She’s a ball of fire! Chad is going to lose his shit!” He snorted. “So what’s been going on with you? Haven’t seen you around the halls lately, they workin you too much at the hospital?”

 

“Yeah work’s been busy. I’ve also been staying over at my girlfriend’s place.” Rio explained

 

“Oooh, your girlfriend’s place.” His voice lilted in that singsongy taunting tone. “Things are getting pretty serious then?” 

 

“Heh, I’d say so.” Rio replied as she brought up a hand to rub at the back of her neck as a flutter of nerves washed over her. “We’re…uh…we’re actually having a baby in a little over a month.”

 

“Oh shit!” Marco’s eyes nearly flew out of his head in shock. “Yeah that’s..uh…that’s about as serious as you can get. Damn, does that mean you’re moving out on us?” 

 

“I mean, yeah, eventually. I guess sooner rather than later. My lease is up at the end of June so we’ll probably make it official then.” 

 

“Man, I hate to see you go! But, hey, congratulations! That's super exciting!” He cheered before a concerned realization struck him. “You’ll still play with us though right?”

 

“I think I’ve got a few more games in me before I’m out for the season.” Rio reasoned

 

“And you’ll come back next year? Once things settle?” he half begged.

 

“If I can make it happen I will.” She chuckled at his enthusiasm. 

 

“Excellent!” He cheered as he pumped his fist. “Don’t want to lose our best player!”

 

“Please I’m hardly your best.” Rio scoffed

 

“Don’t sell yourself short! You got most of these guys dripping sweating up and down the court trying to keep up with you. Well, glad you’re back today at least. I’m gonna head down and get warmed up before Chad gets his sweaty hands on all the balls. See you down there!”

 

“Yeah man, see you down there!” Rio waved him off as she slid her key into the lock and pushed her way through into her apartment. 

 

At this point it had been over a month since she had slept here and it was apparent. The earthy amber fragrance she had cultivated was hidden under a layer of musty staleness. Her plants had been regretfully neglected, many of which long since withered and died though a few were still holding on for dear life. She plopped her bag on the counter and went to inspect the fridge. As soon as she cracked the door she was met with several pungent odors competing to make her gag. She quickly closed it and moved to grab the trash can and drag it close. She inhaled deeply and held her breath as she reopened the door and scraped the minimal contents of her fridge into the trash. She quickly tied the bag shut and hauled it over her shoulder to immediately take down to the dumpster outside. 

 

The journey down was longer than she remembered, particularly so with the stench that lingered behind every step. With a grunt and a heave she disposed of the trash then made her way back to the main entryway to head down the hall and check her mail. As she approached the locker she could see bits of paper sticking out of the slats and she kicked herself for not thinking to check sooner. She twisted the knob until the lock clicked and cautiously cracked the door. All at once a waterfall of envelopes and fliers poured out onto the floor around her. She closed her eyes and let out a deep irritated sigh before bending down to gather what was essentially a pile of trash. As she struggled to collect everything she heard a pair of feet rushing towards her.

 

“Need any help?” Offered a kind and somewhat familiar voice 

 

“No…I think I got it, thanks though.” Rio replied as she dropped a handful of letters, not really looking at the person standing right in front of her. 

 

“You sure about that?” The person giggled as they bent down to help. 

 

As Rio grabbed the pile of mailers the person had picked up she gasped in shock. “Yelena! What the hell are you doing here?” She shrieked, immediately dropping everything she had collected to tackle her in a hug. “I didn’t think you would get here until tomorrow! Is Nat with you? ” 

 

“Hey! It’s good to see you too!” Yelena laughed. “No, Nat’s still coming tomorrow night with Hela. My schedule got switched around so I was free and figured I’d head up early, see if you needed any help before the party on Saturday. I was hoping to surprise you!”

 

“You’re sure fucking did! How’d you know I was here?” She asked as her forehead wrinkled in confusion.

 

“To be fair, I had no idea where you were. I did try and check at the hospital first, obviously you weren’t there so I came to check here and caught you swimming in mail. What happened?” She asked as she started picking up envelopes again. 

 

“Hate to say it’s been a minute since I checked the mail.” Rio explained

 

“You don’t say.” Yelena scoffed

 

“Hey! I’ve been busy and I’m not really here too often these days.” Rio retorted

 

“Why am I not surprised? Sounds like things are going well.”

 

Rio didn’t reply immediately, caught up in the memory of the previous days. “Yeah…yeah for sure! Really well.” 

 

“Uh-oh”

 

“What?”

 

“That sounded less than convincing.” Yelena replied skeptically.

 

“No, really everything’s fine, it’s great…it’s just…”

 

“RIO!” Alice belted from the entryway.

 

“Hey Alice! You made it!” Rio called back as she stood to greet her. 

 

“What the hell? Did you rob the mailman or something?” Alice chortled as she got closer and could see the mayhem that had ensued.  

 

“No, it’s just been a few days.” Alice exchanged a doubtful glance with Yelena. “Ok, maybe a few weeks.”

 

“Need any help?” Alice offered

 

“I think there are a couple packages in the locker, if you wouldn’t mind grabbing those and we can all head up. Alice, this is Yelena by the way, one of my friends from Boston, she’s come up for the party. Yelena, this is Alice, one of Agatha’s friends.” Rio explained as she scooped up the last of the papers from the floor.

 

“Oh yeah! You were at the bar that night we came to visit. You were with that woman in the pink suit, right? Nice to finally meet you.” Yelena said as she reached out a hand to Alice.

 

“That was Jen, Agatha’s friend from college. Alice actually owns the bar that we were at.” Rio explained as she led them back up to her apartment. 

 

“No kidding! Well we had a great time, would definitely go back!” Yelena insisted. “What are you two up to this morning?”

 

“Rio had invited me over for a pick up game in the gym. You’ll be joining us right? They need all the help they can get!” Alice chuckled

 

“OOO, I don’t know about that!” Yelena cringed

 

“Come on, it’ll be fun! No one really takes it seriously, just friendly competition.” Rio insisted

 

“Eh, you know basketball isn’t really my sport. I wouldn’t say I have an advantage.”

 

“You’d be surprised. The guys might have us on height but most of them could barely run a mile. I run circles around them. And then of course they never expect anyone to pass you the ball so I scored half the points last time.” Alice explained

 

“I’ll consider it. I wasn’t really planning on chasing any balls today.” 

 

Rio snorted in laughter as they approached her door. “Sorry if my place is a bit messy. Like I said, it’s been a minute since I’ve been back.”

 

“It can’t be that bad! You’ve been to my place.” Yelena scoffed.

 

“Fair enough, just know I warned you.” Rio cautioned as she opened the door letting the musty amber smell greet them. “You can just throw the mail and boxes on the counter, I’ll sort through it later.” 

 

“When you said your place was a mess I was expecting it to be a lot worse.” Alice chuckled as she set the packages down. “Is there a bit of a smell? Sure, but nothing a few cracked windows and some air circulation can’t fix.” 

 

“You really haven’t been here!” Yelena gasped as she inspected a particularly shriveled plant. “I don’t think I’ve ever seen you kill a plant.” 

 

“I know, I’ve only been by a few times to quickly grab clothes and things and that was still weeks ago. What can I say, my priorities have shifted a bit.”

 

“I would hope so! What is it? You have like a month left?” Yelena asked

 

“Hopefully…at least a month.” Rio grumbled as she put a new bag in the trashcan. 

 

“She’s not due until June right? You have plenty of time!” Alice reassured

 

“How far along are you on baby prepping?” Yelena asked

 

“To be honest I’ve been stress cleaning all week. It feels like we have nothing together. Agatha is swamped with getting ready for the festival and is already doing more than she should, which is driving me crazy, so I’m trying to fill in the gaps. The baby’s room is stuffed with shipping boxes and shopping bags, I haven’t had a chance to touch anything in there.”

 

“You still want to set that up on Saturday morning before the party?” Alice asked

 

“That’s the plan, if you’re still up for it.”

 

“Of course!” Alice exclaimed

 

“Is Jen still good to take her out and keep her occupied?” Rio asked

 

“Oh yes, she’s got a whole plan now. I think she’s actually excited about it.” Alice said as she opened a few windows.

 

“Sweet, that’s going to make this all so much easier!” Rio sighed in relief.

 

“I know you had asked Nat and I to pick up the food, but if you need any other help I’m here.” Yelena offered

 

“Oh I’m definitely going to need your help! There’s a lot more to pull together than I initially thought, and of course we’ll still have to set up for the actual party. We’ll just have Nat and Hela pick up the food.” 

 

“Jeez! I’m glad I came early. Were you really going to try and set everything up just the two of you?” Yelena exclaimed

 

“Well, Lilia agreed to help with the party set up but yeah, I’m going to need more hands.” 

 

“Oh nice! Your aunt’s coming? I take it you three had a chance to chat and work things out?” Alice asked

 

“Work things out? What happened with Lilia?” Yelena asked

 

“I told you she was the one who figured out Agatha was pregnant in the first place. The pregnancy tests and everything.”

 

“Oh, right.” Yelena replied, her eyes flashing as she remembered the details.

 

“Things have been understandably awkward since then but Agatha, surprisingly, agreed to sit down and talk things over with her. Try and start fresh, ya know.” 

 

“And it went well?” Alice asked

 

“Better than I expected! Agatha even admitted she liked her, so she’s coming to the party.”

 

“Good! I’m glad it went well! You two deserve to have some sort of stable family in your lives.” Alice said as she plopped down on the couch. 

 

“Oh, I wouldn’t consider Lilia stable by any means but she does care about us. I know she’ll be there for whatever we need, and she’s certainly going to spoil the shit out of this kid!” Rio cracked a smile at the thought but her mind quickly returned to the look Lilia had given her right before she had left. 

 

“You doing ok otherwise?” Yelena asked, seeing the flash of concern dance across her face. 

 

“Yeah, I’m fine. Totally fine, just a little overwhelmed with it all.” Rio hurried to explain, brushing off Yelena’s worry.

 

“I’d be concerned if you weren’t!” Alice shouted from the couch “You know what might help with that?” She said, popping up to look over the back of the sofa.

 

“What?” Rio chuckled

 

“Kicking some ass on the court!” Alice insisted, pointing a determined finger in her direction.

 

Rio let out a breathy laugh, “You are too right. Let me go get changed. Yelena, you playing?”

 

“Not in this!” She gestured to her outfit of a grey sweater and jeans with a pair of doc martins. 

 

“Obviously. Come on, I’ll find you something to wear.” Rio insisted as she turned Yelena around and pushed her down the hall towards her bedroom.

 

As soon as the door closed behind them Yelena flopped back onto the bed while Rio rifled through the doors. 

 

“So, what’s really going on?” Yelena probed as she tucked her arms beneath her head and stared pointedly at Rio. 

 

Rio didn’t glance back but could feel her gaze boring into her. “Nothing, I’m fine. Like I said, I’m just tired and a little overwhelmed.”

 

“Eh, I’m not buying it.” Yelena retorted

 

“Not buying what?” Rio feigned ignorance and continued to dig about her room, doing her best to dismiss Yelena’s concern. 

 

“Please, we survived medical school together. I’ve seen you exhausted and way more overwhelmed than this! This is different. You look worried.” 

 

“Worried?” The bluntness with which Yelena had seen her sent a bolt of panic down Rio’s spine. “Why…why would I be worried?” She stuttered, trying and failing to uphold her nonchalance. 

 

“I don’t know, you tell me.” Yelena sat up, her gaze now burning a hold through Rio’s soul as she leaned forward onto her elbows in full interrogation mode. “Out with it Vidal!” 

 

Rio chewed at the side of her mouth as she considered what was actually bothering her. She and Agatha were in a good place. They had overcome so much and were finally in a position to enjoy this exciting new life on the horizon, but something was gnawing at her. Though she had tried to brush it off and occupy her mind with preparing for the baby, she couldn’t help but acknowledge the real fear that was plaguing her and growing by the night. 

 

“I’m…afraid.” She closed her eyes, letting the weight of her admission settle.

 

They sat for a moment in silence before Yelena asked, “Afraid of what?”

 

“Agatha’s been having trouble with high blood pressure. She’s dealing with a lot, too much really. The doctor finally put her on some medication to help manage it and I thought things would calm down after we dealt with the whole court thing, but she still has spikes here and there. We’re getting closer and she’s just doing way too much.” 

 

“It makes sense why you would be concerned. That’s not something you really want to take lightly. Have you two talked about it?”

 

“Not exactly. After the appointment I suggested maybe she take a step back at work, do what she can from home, give herself a break before the baby is born. But she wouldn’t hear of it, not with the festival coming up. She’s putting a lot of pressure on herself and I’m afraid it might make things worse.”

 

“Ugh, that’s not good! No wonder you’re spiraling about it. It sounds like you might want to try and have another conversation.”

 

“I’ve tried but I’m afraid if I push it too much more she’s just going to work harder out of spite, to prove that she can do it. She’s tough and determined to see this festival through to the end but I’m worried it’s going to break her! I…I don’t know what I’d do if she…If something happened…” Rio was practically chewing a hole through her cheek trying to keep from crying as her eyes quickly flooded with tears. 

 

Yelena pushed herself from the bed and moved to pull Rio into a hug. “Hey! It’s going to be ok! I’m sure she’ll be perfectly fine, they both will, they’re in great hands! Besides, you know they’ll just put her on bedrest if the medication really isn’t working. It’s too much of a risk not to.”

 

“I know, and I’m afraid she’s going to lose it if they do that before the festival!” Rio groaned

 

“Maybe, but she wouldn’t really have a choice, that shit can be life or death.” Yelena reminded her.

 

“Oh, believe me, I’m well aware. For now I’m just trying to hold everything together, make sure she has what she needs, get the house together, try and get her to relax as much as possible. It’s been exhausting!” Rio sighed as she flopped onto the bed. 

 

“You need to be careful or you’re going to wear yourself down before this baby comes!” Yelena warned as she settled down next to her.

 

“Agatha was saying something similar this morning.” Rio laughed as she began to wipe away the few tears that had managed to fall. “She actually kicked me out of the house for the day because she wanted me to chill. She said I was too wound up because I’d been cleaning her house within an inch of its life trying to manage my stress about everything.” 

 

“See! It sounds like both of you need a break! Really you guys should do like a baby moon or something.” 

 

“A what?”

 

“A baby moon. You know, like a honeymoon? Take a trip or a few days off at least before the baby is born. Enjoy the last bit of freedom you have before your life is nothing but sleepless nights and diaper changes.” 

 

“Heh, that’s going to take some convincing, but it’s not a bad idea. Maybe for a day or two once the festival is underway, then she’ll have no choice but to relax!” 

 

Just then Alice burst through the door. “Oh come on! You guys haven’t even changed yet! What have you been doing this whole time?” Alice looked quickly back and forth between them. “You two weren’t hooking up in here were you?” 

 

“Ugh! Absolutely not!” “Ha! Hell no!” They protested in unison.

 

“Phew! Not going to lie, I was worried for a second. That would have been a disaster! So we still doing this or have plans changed? I’m down for whatever.” Alice shrugged.

 

“Oh, no, we’re still doing this! I can’t wait to see the look on Chad’s face when the three of us walk in at the last minute.” Rio chuckled

 

“Then you two better get it together, we’ve only got like 5 minutes.” Alice warned as she turned to head back into the kitchen.

 

“Thanks.” Rio muttered as she threw Yelena an outfit.

 

“For what?” 

 

“For coming up to help out. For helping me talk things over. I really appreciate it.” Rio explained as she slipped on a pair of gym shoes.

 

“You know I’m here for you any time man! It’s all going to work out. She’s going to be fine. The baby is going to be fine. Just try and give yourself a break, ok? Let yourself be excited.” Yelena urged

 

 “You’re right. I’ve just got to get out of my own head about it. This should help.” She smirked as she helped Yelena to her feet.

 

“What’s that?”

 

“Kicking Chad’s ass.” Rio chortled

 

“Who’s Chad?”

 

“He’s a douche. Don’t worry, you’ll know him when you see him.” Rio scoffed

 

“He sounds delightful. You think we can make him cry?” Yelena chuckled

 

“Gods that would just make my day! If we can make him cry I’m buying everyone lunch!”

 

“I think I just got excited about this game.” Yelena snorted

 

“Alice!” Rio called as she and Yelena made it out to the kitchen. “New goal, we’re gonna try and make Chad cry.”

 

“And it will be music to my ears! Damn, I fucking hate that guy!” Alice laughed

 

“Don’t we all! You ready to do this?” Rio asked as she grabbed each of them a water bottle.

 

“Let’s go!!!” Alice shouted as she ushered them out the door.




As the three of them entered the school gym Marco made his way over to greet them. “Damn dude! Cutting it close! You had me worried for a minute that you were going to flake!”

 

“No, no, just had to get the whole team assembled. You remember Alice,”

 

“Sup Marco!” Alice beamed

 

“And this is my friend Yelena from Boston.” Rio said, nodding her head in Yelena’s direction.

 

“Hey, nice to meet you!” Yelena smiled and waved. 

 

“Likewise! I’m glad you brought reinforcements. Brian is out with “knee pain” so we’ll need all the help we can get. Chad is on one today, he’s already driving me up a wall.” The four of them looked over to spot an average height balding man with a sizable gut peeking out of his cut off t-shirt. He wore a handlebar mustache and sported sweatbands on his head and wrists, knee braces on both knees, and sports goggles strapped to his head. He was over at the other end of the court loudly criticizing his teammates' form as they threw some practice shots. 

 

“Oh I see what you mean. He looks like a total douche.” Yelena grumbled, getting a chuckle out of Marco. 

 

“Oh, I think I’m gonna like her! If you guys wanna get some practice shots in, I'd shoot a few now, we’re gonna get started here in a couple minutes.” He said as he handed over the ball he had been carrying. 

 

They made their way to the nearest hoop and began taking turns throwing shots and warming up. Almost instantly their practice was interrupted by a nauseating drone as Chad slid down to their side of the court. 

 

“Well, well, well! Look who decided to show up today! I figured after last week you would have realized that you’re out of your league.” He said in a smarmy tone

 

“Bro, it’s a pick up game, there are no leagues.” Alice scoffed

 

“That may be, but still, the win just isn’t as satisfying when you’re playing against a bunch of girls. I mean, come on, it’s inevitable.” He chortled

 

“Girls? Bitch, I’m 35!” Yelena snarled

 

“Buzz off Chad! You know as well as I do that we can beat you with our eyes closed. Last week was a fluke, I had a lot going on.” Rio growled as she sunk another practice shot.

 

“A fluke?” He snorted “Right, blame your period or whatever, just know you have no chance and might as well go braid each other's hair or something.” 

 

Rio narrowed her eyes and marched up to stand toe to toe with Chad. “Believe what you want to, just don’t act shocked when you’re sweating bullets and barely able to breathe because we’re running circles around you again.” She finished with a smirk. “See you on the court, Chad.”  She said as she shoved the ball she was holding into his gut and led the other two to the benches where Marco was waiting. 

 

“Ugh, you were right, he is particularly insufferable today!” Rio groaned as she stuck out her tongue in disgust. 

 

“I know! After last week and Monday his ego has fucking ballooned.” Marco said, rolling his eyes in annoyance. 

 

“I’m surprised he can walk with how big his head is!” Alice chuckled
